title: Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources Pathway (AFNRM) | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
text: Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources Pathway (AFNRM) | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources Pathway (AFNRM) Home Pathways and Programs AFNRM Ag Food Production Business (AFP) The Agriculture and Food Production Business program equips students with essential knowledge and skills in economics, marketing, communication, and management. These principles are crucial for the sale and supply of agricultural products, including both plant and animal, across the entire agricultural industry spectrum. Animal Systems (ANS) The Animal Systems program is ideal for students aiming to become veterinarians, vet techs, vet assistants, or pursue careers in scientific, health, or agricultural fields. The program imparts knowledge and skills related to animal health and disease, basic animal care and nursing, clinical and laboratory procedures, and the anatomical and physiological systems of both small and large animals. Food Systems (FS) The Food Systems program equips students with knowledge and skills in plant and animal structural anatomy, systems physiology, genetics and biotechnology, production economics, and various management approaches for plant and animal production. Advanced courses offer personalized learning experiences, focusing on food production, entrepreneurship, and the integration of academic, technical, and employability skills. Natural Resources Management (NRM) The Natural Resources Management program is designed for students interested in becoming environmental stewards, working as environmental scientists, conservationists, foresters, or wildlife managers. The program covers environmental impacts, public policy, and the fundamental science and management of resources, with a focus on current practices that support healthy and sustainable natural resources. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. text: Animal Systems (ANS) | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Animal Systems (ANS) Home Pathways and Programs AFNRM Animal Systems Animal Systems (ANS) Pathway Map to Employment Careers in Animal Systems span a variety of roles that focus on the health, care, and management of animals. These careers require specialized knowledge in animal science, health care, and various biological and clinical practices. Students in the Animal Systems program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into this field with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities.  The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the Animal Systems program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore the field through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in Animal Systems will require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training is required, you may be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview : The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey : If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement : As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.title: Windward Community College Veterinary Technology Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Windward Community College Veterinary Technology Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Veterinary Technology Program Home AFNRM ASNS Programs Program Description: Get an academic foundation essential to becoming a member of a veterinary health care team. Laboratory and clinical experiences expand on classroom knowledge to equip you with the necessary skills of an entry-level veterinary technician. Graduates pursue careers in private veterinary practices, biomedical research, academia, and other health-related fields. There are two pathways within the Veterinary Technology Program : On-Campus Veterinary Assisting and Veterinary Technology Program This educational pathway is best suited for students who can attend classes full-time on the Windward Community College campus in KÄneâohe. Hybrid Veterinary Assisting and Veterinary Technology Program Best suited for students who reside on a neighbor island or Oâahu, and are working at least 20 hours per week in a veterinary facility. These dynamic programs are designed to prepare students for careers in the veterinary industry! If youâre interested in continuing your education in veterinary school, consider UH Manoaâs BS in Animal Science or UH Hiloâs BS in Agriculture , both of which offer a Pre-Veterinary track. These tracks provide students with pre-veterinary advising, degree options, guidance on vet school admissions, and additional resources to support your path to becoming a veterinarian. While Hawaii does not have a veterinary school, Hawaii residents have access to the Western Interstate Commission for Higher Education Professional Student Exchange Program (WICHE PSEP). This program allows a limited number of students to attend participating veterinary schools at in-state tuition rates. Veterinary schools in the WICHE program include Washington State University, Oregon State University, and Colorado State University, with Hawaii funding three students per year to attend these schools. Students not selected for WICHE will pay out-of-state tuition, as will those attending veterinary schools in non-WICHE states. Apply Now Contact Program Director Jenny Kelly Program Director (808) 263-9166 jennyrk@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: The Veterinary Technology program has a Certificate of Achievement (CA) in Veterinary Assisting (VETA) and an Associate in Science (AS) in Veterinary Technology (VETT). You must complete the VETA certificate FIRST in order to apply for the second year continuation into the VETT program. VETA Program admissions requirements: Be 18 years or older by the first day of instruction Attend an information session Submit an application to Windward Community College and complete health clearance requirements through Admissions & Records office Place into ENG 100 and MATH 101 Show proof of health insurance AFTER completion of the VETA Program, students can go through the competitive application process to be accepted into the VETT Program.  See VETT Program admissions requirements . Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Additional fees: up to $500 per semester Total number of credits: VETA: 31, VETT: 42, 73 total credits for the AS VETT Approximate total program tuition costs: VETA: $4,061, VETT: $5,502, Total AS VETT $9,563 Estimated program length (based on full time student status):  VETA: 1 year, VETT, 1.5 to 2 years, Total AS VETT 2.5 to 3 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the Windward Community CollegeÊ»s Veterinary Technology program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree program requirements for the Windward Community Collegeâs CA and AS in Agriculture program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I âCâ or better in ENG 22, or Placement into ENG 100 PSY 100: Survey of Psychology None Program Specific Courses: ENG 100: Composition I âCâ or better in ENG 21 or 23, or placement into ENG 100X *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration.  Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. subcontent.title: Associate in Science degree in Natural Science Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Associate in Science degree in Natural Science Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Associate in Science degree in Natural Science (ASNS) Home AFNRM ASNS Programs Program Description: The Associate in Science degree in Natural Science (ASNS) is offered at all 7 UH Community College campuses and prepares students to transfer to four-year institutions. These 60 credit programs provide clear, explicit, coherent pathways in biological and physical sciences for students intending to transfer into Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) majors, including those bachelor programs in the Agriculture, Ag Food Production, Animal Systems, Food Systems and Natural Resources Management Pathway maps. The program provides curricula that focus on basic science and mathematics as well as more advanced research and mentoring experiences. The degree provides students with undergraduate research opportunities as they move through STEM curricular pathways. Targeted advising and appropriate course sequencing enable the efficient transfer of STEM students. Program Prerequisites: Placement into English 100 Composition I Placement into Math 103 College Algebra or higher **Prerequisites vary per campus, check specific campus pages. University of Hawaii Community Colleges that offer ASNS - Biological or Physical Sciences: Kapiolani Community College Leeward Community College Windward Community College Honolulu Community College HawaiÊ»i Community College Kauai Community College UH Maui College Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 60 Approximate total program tuition costs: ~$8,060 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the community collegeâs ASNS programs. General Academic Courses: ENG 100 Composition I Math 103 College Algebra BIOL 171 General Biology BIOL 171L Lab CHEM 161 General Chemistry I CHEM 161L Lab PHYS 170 General Physics PHYS 170L Lab **Check campus pages for individual course prerequisites as they vary per campus. *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration.  For these courses, please check with the specific campus for course prerequisites.  Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: Students who complete the Associateâs degree in Natural Science program can apply to 4-year university programs within the UH System. While there are no official program-to-program articulations for the Biological and Physical Science concentrations, there are course articulations that facilitate credit transfers between campuses. For more information, please consult your advisor. Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. subcontent.title: UH Hilo Agriculture Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: UH Hilo Agriculture Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Agriculture Program Home AFNRM ASNS Programs Program Description: UH Hilo College of Agriculture, Forestry, and Natural Resources Management (CAFNRM) offers the Bachelor of Science degree (BS) in three areas of specialization: Animal Health and Management (which includes a pre-veterinary option) Aquaculture Tropical Agroecology Additionally, non-Agriculture majors can also pursue a Minor in Agriculture. To provide a well-balanced education, a good portion of a typical curriculum consists of College of Arts and Sciences courses as well as CAFNRM courses. CAFNRM also offers academic subject certificates for baccalaureate degree seeking students and non-degree seeking students: Beekeeping Certificate Equine Science Certificate Unmanned Aircraft Systems Certificate All CAFNRM students are invited to participate in the Agriculture Club. This is a student organization that promotes agriculture, food security and sustainability through education and service in the community. The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) projects strong employment opportunities for college graduates in the food, agricultural, and natural resources system in the United States. Apply Now Contact Program Director Norman Arancon Program Director (808) 932-7037 normanq@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to UH Hilo Competition of General Education courses Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $306 Total number of credits 120 Approximate total program tuition costs: $36,720 Estimated program length: 4 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the UH Hilo CAFNRM program: General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100 BIOL 171 & 171 Lab None Program Specific Courses: AG 230: Sustainable Agriculture None *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration.  Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: While there are no official program-to-program articulations for the UH Hilo BS in Agriculture, there are course articulations that facilitate credit transfers between campuses. There is also a UH System wide transfer policy for general education classes.  For more information, please consult your advisor or visit individual program pages. Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. subcontent.title: Agriculture Animal Systems Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Agriculture Animal Systems Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Agriculture Animal Systems Admission Requirements Home Pathways & Programs Admission Requirements High school students aspiring to enter post-secondary programs in the Animal Systems field should excel in biology, chemistry, and math courses to build a strong foundation in the sciences. Courses in animal science or agriculture can provide valuable insights. Participation in extracurricular activities such as 4-H, FFA (Future Farmers of America), or volunteering at animal shelters or farms can offer hands-on experience and demonstrate their commitment to working with animals. Gaining practical experience through internships or part-time jobs in veterinary clinics or related settings will further enhance their college applications and readiness for a career in animal systems. The basic admissions requirements can include: Course prerequisites: Some programs have specific prerequisite coursework that must be completed before applying. These prerequisites usually include general education requirements such as MATH 103 or BIOL 171, these will vary by program and campus (see campus program page for more details). GPA requirements: Some programs have minimum GPA requirements that students must meet with all prerequisite courses. These requirements can vary per campus. Application process: Certain programs will have a detailed set of application requirements such as submitting a written personal statement, and professional reference letters or interviewing with the program. Field or work experience: Having experience with animals or agriculture through internships, part time jobs, work-based learning experiences or a students own social capital will give an advantage when applying for some programs. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to select an education program, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs related to the Animal Systems POS: KapiÊ»olani Community College, ASNS, Biological or Physical Science Windward Community College, ASNS, Biological or Physical Science Windward Community College, Associate of Science Degree, Veterinary Technology Leeward Community College, ASNS, Biological or Physical Science Honolulu Community College, ASNS, Biological or Physical Science KauaÊ»i Community College, ASNS, Biological or Physical Science HawaiÊ»i Community College, ASNS, Biological or Physical Science UH Maui College, ASNS, Biological or Physical Science * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i Hilo For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Animal Systems Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Animal Systems ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs For entry-level positions in the Animal Systems field, several industry-related credentials can enhance your qualifications and demonstrate foundational knowledge and skills. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. The following are some NON-CREDIT (not related to college) programs you can take that will help you in your career journey. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for Animal Systems related careers: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for healthcare professionals, including nurses. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Pet First Aid/CPR: You love your pets and want to keep them happy â and providing a healthy lifestyle and being prepared to deliver first aid care for your pet is the best way to do that! In this online course, you will learn the basics in caring for cats and dogs through a variety of topics â from understanding and checking your pet's vital signs, to preventative care for cats and dogs, to caring for the most critical emergency situations - including breathing and cardiac emergencies, wounds, bleeding, and seizures. Range of program duration: 35 Minutes Animal Care Certification (CPACP): Becoming a CPACP shows your community that your professional qualifications and body of knowledge have met the highest pet care standards established by industry experts and have been certified by an independent testing body. 125-question CPACP exam, conducted at an approved testing location for a total testing time of 2.5 hours, covers animal care topics including health issues such as administering medications, first aid and CPR, and cleaning and disinfecting. Additional tested health-related knowledge includes fights and bites; documentation; profile, play, behavior, and temperament; and animal management. Range of program duration: 500 hours of hands on work experience with animals, 2.5 hours 125 question Certification Exam Theses training programs can lead to the following entry level Jobs: Animal Caretaker Kennel Technician Pet Groomer Assistant Animal Shelter Worker Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Animal Science Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Animal Science Program Home AFNRM Animal Science Program Description: Animal Sciences (ANSC) is the application of experimental investigation, cutting edge technology, and other scientific principles for the advancement of efficient and environmentally friendly animal agriculture and improved food quality and safety. Students receive training in both basic and applied agricultural systems, as well as in animal sciences. The present Bachelor in Science (BS) in Animal Sciences (ANSC) program focuses on pre-veterinary training with most emphasis on swine, sheep, beef and dairy cattle, and pond aquaculture production and management systems. Students are also exposed to the challenges of proper care/welfare and management of pets and companion animals (including horses), marine mammals, exotic wildlife and/or zoo animals. Unlike most continental United States institutions, the emphasis of the present program is on tropical production systems with particular reference to the Pacific Basin or other sub-tropical regions. Upon entering the program, students will be assisted by academic advisers to identify their career objectives and select an appropriate option for study. Apply Now Contact Information Contact Information (808) 263-9166 hnfas@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to UH MÄnoa UH MÄnoa General Education required courses Minimum cumulative UHM GPA 2.0 Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total program tuition costs: $56,520 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. text: Food Systems (FS) | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Food Systems (FS) Home Pathways and Programs AFNRM Food Systems Food Systems (FS) Pathway Map to Employment A career in Food Systems involves understanding and managing the complex processes that bring food from farm to table. Professionals in this field work across various sectors, including agriculture, production, distribution, marketing, and policy, ensuring that food systems are efficient, sustainable, and equitable. Students in the Food Systems program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into this field with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the Food Systems program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore the field through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in Food Systems will require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training is required, you may be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview : The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey : If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement : As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Food Systems Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Food Systems ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs For entry-level positions in the Food Systems field, several industry-related credentials can enhance your qualifications and demonstrate foundational knowledge and skills. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. The following are some NON-CREDIT (not related to college) programs you can take that will help you in your career journey. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for Food Systems related careers: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for healthcare professionals, including nurses. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Food Handlers Card: The class is designed to provide the food handler with a basic understanding of food microbiology, major foodborne illnesses, and learn how to implement specific procedures to ensure safe food preparation. Range of program duration: 3 hours ServSafe: ServSafe certifications are preferred, if not required, by most employers in the food service industry. The ServSafe Food Handler certification fulfills the training requirement for a HawaiÊ»i Food Handlerâs Card. Range of program duration: 3 hours OSHA 10: General Industry: Agriculture: Learn how to recognize and avoid common workplace hazards with this voluntary training program. This deep dive into OSHA safety standards is designed for entry-level workers in general industry roles. This 100% online course focuses on the prevention, recognition, avoidance and abatement of potential hazards at work. Students who complete this course will receive an official OSHA 10 card from the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL). Range of program duration: 10 hours Theses training programs can lead to the following entry level Jobs: Food Industry worker or manager Food Production worker Farmers Market worker Farm Assistant Sales Representatives Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Food Systems Training & Certification Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Food Systems Training & Certification Programs Home Pathways and Programs AFNRM Food Systems Training Program The University of HawaiÊ»i Community Colleges offer various training programs and certifications that can significantly enhance your career prospects in the Food Systems industry. Many of these certifications can be pursued while you are still in high school or shortly after graduation, providing specialized knowledge and skills. These certifications provide focused, hands-on training in areas such as food safety, culinary techniques, food processing, and sustainable practices, which can be immediately applied in the workplace. They not only make individuals more competitive in the job market but also demonstrate a commitment to industry standards and best practices, which can build credibility with employers, clients, and stakeholders. For those looking to gain practical skills without the commitment of a full academic program, non-credit certifications, either through UHCCâs or local organizations, offer targeted, hands-on training that can be immediately applied in the field. They are more flexible and less time-consuming than traditional courses, making them ideal for working professionals or those seeking to quickly upskill. Additionally, these certifications enhance your resume, show a proactive approach to learning, and increase job opportunities and career advancement potential. The following are certifications that can be acquired at UHCC campuses: Agriculture-Based Production Development & Entrepreneurship Certificate - Leeward Community College Entrepreneurship Certificate - KauaÊ»i Community College Sustainable Agriculture Certificate - Windward Community College Agri Pharmatech Certificate - Windward Community College Maui Food & Innovation Center (MFIC) Certificate - MFIC, UH Maui College The following are non-credit certifications that can be acquired: Bring Your Product to Market: âÄina to MÄkeke - Leeward Community College Young Entrepreneurs Program - Hawaii Ag Foundation Maui Food & Innovation Center (MFIC) Classes & Workshops - MFIC, UH Maui College Go Farm HawaiÊ»i Training Programs - UH GoFarm Good Agricultural Practices - UH Manoa CTAHR Farm Food Safety Rural & Cooperative Business Development Services - The Kohala Center Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Leeward Community College Sustainable Agriculture | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Leeward Community College Sustainable Agriculture Home AFNRM Sustainable Agriculture Program Description: If you are passionate about plants and sustainability, this is the degree for you. The Sustainable Agriculture program offers education and training for you to be part of Hawaiiâs diversified agriculture and conservation fields. Youâll learn from a variety of fields including: soil science natural resource management organic agriculture plant propagation nutrition Our classes are dynamic and applied to current issues related to tropical agriculture and island sustainability. We focus on sustainable agriculture practices that are science-based, environmentally sound, and benefit our island community. We have a research and learning farm on campus that supports our classes by allowing students to learn hands-on with composting, vermicast, integrated pest management, and growing and eating amazing produce. We also have a native plant garden that serves those interested in native plant conservation. Programs in Sustainable Agriculture: Associate in Science (AS), Sustainable Agriculture Academic Subject Certificate (ASC), Agriculture Business Certificate of Achievement (CA), Sustainable Agriculture Certificate of Competence (CO), Sustainable Agriculture Certificate of Competence (CO), Aquaponics Technician Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Daniela Elliot Program Coordinator (808) 455-0398 ddutra@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Eri Nomura Program Counselor (808) 984 3306 eri4@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: None Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 60 Approximate total program tuition costs: $7,869-$8,646 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the Leeward Community College program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite - Grade or credit in EN 22 or 24, OR Placement into ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics *Prerequisite - Grade or credit in Math 82X, OR Placement into MATH 100 or higher. Program Specific Courses: ICS 101 Digital Tools for the Information World *Prerequisite - None ENT 125 Starting a Business *Prerequisite - ENG 22 or 24, or Placement into ENG 100 BOT 130  & BOT 130 Lab, Plants in the Hawaiian Environment Placement in ENG 100 *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: Students who complete the Associate of Science degree in Sustainable Agriculture may apply to transfer to the following programs via a transfer agreement with the 4-year university programs listed below. UH West Oahu - Bachelors of Art in Sustainable Community Food Systems ( Articulation Agreement - Fall 2020 ) Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. Management is a basic requirement for career advancement in any field that you may choose. Prepare for entry-level employment and supervisory positions in a variety of organizations. Become an expert in the use of the latest computer software, conquer office essentials, and get the edge needed to land that first job or earn that promotion! Our program provides training in the communication, problem-solving, and leadership skills necessary for success and advancement in todayâs workplace. An emphasis on entrepreneurship is included to prepare students to be a vibrant part of Hawaiiâs growing kamaâaina economy. Degree seeking students, students intending to transfer, as well as those interested in a few targeted courses for professional development are encouraged to be part of the program. There are three general academic tracks in the program: crop production, landscaping, and resource management. Students can work toward an Associate in Applied Science in Sustainable Tropical Crop Production or Horticulture and Landscape Maintenance; or work with the Program Coordinator to develop an Associate in Technical Studies in Cultural and Natural Resource Management. Farmer development training is condensed in a Certificate of Competence. subcontent.text: HawaiÊ»i Community College TEAM Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us HawaiÊ»i Community College TEAM Program Home AFNRM TEAM Program Program Description: The Forest TEAM Program leads to a Certificate of Achievement (CA) and the Applied Science (AS) degree in Tropical Forest Ecosystem and Agroforestry Management . Students learn to actively manage threatened native forests and regenerate Hawai`i's native ecosystems. They learn how to grow native plants and establish agroforestry operations. Classes include training in the use of Global Positioning Systems (GPS), and Geographic Information Systems (GIS). Internships give students hands-on learning with potential employers such as the National Park Service, the US Forest Service, the Biological Resources Division of the US Geological Survey, the Hawai`i Department of Land and Natural Resources, the Nature Conservancy of Hawai`i, Kamehameha Schools, and members of the Hawai`i Forest Industry Association. To provide a well-balanced education, a good portion of a typical curriculum consists of College of Arts and Sciences courses as well as CAFNRM courses. CAFNRM also offers academic subject certificates for baccalaureate degree seeking students and non-degree seeking students: Beekeeping Certificate Equine Science Certificate Unmanned Aircraft Systems Certificate All CAFNRM students are invited to participate in the Agriculture Club. This is a student organization that promotes agriculture, food security and sustainability through education and service in the community. The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) projects strong employment opportunities for college graduates in the food, agricultural, and natural resources system in the United States. subcontent.title: HawaiÊ»i Pacific University Biotechnological Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: HawaiÊ»i Pacific University Biotechnological Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us HawaiÊ»i Pacific University Biotechnological Engineering Program Home AFNRM Biotechnology Engineering Program Description: The Bachelor of Science in Biotechnology Engineering degree at HPU involves the design, development, and application of innovative technologies, products, and/or environmentally sustainable systems through the efficient use of resources. Biotechnology specializations include those related to bioenvironmental engineering and bioprocess engineering. Bioenvironmental engineering is the application of engineering principles to the natural environment and its ecosystems for sustaining and remediation of environmental quality of life. Bioenvironmental engineering solutions may seek to address topics of concern in soil ecology, land treatments, waste treatment and management, air quality, biofuels, and ground water hydrology. Bioprocess engineering is the application of engineering principles to the design, construction, integration, and/or maintenance of environmentally responsible systems for process sustainability and remediation. Bioprocess engineers may be concerned with manufacturing processes of food, chemicals, pharmaceutics, herbal supplements and/or other natural/bio resources like stem cells. Other bioprocessing topics may include industrial hygiene, emergency response systems, biomaterials packaging/transporting systems etc. The HPU Bachelor of Science in Biotechnology Engineering is a four-year program. HPU Bachelor of Science in Biotechnology Engineering graduates will find employment in biotechnology industry, within sectors such as agriculture, environmental, healthcare, food manufacturing, and pharmaceutical industries. subcontent.title: Agriculture Food Systems Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Agriculture Food Systems Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Agriculture Food Systems Admissions Requirements Home Pathways & Programs AFNRM Early College High school students aiming to enter post-secondary programs in the Food Systems field should focus on excelling in science courses such as biology and chemistry, as well as math, to understand the fundamental aspects of food production and safety. Business and economics courses will also be beneficial, as they provide insights into the economic and managerial aspects of food systems. Participation in related extracurricular activities, such as 4-H, FFA (Future Farmers of America), or nutrition clubs, along with gaining practical experience through internships or volunteer work in agriculture, food production, or community food programs, will strengthen their preparation and college applications. The basic admissions requirements can include: Course prerequisites: Some programs have specific prerequisite coursework that must be completed before applying. These prerequisites usually include general education requirements such as MATH 135 or BIOL 171, these will vary by program and campus (see campus program page for more details). GPA requirements: Some programs have minimum GPA requirements that students must meet with all prerequisite courses. These requirements can vary per campus. Application process: Certain programs will have a detailed set of application requirements such as submitting a written personal statement, and professional reference letters or interviewing with the program. Field or work experience: Having experience with agriculture or business through internships, part time jobs, work-based learning experiences or a students own social capital will give an advantage when applying for some programs. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges : To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to select an education program, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs associated with Food Systems: KapiÊ»olani Community College Windward Community College Leeward Community College Honolulu Community College KauaÊ»i Community College HawaiÊ»i Community College UH Maui College *University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa *University of HawaiÊ»i Hilo *University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu: For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map *HawaiÊ»i Pacific University: HPU understands that each student has a unique academic history and individual talents. This is why HPU takes a holistic approach to reviewing applications, and considers all the information provided on your application to make an admissions decision. For more admissions information, please visit the HPU Admissions website . Preparing for leadership in a complex, dynamic world necessitates new knowledge and skills. As an island, Maui is considered a 'closed system' and is therefore a natural living laboratory for observing successes and failures in sustainability pursuits. Sustainability science has emerged as one of the fastest-growing professions, with applications in a variety of fields and opportunities for meaningful work in the future. Join the Sustainable Science Management (SSM) program today! Programs in Sustainable Science Management: Bachelor of Applied Science (BAS), Sustainable Science Management (SSM) BAS, SSM with Concentration in Marine Studies Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Meagan Jones Program Coordinator (808) 984 3709 meaganj@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Eri Nomura Program Counselor (808) 984 3306 eri4@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply to UH Maui College Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 for courses 100 and 200 level (Lower Division), $306 for courses 300 and 400 level (Upper Division) Additional fees: $50 per semester Total number of credits: 64-66 lower division credits, 60 Uperdivison, 124-126 total credits Approximate total program tuition costs: ~ $26,944 - $27,206 Estimated program length (based on full time student status): 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the UH Maui CollegeÊ»s Agriculture program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. subcontent.title: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Entrepreneurship Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Entrepreneurship Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Entrepreneurship Program Home AFNRM Entrepreneurship Program Description: The Bachelor of Business Administration (BBA) in Entrepreneurship program is designed to prepare future entrepreneurs with the skills and knowledge to start their own businesses. The program will focus on identifying, analyzing and evaluating global and local business opportunities; creating new independent business ventures or new ventures within existing firms; developing creativity and understanding innovation; ethical and social responsibilities for entrepreneurs; environment assessment for new ventures; marketing research; financial planning; developing effective business plans to obtain financing; sources of capital; legal issues related to starting and operating a business; valuation; family owned businesses; succession; and opportunities for women and minority entrepreneurs. Apply Now Program Contact Information Program Contact Information (808) 956-8215 business@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: For admission to the BBA in Entrepreneurship Program, students must: Complete 60 credits (Junior Standing), credits must be acceptable at UH Manoa if taken at another institution Have a cumulative GPA of 2.5 or higher Complete either LTEC 112 âTechnologies for Academic Sucessâ AND LTEC 113 âTechnologies for Academic Sucess - Businessâ OR ICS 101 âDigital Tools for the Information Worldâ Complete 7 Pre-Business core courses with a minimum of âCâ grade (some courses will fulfill the general education requirements): English Composition (ENG 100/190/ESL 100, OR ENG 200) Calculus (BUS 250; NREM 203; OR MATH 203, 215, 241, or 251A) Speech (COMG 151 OR COMG 251) Principles of Microeconomics (ECON 130) Principles of Macroeconomics (ECON 131) Introduction to Accounting I (ACC 200)* Introduction to Accounting II (ACC 210)* *Qualified High school applicants seeking direct entry to the program as first-year/freshman can apply for Direct Admit Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Program fees per semester: $941 Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total tuition costs: ~$64,048 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree general program related requirements for the UH Manoa BBA in Entrepreneurship program: General Education/Program PreBusiness Courses: ENG 100: Composition I Placement into ENG 100 ICS 101: Digital Tools for the Information World None ECON 131: Principles of Economics None COMG 151: Personal and Public Speech None (COMG 151 is the equivalent of SP 151 at all UH Community Colleges) *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Natural Resources & Environmental Management Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Natural Resources & Environmental Management Program (NREM) Home AFNRM NREM Program Description: Welcome to the Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Management (NREM) at the University of Hawaii, Manoa. We are part of the College of Tropical Agriculture and Human Resources (CTAHR). Our department's focus is preparing students to be natural resources managers and professionals, with emphasis upon: Understanding the biophysical aspects of natural resources within a tropical island context Using the latest information, tools, and models to effectively manage these resources Discovering the real economic value of these resources and evaluating the costs and benefits of different management options Working with the community and stakeholders to implement practical solutions to their resource management challenges and concerns. Our program combines hands-on learning with the latest theories and concepts. Students choose between natural or social science pathways but take courses in both areas. An internship is required for all NREM students, offering real-world experience, professional networking, and guidance for academic and career planning. Students choose between: Natural Science Pathway Study the natural, physical, and biological aspects of managing natural resources and the environment. Specialize inâ¦ Plant Ecology, Conservation, and Management Soil and Water Conservation Watershed and Coastal Management Wildlife Ecology and Management Image and Data Science for NREM Social Science Pathway Study the social, cultural, and economic aspects of managing natural resources and the environment. Specialize inâ¦ Community and Cultural Resources Management Environmental Policy and Governance Sustainable Systems and Communities Apply Now Program Program Chair Dr. Travis Idol Program Chair (808) 956-7508 nremadv@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply and be accepted to UH Manoa Complete the general education requirements See program advisor for specific general education requirements for the NREM program. Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total tuition costs: $56,520 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree general program related requirements for the UH Manoa BS in NREM, taken prior to admission to the program: General Education Courses: ENG 100: Composition I Placement into ENG 100 ECON 130: Principles of Economics None MATH 134: Precalculus: Elementary Functions Prerequisite: 2 yrs or HS Algebra, 1 year HS Geometry. This course is the same as MATH 135 Precalculus at the University of HawaiÊ»i Community Colleges, NREM program requires MATH 203, MATH 134 is the prerequisite to MATH 203. *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Biological Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Biological Engineering Program Home AFNRM Biological Program Description: Completing a B.S. in Biological Engineering (BE) will prepare you for a variety of careers in traditional as well as emerging biotech fields. Graduates have accepted engineering positions such as designing process equipment and systems for biological production and treatment, or implementing site preparation for construction or bioremediation of environmental contamination. They are prepared to help engineer systems to develop renewable sources of energy, and to improve the value of natural products produced in Hawaii for food and therapeutic applications. Increasing numbers of graduates from BE are meeting demands from growing biotech industries in Hawaii, for example for the production of systems for culturing human tissues for medical replacement and for screening, extracting, and producing antibiotics and other pharmaceutical compounds from Hawaii's unique natural biota. Many Bioengineers are employed with forward thinking institutions like NASA that are interested in engineering self-sustaining habitable environments in space as well as on Earth. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Biological Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Molecular Bioscience & Biotechnology Program Home AFNRM Molecular Program Description: The cutting-edge tools of molecular biology, genetics, cell biology, tissue culture, and biochemistry are transforming the environmental, medical, and agricultural sciences. In the field of biotechnology, these bioscience tools are harnessed to make products and solve problems faced by society. The biotechnology program emphasizes developing a strong foundation in the molecular and biochemical principles underpinning living cells (animals, microbes, and plants). The program combines hands-on laboratory research with courses covering various facets of molecular, cellular, and organismal biosciences (outlined below). The program facilitates excellence in biotechnology education by involving undergraduate students in rich interactions with faculty in both the classroom and research laboratories. MBB graduates have excellent job prospects upon graduation. Graduates are amply prepared to enter graduate studies in the biological, environmental, medical, and agricultural sciences and are profession-ready for job opportunities in industry (biomedical, health-care diagnostics, pharmaceutical, forensics, agricultural, environmental, and biotechnological) and in governmental research. With additional courses in education, the BS degree in MBB also qualifies graduates to teach at the elementary, middle, and high school levels. The MBBE faculty have a commitment to and passion for teaching, combined with renowned research expertise in their chosen disciplines. The faculty provide independent research experiences for undergraduate students (as MBBE 499), and many have well-funded research programs utilizing state-of-the art equipment and techniques. On-campus research facilities that students can use to enhance their education and research experience include the Biological Electron Microscope Facility; the Greenwood Molecular Biology Facility; and the Center for Advanced Studies in Genomics, Proteomics and Bioinformatics.
