subcontent.title: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Tropical Agriculture and the Environment (TAE) Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Tropical Agriculture and the Environment (TAE) Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Tropical Agriculture and the Environment (TAE) Program Home AFNRM Trop Agriculture Program Description: The Tropical Agriculture and the Environment (TAE) undergraduate program at the University of Hawaii at MÄnoa (UHM) is a unique program for those who like the outdoors and wish to combine that interest with a professional career. Our students come from many academic and cultural backgrounds. Some have very little practical environmental or agricultural experience. However, they all share a keen interest in applying science for the purpose of finding practical solutions to problems. The comprehensive undergraduate program gives students the opportunity to study plant systems at the molecular, biochemical, or species level, as well as managed and natural ecosystems. Our graduates have a wide variety of career opportunities from which to choose, ranging from the laboratory to outdoor activities. Undergraduate student in labBiotechnology is one of the exciting new fields offered in the program. Several members of the TAE faculty are responsible for genetically engineering a ring spot virus resistant papaya cultivar, which has saved the local industry. This technology, in conjunction with traditional plant breeding and production related research, has the potential is to increase food supply, improve food quality, and assure food safety while protecting the environment and improving the quality of life. Undergraduates are encouraged to obtain practical experience by conducting research under the direction of a faculty member, and working in a commercial industry via our internship program. Students enrolled in Tropical Agriculture and the Environment program (TAE) will enjoy learning the science, technology, and art of growing and using plants and their products, and about the soils crucial to man. The undergraduate advisors and faculty are committed to preparing you for a challenging career in one of many interesting and rewarding areas. The University of Hawaii at MÄnoa (UHM) is an accredited land-grant university in the tropics, and its program in Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences has a uniquely tropical emphasis. We emphasize the study of the tropical species that are important as Hawaii foliage plants (Mainland âhouseâ plants) such as anthuriums, orchids, tropical lei and cut flowers, nursery and landscape plants, and turfgrass. Other equally important areas of study are the food crops such as vegetables, macadamia nuts, papaya, coffee and new potentially important tropical crops. Agri-Business Certification: The Agribusiness Certificate program is designed to meet the needs of students who want a competitive advantage when entering the agriculture and food systems job market. The program will provide students the opportunity to apply business, management, and accounting principles to agribusinesses and to understand what differentiates agriculture and agriculture-related products and services from other businesses. The basic business literacy offered through the Agribusiness Certificate program will benefit all program and life sciences graduates, whatever their field, interest, or career choice. The certificate program is open to all UH Manoa undergraduate students. The Certificate requires that you take three 300-level courses, as the agribusinesses core courses for a total of 9 credits. A passing grade in all three courses is required to complete the certificate. Each course is offered once a year, with two courses scheduled in the Fall semester and one in the Spring semester. The three courses can be taken in any sequence: TPSS 322 Farm and Food Marketing TPSS/NREM 341 Accounting & Financial Analysis TPSS 351 Enterprise Management Prerequisite for all 3 courses is ECON 131 Principles of Economics and BLAW 200 Business Law. subcontent.title: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Food Science & Human Nutrition Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Food Science & Human Nutrition Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Food Science & Human Nutrition Program Home AFNRM Food Science Program Description: There are Five Exciting Tracks Within the FSHN (BS) Program: Food Science: Business Combine nutrition coursework with classes in business management This study track educates and develops skills in students who desire to work in food processing, regulation and food business arena, both in the public and private sector. This track also prepares students for managerial positions since there is a high demand for people with skills in food science and knowledge of business, accounting, and interpersonal skills. Students learn about food chemistry, microbiology, structure, engineering, safety, regulation, sanitation, quality control, and business. Food Science: Pre-Professional Focus on product development and food technology Develop your skills in food processing, regulation and the food business arena in both private and public sectors! This track also prepares students for managerial positions in the demanding field of food service! You can gain some knowledge in business, accounting, and interpersonal skills. Culinology Blend culinary arts with the science of food A new and exciting field involving the blend of culinary arts and the science of food! The Food Science & Human Nutrition Culinology option at the University of Hawai'i at MÄnoa is a 2+2 program that offers graduates of Kapi'olani Community College's Culinary Arts Associate's in Science (AS) program an opportunity to pursue a Bachelor's of Science (BS) degree from the Department of Human Nutrition, Food and Animal Sciences. Sports and Wellness Augment nutrition coursework with classes in exercise science Students who are interested in pursuing a career in sports and wellness, are encouraged to complete course work in applied musculo-skeletal anatomy, exercise physiology (KRS 353 and 354), and nutrition in exercise and sport (FSHN 480). This track prepares students for careers at health clubs, fitness centers, and spas. Pre-Professional Human Nutrition Prepare for post-baccalaureate study in medicine, dentistry, nutrition, or other graduate program This course of study allows students to study other areas of science, foods, and nutrition. With guidance from their advisor, students can design a course of study to meet their course requirements to prepare them for different aspects of applied nutrition, food science, post- baccalaureate studies in other health professional programs (medicine, dental, pharmacy), or an advanced research degree in nutrition or other biomedical sciences. However, this course of study does not meet all the undergraduate academic course work requirements of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics. subcontent.title: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Dietetics Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Dietetics Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Dietetics Program Home AFNRM Dietetics Program Description: The Dietetics program mission is to provide the foundation knowledge and skills in dietetics for successful preparation of students for supervised practice leading to eligibility for the CDR credentialing exam to become a registered dietitian nutritionist with an emphasis on community nutrition and an appreciation for the unique cultural environment of Hawaiâi and US Affiliated Pacific Region. The Didactic Program in Dietetics (DPD) in the Department of Human Nutrition, Food and Animal Sciences (HNFAS) is the only dietetics program offered in the State of Hawai'i. Students are expected to rigorously apply their knowledge and skills in food science and nutrition for daily living and good health. Upon successful completion of the DPD program, students will earn a Bachelor's of Science (BS) degree in Dietetics. Students majoring in dietetics may earn a DPD Verification Statement (which is required to apply for a dietetic internship and registered dietitian exam). Apply Now Contact Program Director Monica Esquivel, PhD, RDN Program Director (808) 956-8691 monicake@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Prior to applying for the BS in Dietetics, interested students must: Be accepted to UH Manoa Earn 60 credits by completing undergraduate general education requirements, must include the following courses some of which can count towards your undergraduate general education requirements: MATH 140 or higher PHYL 141 & 141 Lab PHYL 142 & 142 Lab CHEM 161 & 161 Lab CHEM 162 & 162 Lab Complete FSHN 185 Human Nutrition, with a âBâ or better Declare their major in one of the Food Science Human Nutrition degree programs Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits: 60 Gen Ed credits, 60 program credits = 122 total credits Approximate total tuition costs: $57,462 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree general program related requirements for the UH MÄnoa BS in Dietetics program, taken prior to admission to the program: General Education Courses: FSHN 185: The Science of Human Nutrition None ENG 100: Composition I Placement into ENG 100 HIST 151: World History to 1500 None MATH 140: Precalculus Prerequisite: MATH 134 Precalculus: Elementary Functions (Same at MATH 135 Precalculus at the University of HawaiÊ»i Community Colleges) *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. subcontent.text: AA Hawaiian Studies Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Agriculture: Graduate School Home Pathways and Programs AFNRM Graduate School Graduate School is an advanced level of academic study (MasterÊ»s degree, PhD or Doctoral degree, etc.) that follows the completion of an undergraduate degree (BachelorÊ»s degree). Graduate school is crucial for certain careers in the Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources industry, as it provides advanced knowledge, research skills, and specialized training that are essential for leadership roles and technical positions. For careers in agricultural research, environmental policy, food science, and natural resource management, a graduate degree can deepen expertise in areas like sustainable practices, biotechnologies, and ecosystem management. This level of education also opens doors to academic and research positions, high-level consultancy, and roles in governmental and international organizations, where advanced qualifications are often required to influence policy, drive innovation, and address complex challenges in the industry. For students considering applying to graduate school, here are five important factors to consider: Career Goals: Determine whether a graduate degree is necessary for your desired career path. Some careers in fields like academia, research, or specialized industry roles require advanced degrees, while others may not. Field of Study: Consider what specific area or discipline you want to focus on in graduate school. Graduate programs are highly specialized, so itâs important to have a clear understanding of your academic and professional interests. Program Requirements: Research the prerequisites for the graduate programs youâre interested in, including required coursework, standardized tests (like the GRE), and any relevant work or research experience. Make sure you meet these requirements or have a plan to do so. Financing: Think about how you will finance your graduate education. Consider tuition costs, availability of scholarships, assistantships, or grants, and whether youâll need to take out loans. Weigh the potential return on investment of a graduate degree in your field. Research potential scholarship opportunities. Time Commitment: Understand the time commitment involved in graduate school. Masterâs programs typically take 1-3 years, while doctoral programs can take 4-7 years or more. Consider how this fits into your long-term personal and professional plans. subcontent.text: UH Hilo Marine Science Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Marine Science Program Home AFNRM Marine Science Program Description: The Marine Science Department at UH Hilo has the resources to prepare the next generation of marine scientists. Located just 10 minutes from the shoreline and our research vessel, our students have access to HawaiÊ»i Islandâs unique variety of tropical marine environments all year long. Our Bachelorâs degrees in Marine Science have been carefully designed to provide students the opportunity to study the unique variety of marine environments found around the Island of HawaiÊ»i. We believe the best way to study the ocean is to be immersed in it. We prepare students to be innovative, successful life-long learners, and engaged stewards of the marine environment. The Marine Option Program (MOP) provides numerous field trips and experiences throughout the year. All faculty have active research programs, and we rely on undergraduates to participate as volunteers, employees, and project leaders on research projects. Students are encouraged to conduct their own research projects and can earn academic credit working on a MOP Project or a Senior Thesis. Opportunities exists to intern with our Boating Safety Program , Dive Safety Program , Analytical Lab , the HawaiÊ»i Cooperative Fishery Research Unit , as well as with local NGOs and federal and state agencies. Apply Now Contact Program Chair Kathryn Besio Program Chair (808) 932-7253 besio@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to UH Hilo Competition of General Education courses Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $306 Total number of credits 120 Approximate total program tuition costs: $36,720 Estimated program length: 4 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the UH Hilo Marine Science program: General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100 COM 251: Public Speaking None, (Same at UHCC SP 251 course) Program Specific Courses: MARE 171 & 171 Lab: Marine Biology-Diversity None *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: While there are no official program-to-program articulations for the UH Hilo BS in Agriculture, there are course articulations that facilitate credit transfers between campuses. There is also a UH System wide transfer policy for general education classes. For more information, please consult your advisor or visit individual program pages. Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. These careers require knowledge of agricultural practices, business principles, and the supply chain involved in bringing agricultural goods to market. Students in the Ag Food Production Business program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into this field with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the Ag Food Production Business program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore the field through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in Ag Food Production Business may require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training might be required, you may also be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview : The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey : If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement : As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. subcontent.text: AG Food Production Business Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us AG FOOD PRODUCTION BUSINESS ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs For entry-level positions in the Agriculture Food Production Business field, several industry-related credentials can enhance your qualifications and demonstrate foundational knowledge and skills. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. The following are some NON-CREDIT (not related to college) programs you can take that will help you in your career journey. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for Ag Food Production Business related careers: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for healthcare professionals, including nurses. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Food Handlers Card: The class is designed to provide the food handler with a basic understanding of food microbiology, major foodborne illnesses, and learn how to implement specific procedures to ensure safe food preparation. Range of program duration: 3 hours ServSafe: ServSafe certifications are preferred, if not required, by most employers in the food service industry. The ServSafe Food Handler certification fulfills the training requirement for a HawaiÊ»i Food Handlerâs Card. Range of program duration: 3 hours OSHA 10: General Industry: Agriculture: Learn how to recognize and avoid common workplace hazards with this voluntary training program. This deep dive into OSHA safety standards is designed for entry-level workers in general industry roles. This 100% online course focuses on the prevention, recognition, avoidance and abatement of potential hazards at work. Students who complete this course will receive an official OSHA 10 card from the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL). Range of program duration: 10 hours Theses training programs can lead to the following entry level Jobs: Food Industry worker or manager Food Production worker Farmers Market worker Farm Assistant Sales Representatives Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Value-Add Production Development Centers | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Value-Add Production Development Centers Home Pathways and Programs AFNRM Value-Add PDC Value-added production development centers in agriculture provide numerous benefits that can significantly enhance the profitability and sustainability of agricultural businesses. These centers offer farmers and producers the resources and expertise needed to create value-added productsâgoods that have been processed or transformed to increase their market value, such as turning raw fruits into jams or milk into cheese. By doing so, producers can diversify their product offerings, access new markets, and command higher prices for their products. These centers often provide access to specialized equipment, training, and technical assistance, helping farmers and merchants navigate the complexities of food safety regulations, packaging, branding, and marketing. Additionally, they may offer support in business planning and financing, enabling producers to scale their operations and increase their economic resilience. Ultimately, value-added production development centers empower agricultural businesses to capture more of the economic value from their products, leading to greater income stability and the ability to compete more effectively in the marketplace. The following are Value Add Production Development Center in HawaiÊ»i: WahiawÄ Value-Added Product Development Center - WahiawÄ, Ê»Oahu Maui Food Innovation Center (MFIC) - Kahalui, Maui Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. Certifications provide specialized knowledge and skills in areas such as crop management, livestock production, sustainable practices, and farm management, making individuals more competitive in the job market. They also demonstrate a commitment to industry standards and best practices, which can build credibility with employers, clients, and stakeholders. Additionally, certifications can open up opportunities for advancement, increase earning potential, and ensure compliance with regulations, ultimately leading to improved efficiency and productivity in agricultural operations. subcontent.text: Grow Your Own Business | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Grow Your Own Business Home Pathways and Programs AFNRM Grow Your Own Business Growing your own value-added product business means taking something you grow or produce, like fruits, vegetables, or milk, and turning it into something more valuable, like jams, sauces, or cheese, which you can sell for a higher price. Hereâs how you can do it, even as a young entrepreneur, by using local training programs, degree programs, and business incubators: Start with Local Training Programs: Look for workshops or classes in your community that teach you how to make value-added products. Review the Training Program or UHCC Certificate Programs to see if there are classes that fit. These classes can teach you the basics of food processing, safety, and marketingâeverything you need to start creating your product. Consider a Degree Program: Think about pursuing a degree in something like agriculture, food science, or business. These programs will give you a deeper understanding of how to grow your business. Youâll learn about the science behind food production, how to manage a business, and how to market your products to customers. College also offers networking opportunities with professors and other students who can support your business goals. Review the AFP Program of Study map to see what college programs align with this pathway. Utilize Business Incubators/Accelerators: Once you have your product idea and some training, look for a business Accelerator Program . These programs will help new businesses grow by providing resources like workspace, equipment, mentorship, and sometimes even funding. Theyâre like a support system for your business, helping you avoid common mistakes and grow faster. By combining the skills and knowledge you gain from these resources, you can turn your idea into a successful value-added product business. It takes time, but with the right support, you can create something that not only makes money but also adds value to your community. subcontent.text: Agriculture Non-Credit Training Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Agriculture Non-Credit Training Programs Home Pathways and Programs AFNRM Non-Credit Training Program Taking non-credit certifications in agriculture business offers several key benefits, especially for those looking to gain practical skills and knowledge without the commitment of a full academic program. These certifications provide targeted, hands-on training in specific areas such as sustainable farming, crop management, and agribusiness operations, which can be immediately applied in the field. They are often more flexible and less time-consuming than credit-bearing courses, making them accessible for working professionals or those looking to upskill quickly. Additionally, non-credit certifications can enhance a resume, demonstrating to employers a proactive approach to learning and staying current with industry trends, thereby increasing job opportunities and career advancement potential. These programs provide access to mentorship from industry experts, tailored business coaching, and networking opportunities with potential investors, partners, and customers. Participants often receive education on critical aspects of agribusiness, such as supply chain management, sustainable practices, and market strategies. Additionally, accelerators may offer seed funding or access to financial resources, helping businesses to grow more rapidly and sustainably. Overall, an accelerator program can fast-track the development of an agriculture business, enhance its market readiness, and increase its chances of long-term success. subcontent.text: Leeward Community College Sustainable Agriculture | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Leeward Community College Sustainable Agriculture Home AFNRM Sustainable Agriculture Program Description: If you are passionate about plants and sustainability, this is the degree for you. The Sustainable Agriculture program offers education and training for you to be part of Hawaiiâs diversified agriculture and conservation fields. Youâll learn from a variety of fields including: soil science natural resource management organic agriculture plant propagation nutrition Our classes are dynamic and applied to current issues related to tropical agriculture and island sustainability. We focus on sustainable agriculture practices that are science-based, environmentally sound, and benefit our island community. We have a research and learning farm on campus that supports our classes by allowing students to learn hands-on with composting, vermicast, integrated pest management, and growing and eating amazing produce. We also have a native plant garden that serves those interested in native plant conservation. Programs in Sustainable Agriculture: Associate in Science (AS), Sustainable Agriculture Academic Subject Certificate (ASC), Agriculture Business Certificate of Achievement (CA), Sustainable Agriculture Certificate of Competence (CO), Sustainable Agriculture Certificate of Competence (CO), Aquaponics Technician Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Daniela Elliot Program Coordinator (808) 455-0398 ddutra@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Eri Nomura Program Counselor (808) 984 3306 eri4@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: None Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 60 Approximate total program tuition costs: $7,869-$8,646 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the Leeward Community College program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite - Grade or credit in EN 22 or 24, OR Placement into ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics *Prerequisite - Grade or credit in Math 82X, OR Placement into MATH 100 or higher. Program Specific Courses: ICS 101 Digital Tools for the Information World *Prerequisite - None ENT 125 Starting a Business *Prerequisite - ENG 22 or 24, or Placement into ENG 100 BOT 130  & BOT 130 Lab, Plants in the Hawaiian Environment Placement in ENG 100 *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. It is designed for students who seek to gain a solid foundation of the basic business concepts and skills necessary to contribute and create solutions in todayâs business environment. Upon successful completion of this program, students will acquire the knowledge and skills to apply management, marketing, and accounting concepts to improve operational performance in a business setting. This degree can help an individual jump-start a career in business or prepare them for transfer to a four-year institution. The Business Program at Kauaâi Community College is offered 100% online, asynchronous. This means that Business Majors do not need to come to campus to take courses nor do they need to schedule a specific time to sit in on an online lecture. There are 2 campuses that have Hawaiian Studies programs with concentrations or subject certificates that align to the AFNRM Pathway. These 60 credit programs provide clear, explicit, coherent pathways in Hawaiian knowledge and culture with enhanced subject areas of AhupuaÊ»a Systems, and Malama Ê»Aina for students intending to transfer into Bachelor of Arts majors, including those bachelor programs in the Agriculture, Ag Food Production, Animal Systems, Food Systems and Natural Resources Management Pathway maps. The curricula focus on Hawaiian culture while fulfilling general education requirements as well as more hands-on cultural Ê»aina based and mentoring experiences. Targeted advising and appropriate course sequencing enable the efficient transfer of students to 4 year programs. Program Prerequisites: Placement into English 100 Composition I Placement into Math 100 Survey of Mathematics **Prerequisites vary per campus, check specific campus pages. An emphasis on entrepreneurship is included to prepare students to be a vibrant part of Hawaiiâs growing kamaâaina economy. Degree seeking students, students intending to transfer, as well as those interested in a few targeted courses for professional development are encouraged to be part of the program. There are three general academic tracks in the program: crop production, landscaping, and resource management. Students can work toward an Associate in Applied Science in Sustainable Tropical Crop Production or Horticulture and Landscape Maintenance; or work with the Program Coordinator to develop an Associate in Technical Studies in Cultural and Natural Resource Management. Farmer development training is condensed in a Certificate of Competence. subcontent.text: HawaiÊ»i Community College TEAM Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us HawaiÊ»i Community College TEAM Program Home AFNRM TEAM Program Program Description: The Forest TEAM Program leads to a Certificate of Achievement (CA) and the Applied Science (AS) degree in Tropical Forest Ecosystem and Agroforestry Management . Students learn to actively manage threatened native forests and regenerate Hawai`i's native ecosystems. They learn how to grow native plants and establish agroforestry operations. Classes include training in the use of Global Positioning Systems (GPS), and Geographic Information Systems (GIS). Internships give students hands-on learning with potential employers such as the National Park Service, the US Forest Service, the Biological Resources Division of the US Geological Survey, the Hawai`i Department of Land and Natural Resources, the Nature Conservancy of Hawai`i, Kamehameha Schools, and members of the Hawai`i Forest Industry Association. These 60 credit programs provide clear, explicit, coherent pathways in biological and physical sciences for students intending to transfer into Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) majors, including those bachelor programs in the Agriculture, Ag Food Production, Animal Systems, Food Systems and Natural Resources Management Pathway maps. The program provides curricula that focus on basic science and mathematics as well as more advanced research and mentoring experiences. The degree provides students with undergraduate research opportunities as they move through STEM curricular pathways. Targeted advising and appropriate course sequencing enable the efficient transfer of STEM students. Program Prerequisites: Placement into English 100 Composition I Placement into Math 103 College Algebra or higher **Prerequisites vary per campus, check specific campus pages. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration.  For these courses, please check with the specific campus for course prerequisites. To provide a well-balanced education, a good portion of a typical curriculum consists of College of Arts and Sciences courses as well as CAFNRM courses. CAFNRM also offers academic subject certificates for baccalaureate degree seeking students and non-degree seeking students: Beekeeping Certificate Equine Science Certificate Unmanned Aircraft Systems Certificate All CAFNRM students are invited to participate in the Agriculture Club. This is a student organization that promotes agriculture, food security and sustainability through education and service in the community. The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) projects strong employment opportunities for college graduates in the food, agricultural, and natural resources system in the United States. subcontent.text: AA Hawaiian Studies Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Agriculture: Graduate School Home Pathways and Programs AFNRM Graduate School Graduate School is an advanced level of academic study (MasterÊ»s degree, PhD or Doctoral degree, etc.) that follows the completion of an undergraduate degree (BachelorÊ»s degree). Graduate school is crucial for certain careers in the Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources industry, as it provides advanced knowledge, research skills, and specialized training that are essential for leadership roles and technical positions. For careers in agricultural research, environmental policy, food science, and natural resource management, a graduate degree can deepen expertise in areas like sustainable practices, biotechnologies, and ecosystem management. This level of education also opens doors to academic and research positions, high-level consultancy, and roles in governmental and international organizations, where advanced qualifications are often required to influence policy, drive innovation, and address complex challenges in the industry. For students considering applying to graduate school, here are five important factors to consider: Career Goals: Determine whether a graduate degree is necessary for your desired career path. Some careers in fields like academia, research, or specialized industry roles require advanced degrees, while others may not. Field of Study: Consider what specific area or discipline you want to focus on in graduate school. Graduate programs are highly specialized, so itâs important to have a clear understanding of your academic and professional interests. Program Requirements: Research the prerequisites for the graduate programs youâre interested in, including required coursework, standardized tests (like the GRE), and any relevant work or research experience. Make sure you meet these requirements or have a plan to do so. Financing: Think about how you will finance your graduate education. Consider tuition costs, availability of scholarships, assistantships, or grants, and whether youâll need to take out loans. Weigh the potential return on investment of a graduate degree in your field. Research potential scholarship opportunities. Time Commitment: Understand the time commitment involved in graduate school. Masterâs programs typically take 1-3 years, while doctoral programs can take 4-7 years or more. Consider how this fits into your long-term personal and professional plans. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Agriculture Food Production Business Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Agriculture Ag Food Production Business Admission Requirements Home Pathways & Programs Admission Requirements High school students interested in post-secondary programs in the Agriculture Food Production Business field should prioritize coursework in biology, chemistry, and math to build a strong foundation in the sciences. Additionally, taking business-related courses such as economics, marketing, and management will be beneficial. Participation in extracurricular activities like 4-H, FFA (Future Farmers of America), or business clubs can provide relevant experience and enhance college applications. Practical experience through internships, part-time jobs, or volunteering in agriculture or food production can further demonstrate their commitment and readiness for a career in this dynamic and essential industry. The basic admissions requirements can include: Course prerequisites: Some programs have specific prerequisite coursework that must be completed before applying. These prerequisites usually include general education requirements such as MATH 103 or HWST 107, these will vary by program and campus (see campus program page for more details). GPA requirements: Some programs have minimum GPA requirements that students must meet with all prerequisite courses. These requirements can vary per campus. Application process: Certain programs will have a detailed set of application requirements such as submitting a written personal statement, and professional reference letters or interviewing with the program. Field or work experience: Having experience with business or agriculture through internships, part time jobs, work-based learning experiences or a students own social capital will give an advantage when applying for some programs. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to select an education program, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs associated with Ag Food Production Business: KapiÊ»olani Community College Windward Community College Leeward Community College Honolulu Community College KauaÊ»i Community College HawaiÊ»i Community College UH Maui College * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i Hilo * University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. Preparing for leadership in a complex, dynamic world necessitates new knowledge and skills. As an island, Maui is considered a 'closed system' and is therefore a natural living laboratory for observing successes and failures in sustainability pursuits. Sustainability science has emerged as one of the fastest-growing professions, with applications in a variety of fields and opportunities for meaningful work in the future. Join the Sustainable Science Management (SSM) program today! Programs in Sustainable Science Management: Bachelor of Applied Science (BAS), Sustainable Science Management (SSM) BAS, SSM with Concentration in Marine Studies Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Meagan Jones Program Coordinator (808) 984 3709 meaganj@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Eri Nomura Program Counselor (808) 984 3306 eri4@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply to UH Maui College Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 for courses 100 and 200 level (Lower Division), $306 for courses 300 and 400 level (Upper Division) Additional fees: $50 per semester Total number of credits: 64-66 lower division credits, 60 Uperdivison, 124-126 total credits Approximate total program tuition costs: ~ $26,944 - $27,206 Estimated program length (based on full time student status): 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the UH Maui CollegeÊ»s Agriculture program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree program requirements for the UH Maui College BAS in Sustainable Science Management program. UH Maui College BAS SSM program courses: ENG 100: Composition I Prerequisite: âCâ or better in ENG 22 OR Placement into ENG 100 PSY 100: Survey of Psychology Prerequisite: âCâ or better in ENG 22, or Placement in ENG 100 CHEM 151: Elementary Survey of Chemistry Prerequisite: âCâ or better in ENG 22 or Placement into ENG 100 AND âCâ or better in MATH 82 or placement into MATH 103 *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. The program will focus on identifying, analyzing and evaluating global and local business opportunities; creating new independent business ventures or new ventures within existing firms; developing creativity and understanding innovation; ethical and social responsibilities for entrepreneurs; environment assessment for new ventures; marketing research; financial planning; developing effective business plans to obtain financing; sources of capital; legal issues related to starting and operating a business; valuation; family owned businesses; succession; and opportunities for women and minority entrepreneurs. Apply Now Program Contact Information Program Contact Information (808) 956-8215 business@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: For admission to the BBA in Entrepreneurship Program, students must: Complete 60 credits (Junior Standing), credits must be acceptable at UH Manoa if taken at another institution Have a cumulative GPA of 2.5 or higher Complete either LTEC 112 âTechnologies for Academic Sucessâ AND LTEC 113 âTechnologies for Academic Sucess - Businessâ OR ICS 101 âDigital Tools for the Information Worldâ Complete 7 Pre-Business core courses with a minimum of âCâ grade (some courses will fulfill the general education requirements): English Composition (ENG 100/190/ESL 100, OR ENG 200) Calculus (BUS 250; NREM 203; OR MATH 203, 215, 241, or 251A) Speech (COMG 151 OR COMG 251) Principles of Microeconomics (ECON 130) Principles of Macroeconomics (ECON 131) Introduction to Accounting I (ACC 200)* Introduction to Accounting II (ACC 210)* *Qualified High school applicants seeking direct entry to the program as first-year/freshman can apply for Direct Admit Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Program fees per semester: $941 Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total tuition costs: ~$64,048 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Dietetics Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Dietetics Program Home AFNRM Dietetics Program Description: The Dietetics program mission is to provide the foundation knowledge and skills in dietetics for successful preparation of students for supervised practice leading to eligibility for the CDR credentialing exam to become a registered dietitian nutritionist with an emphasis on community nutrition and an appreciation for the unique cultural environment of Hawaiâi and US Affiliated Pacific Region. The Didactic Program in Dietetics (DPD) in the Department of Human Nutrition, Food and Animal Sciences (HNFAS) is the only dietetics program offered in the State of Hawai'i. Students are expected to rigorously apply their knowledge and skills in food science and nutrition for daily living and good health. Upon successful completion of the DPD program, students will earn a Bachelor's of Science (BS) degree in Dietetics. Students majoring in dietetics may earn a DPD Verification Statement (which is required to apply for a dietetic internship and registered dietitian exam). Apply Now Contact Program Director Monica Esquivel, PhD, RDN Program Director (808) 956-8691 monicake@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Prior to applying for the BS in Dietetics, interested students must: Be accepted to UH Manoa Earn 60 credits by completing undergraduate general education requirements, must include the following courses some of which can count towards your undergraduate general education requirements: MATH 140 or higher PHYL 141 & 141 Lab PHYL 142 & 142 Lab CHEM 161 & 161 Lab CHEM 162 & 162 Lab Complete FSHN 185 Human Nutrition, with a âBâ or better Declare their major in one of the Food Science Human Nutrition degree programs Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits: 60 Gen Ed credits, 60 program credits = 122 total credits Approximate total tuition costs: $57,462 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree general program related requirements for the UH MÄnoa BS in Dietetics program, taken prior to admission to the program: General Education Courses: FSHN 185: The Science of Human Nutrition None ENG 100: Composition I Placement into ENG 100 HIST 151: World History to 1500 None MATH 140: Precalculus Prerequisite: MATH 134 Precalculus: Elementary Functions (Same at MATH 135 Precalculus at the University of HawaiÊ»i Community Colleges) *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. subcontent.title: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Tropical Agriculture and the Environment (TAE) Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Tropical Agriculture and the Environment (TAE) Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Tropical Agriculture and the Environment (TAE) Program Home AFNRM Trop Agriculture Program Description: The Tropical Agriculture and the Environment (TAE) undergraduate program at the University of Hawaii at MÄnoa (UHM) is a unique program for those who like the outdoors and wish to combine that interest with a professional career. Our students come from many academic and cultural backgrounds. Some have very little practical environmental or agricultural experience. However, they all share a keen interest in applying science for the purpose of finding practical solutions to problems. The comprehensive undergraduate program gives students the opportunity to study plant systems at the molecular, biochemical, or species level, as well as managed and natural ecosystems. Our graduates have a wide variety of career opportunities from which to choose, ranging from the laboratory to outdoor activities. Undergraduate student in labBiotechnology is one of the exciting new fields offered in the program. Several members of the TAE faculty are responsible for genetically engineering a ring spot virus resistant papaya cultivar, which has saved the local industry. This technology, in conjunction with traditional plant breeding and production related research, has the potential is to increase food supply, improve food quality, and assure food safety while protecting the environment and improving the quality of life. Undergraduates are encouraged to obtain practical experience by conducting research under the direction of a faculty member, and working in a commercial industry via our internship program. Students enrolled in Tropical Agriculture and the Environment program (TAE) will enjoy learning the science, technology, and art of growing and using plants and their products, and about the soils crucial to man. The undergraduate advisors and faculty are committed to preparing you for a challenging career in one of many interesting and rewarding areas. The University of Hawaii at MÄnoa (UHM) is an accredited land-grant university in the tropics, and its program in Tropical Plant and Soil Sciences has a uniquely tropical emphasis. We emphasize the study of the tropical species that are important as Hawaii foliage plants (Mainland âhouseâ plants) such as anthuriums, orchids, tropical lei and cut flowers, nursery and landscape plants, and turfgrass. Other equally important areas of study are the food crops such as vegetables, macadamia nuts, papaya, coffee and new potentially important tropical crops. Agri-Business Certification: The Agribusiness Certificate program is designed to meet the needs of students who want a competitive advantage when entering the agriculture and food systems job market. The program will provide students the opportunity to apply business, management, and accounting principles to agribusinesses and to understand what differentiates agriculture and agriculture-related products and services from other businesses. The basic business literacy offered through the Agribusiness Certificate program will benefit all program and life sciences graduates, whatever their field, interest, or career choice. The certificate program is open to all UH Manoa undergraduate students. The Certificate requires that you take three 300-level courses, as the agribusinesses core courses for a total of 9 credits. A passing grade in all three courses is required to complete the certificate. Each course is offered once a year, with two courses scheduled in the Fall semester and one in the Spring semester. The three courses can be taken in any sequence: TPSS 322 Farm and Food Marketing TPSS/NREM 341 Accounting & Financial Analysis TPSS 351 Enterprise Management Prerequisite for all 3 courses is ECON 131 Principles of Economics and BLAW 200 Business Law. Apply Now Program Contact Information Program Contact Information (808) 956-8351 tpss@ctahr.hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply and be accepted to UH MÄnoa Complete the general education requirements Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total tuition costs: $56,520 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree general program related requirements for the UH MÄnoa BS in Tropical Agriculture & Environment program: General Education Courses: ENG 100: Composition I Placement into ENG 100 ECON 131: Principles of Economics None CHEM 151: Elementary Survey of Chemistry Program requires CHEM 161 , this course is a prerequisite for CHEM 161. Placement into CHEM 161 is an alternative via campus placement exam MATH 140: Precalculus Prerequisite: MATH 134 Precalculus: Elementary Functions (Same at MATH 135 Precalculus at the University of HawaiÊ»i Community Colleges) *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. subcontent.title: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Food Science & Human Nutrition Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Food Science & Human Nutrition Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Food Science & Human Nutrition Program Home AFNRM Food Science Program Description: There are Five Exciting Tracks Within the FSHN (BS) Program: Food Science: Business Combine nutrition coursework with classes in business management This study track educates and develops skills in students who desire to work in food processing, regulation and food business arena, both in the public and private sector. This track also prepares students for managerial positions since there is a high demand for people with skills in food science and knowledge of business, accounting, and interpersonal skills. Students learn about food chemistry, microbiology, structure, engineering, safety, regulation, sanitation, quality control, and business. Food Science: Pre-Professional Focus on product development and food technology Develop your skills in food processing, regulation and the food business arena in both private and public sectors! This track also prepares students for managerial positions in the demanding field of food service! You can gain some knowledge in business, accounting, and interpersonal skills. Culinology Blend culinary arts with the science of food A new and exciting field involving the blend of culinary arts and the science of food! The Food Science & Human Nutrition Culinology option at the University of Hawai'i at MÄnoa is a 2+2 program that offers graduates of Kapi'olani Community College's Culinary Arts Associate's in Science (AS) program an opportunity to pursue a Bachelor's of Science (BS) degree from the Department of Human Nutrition, Food and Animal Sciences. Sports and Wellness Augment nutrition coursework with classes in exercise science Students who are interested in pursuing a career in sports and wellness, are encouraged to complete course work in applied musculo-skeletal anatomy, exercise physiology (KRS 353 and 354), and nutrition in exercise and sport (FSHN 480). This track prepares students for careers at health clubs, fitness centers, and spas. Pre-Professional Human Nutrition Prepare for post-baccalaureate study in medicine, dentistry, nutrition, or other graduate program This course of study allows students to study other areas of science, foods, and nutrition. With guidance from their advisor, students can design a course of study to meet their course requirements to prepare them for different aspects of applied nutrition, food science, post- baccalaureate studies in other health professional programs (medicine, dental, pharmacy), or an advanced research degree in nutrition or other biomedical sciences. However, this course of study does not meet all the undergraduate academic course work requirements of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics.
