subcontent.title: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Biological Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Biological Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Molecular Bioscience & Biotechnology Program Home AFNRM Molecular Program Description: The cutting-edge tools of molecular biology, genetics, cell biology, tissue culture, and biochemistry are transforming the environmental, medical, and agricultural sciences. In the field of biotechnology, these bioscience tools are harnessed to make products and solve problems faced by society. The biotechnology program emphasizes developing a strong foundation in the molecular and biochemical principles underpinning living cells (animals, microbes, and plants). The program combines hands-on laboratory research with courses covering various facets of molecular, cellular, and organismal biosciences (outlined below). The program facilitates excellence in biotechnology education by involving undergraduate students in rich interactions with faculty in both the classroom and research laboratories. MBB graduates have excellent job prospects upon graduation. Graduates are amply prepared to enter graduate studies in the biological, environmental, medical, and agricultural sciences and are profession-ready for job opportunities in industry (biomedical, health-care diagnostics, pharmaceutical, forensics, agricultural, environmental, and biotechnological) and in governmental research. With additional courses in education, the BS degree in MBB also qualifies graduates to teach at the elementary, middle, and high school levels. The MBBE faculty have a commitment to and passion for teaching, combined with renowned research expertise in their chosen disciplines. The faculty provide independent research experiences for undergraduate students (as MBBE 499), and many have well-funded research programs utilizing state-of-the art equipment and techniques. On-campus research facilities that students can use to enhance their education and research experience include the Biological Electron Microscope Facility; the Greenwood Molecular Biology Facility; and the Center for Advanced Studies in Genomics, Proteomics and Bioinformatics. Apply Now Program Contact Dr. David Christopher Program Contact (808) 956-8550 dchr@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply and be accepted to UH MÄnoa Complete the general education requirements and they must include: NREM 310 (statistics) MATH 215 or MATH 241 (calculus) BIOL 171/171L; 172/172L; 275/275L CHEM 161/161L; 162/162L; 272/272L PHYS 100/100L or 151/151L; 152/152L NREM 220 (economics) Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total tuition costs: $56,520 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree general program related requirements for the UH Manoa BS in Molecular Bioscience and Biotechnology program: General Education Courses: ENG 100: Composition I Placement into ENG 100 CHEM 151: Elementary Survey of Chemistry Program requires CHEM 161 , this course is a prerequisite for CHEM 161. Placement into CHEM 161 is an alternative via campus placement exam MATH 140: Precalculus Prerequisite: MATH 134 Precalculus: Elementary Functions (Same at MATH 135 Precalculus at the University of HawaiÊ»i Community Colleges) *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. text: Natural Resources Management (NRM) | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Natural Resources Management (NRM) Home Pathways and Programs AFNRM Natural Resources Natural Resources Management (NRM) Pathway Map to Employment Careers in Natural Resources Management focus on the sustainable use, conservation, and restoration of natural resources such as land, water, air, minerals, forests, and wildlife. Professionals in this field work to balance the needs of the environment with those of human development and industry. Students in the Natural Resources Management program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into this field with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the Natural Resources Management program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore the field through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in Natural Resources Management will require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training is required, you may be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview : The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey : If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement : As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Natural Resources Management Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Natural Resources Management ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs For entry-level positions in the Natural Resources Management field, several industry-related credentials can enhance your qualifications and demonstrate foundational knowledge and skills. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. The following are some NON-CREDIT (not related to college) programs you can take either while you are in high school or shortly after that will help you in your career journey. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for Natural Resources Management related careers: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. While BLS certification is often required for healthcare professionals, it is also very important for all jobs and careers. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Food Handlers Card: The class is designed to provide the food handler with a basic understanding of food microbiology, major foodborne illnesses, and learn how to implement specific procedures to ensure safe food preparation. Range of program duration: 3 hours Plant Propagation for Nursery Workers: Through Good Jobs HawaiÊ»i: Introduction to the principles and practices of propagation of fruit, vegetable, and ornamental crops by seed, cuttings, grafting, budding, layering and division. This course can be substituted for the work experience requirement for Nursery Worker I position openings with C&C Honolulu Department of Parks and Recreation. Range of program duration: TBD OSHA 10: General Industry: Agriculture: Learn how to recognize and avoid common workplace hazards with this voluntary training program. This deep dive into OSHA safety standards is designed for entry-level workers in general industry roles. This 100% online course focuses on the prevention, recognition, avoidance and abatement of potential hazards at work. Students who complete this course will receive an official OSHA 10 card from the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL). Range of program duration: 10 hours Theses training programs can lead to the following entry level Jobs: Food Production worker Farmers Market worker Farm Assistant Nursery worker Sales Representatives Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Natural Resources Management Training & Certification Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Natural Resources Management Training & Certification Programs Home Pathways & Programs Training & Certification Programs The University of HawaiÊ»i Community Colleges offer various training programs and certifications that can significantly enhance your career prospects in the Natural Resources Management industry. Many of these certifications can be pursued while you are still in high school or shortly after graduation, providing specialized knowledge and skills. These certifications provide focused, hands-on training in areas such as agriculture, environmental mapping, GIS mapping and sustainable practices, which can be immediately applied in the workplace. They not only make individuals more competitive in the job market but also demonstrate a commitment to industry standards and best practices, which can build credibility with employers, clients, and stakeholders. For those looking to gain practical skills without the commitment of a full academic program, non-credit certifications, either through UHCCâs or local organizations, offer targeted, hands-on training that can be immediately applied in the field. They are more flexible and less time-consuming than traditional courses, making them ideal for working professionals or those seeking to quickly upskill. Additionally, these certifications enhance your resume, show a proactive approach to learning, and increase job opportunities and career advancement potential. The following are certifications that can be acquired at UHCC campuses. There are 2 types of certifications available, Certificate of Competence (CO), which is between 12 and 15 UHCC college credits and is usually between 5 to 12 weeks long or Certificate of Achievement (CA), 25-35 UHCC college credits and completed over a 1 year period : HawaiÊ»i Community College Certificate of Competence (CO) Farm Worker Landscape Worker Certificate of Achievement (CA) Agriculture Geomatics and GIS Tropical Forest Ecosystem & Agroforestry Management UH Maui College Certificate of Competence (CO) Beekeeping GIS in Ecosystem Management Landscape Maintenance Natural Resource Management Pest Managment Sustainable Tropical Crop Production Certificate of Achievement (CA) Horticulture & Landscape Maintenance Sustainable Tropical Crop Management Nursery Management Windward Community College Certificate of Competence (CO) Agripharmatech: Plant Food Production & Technology Sustainable Agriculture Certificate of Achievement (CA) Veterinary Assisting Agripharmatech: Plant Biotechnology Agripharmatech: Ethnopharmacognosy KauaÊ»i Community College Certificate of Competence (CO) Hawaiian Botany Leeward Community College Certificate of Competence (CO) Sustainable Agriculture: Ag Systems & Tropical Crop Production Sustainable Agriculture: Aquaponics Technician Agriculture-Based Production Development & Entrepreneurship Certificate Certificate of Achievement (CA) Sustainable Agriculture The following are non-credit certifications that can be acquired: Bring Your Product to Market: âÄina to MÄkeke - Leeward Community College Young Entrepreneurs Program - Hawaii Ag Foundation Maui Food & Innovation Center (MFIC) Classes & Workshops - MFIC, UH Maui College Go Farm HawaiÊ»i Training Programs - UH GoFarm Good Agricultural Practices - UH Manoa CTAHR Farm Food Safety Rural & Cooperative Business Development Services - The Kohala Center Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Leeward Community College Sustainable Agriculture | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Leeward Community College Sustainable Agriculture Home AFNRM Sustainable Agriculture Program Description: If you are passionate about plants and sustainability, this is the degree for you. The Sustainable Agriculture program offers education and training for you to be part of Hawaiiâs diversified agriculture and conservation fields. Youâll learn from a variety of fields including: soil science natural resource management organic agriculture plant propagation nutrition Our classes are dynamic and applied to current issues related to tropical agriculture and island sustainability. We focus on sustainable agriculture practices that are science-based, environmentally sound, and benefit our island community. We have a research and learning farm on campus that supports our classes by allowing students to learn hands-on with composting, vermicast, integrated pest management, and growing and eating amazing produce. We also have a native plant garden that serves those interested in native plant conservation. Programs in Sustainable Agriculture: Associate in Science (AS), Sustainable Agriculture Academic Subject Certificate (ASC), Agriculture Business Certificate of Achievement (CA), Sustainable Agriculture Certificate of Competence (CO), Sustainable Agriculture Certificate of Competence (CO), Aquaponics Technician Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Daniela Elliot Program Coordinator (808) 455-0398 ddutra@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Eri Nomura Program Counselor (808) 984 3306 eri4@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: None Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 60 Approximate total program tuition costs: $7,869-$8,646 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the Leeward Community College program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite - Grade or credit in EN 22 or 24, OR Placement into ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics *Prerequisite - Grade or credit in Math 82X, OR Placement into MATH 100 or higher. Program Specific Courses: ICS 101 Digital Tools for the Information World *Prerequisite - None ENT 125 Starting a Business *Prerequisite - ENG 22 or 24, or Placement into ENG 100 BOT 130  & BOT 130 Lab, Plants in the Hawaiian Environment Placement in ENG 100 *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: Students who complete the Associate of Science degree in Sustainable Agriculture may apply to transfer to the following programs via a transfer agreement with the 4-year university programs listed below. UH West Oahu - Bachelors of Art in Sustainable Community Food Systems ( Articulation Agreement - Fall 2020 ) Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. It is designed for students who seek to gain a solid foundation of the basic business concepts and skills necessary to contribute and create solutions in todayâs business environment. Upon successful completion of this program, students will acquire the knowledge and skills to apply management, marketing, and accounting concepts to improve operational performance in a business setting. This degree can help an individual jump-start a career in business or prepare them for transfer to a four-year institution. The Business Program at Kauaâi Community College is offered 100% online, asynchronous. This means that Business Majors do not need to come to campus to take courses nor do they need to schedule a specific time to sit in on an online lecture. subcontent.text: UH Maui College Agriculture & Natural Resources Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Maui College Agriculture & Natural Resources Program Home AFNRM Ag & Natural Resources Program Description: The Agriculture and Natural Resources Program provides science-based instruction and hands-on skills training to work in a wide variety of sustainable âgreen industryâ jobs. An emphasis on entrepreneurship is included to prepare students to be a vibrant part of Hawaiiâs growing kamaâaina economy. Degree seeking students, students intending to transfer, as well as those interested in a few targeted courses for professional development are encouraged to be part of the program. There are three general academic tracks in the program: crop production, landscaping, and resource management. Students can work toward an Associate in Applied Science in Sustainable Tropical Crop Production or Horticulture and Landscape Maintenance; or work with the Program Coordinator to develop an Associate in Technical Studies in Cultural and Natural Resource Management. Farmer development training is condensed in a Certificate of Competence. These courses meet degree program requirements for the UH Maui College AAS in Agriculture & Natural Resources program. subcontent.text: HawaiÊ»i Community College TEAM Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us HawaiÊ»i Community College TEAM Program Home AFNRM TEAM Program Program Description: The Forest TEAM Program leads to a Certificate of Achievement (CA) and the Applied Science (AS) degree in Tropical Forest Ecosystem and Agroforestry Management . Students learn to actively manage threatened native forests and regenerate Hawai`i's native ecosystems. They learn how to grow native plants and establish agroforestry operations. Classes include training in the use of Global Positioning Systems (GPS), and Geographic Information Systems (GIS). Internships give students hands-on learning with potential employers such as the National Park Service, the US Forest Service, the Biological Resources Division of the US Geological Survey, the Hawai`i Department of Land and Natural Resources, the Nature Conservancy of Hawai`i, Kamehameha Schools, and members of the Hawai`i Forest Industry Association. Apply Now Contact Program Faculty Orlo Steele Faculty (808) 934-2623 orlo@hawaii.edu Contact Program Faculty Pamela Scheffler Faculty (808) 934-2622 pamelays@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply to HawaiÊ»i Community College Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Additional fees: $50 - $150 per semester Total number of credits: 62-65 Approximate total program tuition costs: ~ $8,322 - $9,115 Estimated program length (based on full time student status): 2 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the HawaiÊ»i Community CollegeÊ»s TEAM program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration.  Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: Students who complete the HawaiÊ»i Community Collegeâs TEAM Associateâs degree program can apply to 4-year university programs within the UH System. While there are no official program-to-program articulations, there are course articulations that facilitate credit transfers between campuses. For more information, please consult your advisor. These 60 credit programs provide clear, explicit, coherent pathways in biological and physical sciences for students intending to transfer into Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) majors, including those bachelor programs in the Agriculture, Ag Food Production, Animal Systems, Food Systems and Natural Resources Management Pathway maps. The program provides curricula that focus on basic science and mathematics as well as more advanced research and mentoring experiences. The degree provides students with undergraduate research opportunities as they move through STEM curricular pathways. Targeted advising and appropriate course sequencing enable the efficient transfer of STEM students. subcontent.text: UH Hilo Agriculture Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Agriculture Program Home AFNRM ASNS Programs Program Description: UH Hilo College of Agriculture, Forestry, and Natural Resources Management (CAFNRM) offers the Bachelor of Science degree (BS) in three areas of specialization: Animal Health and Management (which includes a pre-veterinary option) Aquaculture Tropical Agroecology Additionally, non-Agriculture majors can also pursue a Minor in Agriculture. To provide a well-balanced education, a good portion of a typical curriculum consists of College of Arts and Sciences courses as well as CAFNRM courses. CAFNRM also offers academic subject certificates for baccalaureate degree seeking students and non-degree seeking students: Beekeeping Certificate Equine Science Certificate Unmanned Aircraft Systems Certificate All CAFNRM students are invited to participate in the Agriculture Club. This is a student organization that promotes agriculture, food security and sustainability through education and service in the community. The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) projects strong employment opportunities for college graduates in the food, agricultural, and natural resources system in the United States. subcontent.title: UH System Transfer to Bachelor of Science Degree | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: UH System Transfer to Bachelor of Science Degree | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH System transfer to Bachelor of Science Degree Home AFNRM Transfer to BS Program Description: Transferring from a community college with an Associate of Science (A.S.) degree to a university to pursue a Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degree is a strategic step for students seeking to expand their academic and career opportunities. This pathway allows students to build a strong foundation in their chosen field while benefiting from smaller class sizes and lower tuition costs at the community college level. Upon transferring, students can take advantage of the specialized courses, research opportunities, and broader campus resources available at a university, ultimately positioning themselves for advanced roles in their chosen profession. WIthin the University of HawaiÊ»i System, there is an agreement allowing for general education courses to transfer seamlessly. Please consult with your HS or college advisor. subcontent.text: Natural Resources Management Admissions Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Natural Resources Management Admissions Requirements Home Pathways & Programs AFNRM Early College High school students aspiring to enter post-secondary programs in Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Management should focus on excelling in science courses such as biology, chemistry, and environmental science. Strong math skills are also important for data analysis and research. Participation in related extracurricular activities, such as 4-H clubs, FFA (Future Farmers of America), or environmental clubs, can provide valuable experience and enhance college applications. Gaining practical experience through internships, volunteer work, or part-time jobs in agriculture or conservation can further strengthen their preparation and demonstrate their commitment to the field. The basic admissions requirements can include: Course prerequisites: Some programs have specific prerequisite coursework that must be completed before applying. These prerequisites usually include general education requirements such as MATH 103 or BIOL 171, these will vary by program and campus (see campus program page for more details). GPA requirements: Some programs have minimum GPA requirements that students must meet with all prerequisite courses. These requirements can vary per campus. Application process: Certain programs will have a detailed set of application requirements such as submitting a written personal statement, and professional reference letters or interviewing with the program. Field or work experience: Having experience with agriculture through internships, part time jobs, work-based learning experiences or a students own social capital will give an advantage when applying for some programs. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges : To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to select an education program, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs associated with Food Systems: KapiÊ»olani Community College Windward Community College Leeward Community College Honolulu Community College KauaÊ»i Community College HawaiÊ»i Community College UH Maui College *University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa *University of HawaiÊ»i Hilo *University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu: For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map *Chaminade University of Honolulu: Cumulative high school GPA of 2.50 or higher High school students in dual enrollment or running start programs will need to submit official college transcripts Provide a written statement describing your interest in pursuing your degree at Chaminade University of Honolulu, and any related extracurricular activities that have prepared you for your educational goals. This statement must be a minimum of 250 words. Test Scores (Optional) *HawaiÊ»i Pacific University: HPU understands that each student has a unique academic history and individual talents. This is why HPU takes a holistic approach to reviewing applications, and considers all the information provided on your application to make an admissions decision. For more admissions information, please visit the HPU Admissions website . What is CONSIDERED: Grade Point Average - GPA SAT and/or ACT scores (or English Proficiency if educated outside of the US) Extracurricular activities Personal statement (essay) and/or resume Academic area of interest Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Natural Resources & Environmental Management Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Natural Resources & Environmental Management Program (NREM) Home AFNRM NREM Program Description: Welcome to the Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Management (NREM) at the University of Hawaii, Manoa. We are part of the College of Tropical Agriculture and Human Resources (CTAHR). Our department's focus is preparing students to be natural resources managers and professionals, with emphasis upon: Understanding the biophysical aspects of natural resources within a tropical island context Using the latest information, tools, and models to effectively manage these resources Discovering the real economic value of these resources and evaluating the costs and benefits of different management options Working with the community and stakeholders to implement practical solutions to their resource management challenges and concerns. Our program combines hands-on learning with the latest theories and concepts. Students choose between natural or social science pathways but take courses in both areas. An internship is required for all NREM students, offering real-world experience, professional networking, and guidance for academic and career planning. Students choose between: Natural Science Pathway Study the natural, physical, and biological aspects of managing natural resources and the environment. Specialize inâ¦ Plant Ecology, Conservation, and Management Soil and Water Conservation Watershed and Coastal Management Wildlife Ecology and Management Image and Data Science for NREM Social Science Pathway Study the social, cultural, and economic aspects of managing natural resources and the environment. Specialize inâ¦ Community and Cultural Resources Management Environmental Policy and Governance Sustainable Systems and Communities Apply Now Program Program Chair Dr. Travis Idol Program Chair (808) 956-7508 nremadv@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply and be accepted to UH Manoa Complete the general education requirements See program advisor for specific general education requirements for the NREM program. This course is the same as MATH 135 Precalculus at the University of HawaiÊ»i Community Colleges, NREM program requires MATH 203, MATH 134 is the prerequisite to MATH 203. *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Preparing for leadership in a complex, dynamic world necessitates new knowledge and skills. As an island, Maui is considered a 'closed system' and is therefore a natural living laboratory for observing successes and failures in sustainability pursuits. Sustainability science has emerged as one of the fastest-growing professions, with applications in a variety of fields and opportunities for meaningful work in the future. Join the Sustainable Science Management (SSM) program today! subcontent.text: AA Hawaiian Studies Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Agriculture: Graduate School Home Pathways and Programs AFNRM Graduate School Graduate School is an advanced level of academic study (MasterÊ»s degree, PhD or Doctoral degree, etc.) that follows the completion of an undergraduate degree (BachelorÊ»s degree). Graduate school is crucial for certain careers in the Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources industry, as it provides advanced knowledge, research skills, and specialized training that are essential for leadership roles and technical positions. For careers in agricultural research, environmental policy, food science, and natural resource management, a graduate degree can deepen expertise in areas like sustainable practices, biotechnologies, and ecosystem management. This level of education also opens doors to academic and research positions, high-level consultancy, and roles in governmental and international organizations, where advanced qualifications are often required to influence policy, drive innovation, and address complex challenges in the industry. For students considering applying to graduate school, here are five important factors to consider: Career Goals: Determine whether a graduate degree is necessary for your desired career path. Some careers in fields like academia, research, or specialized industry roles require advanced degrees, while others may not. Field of Study: Consider what specific area or discipline you want to focus on in graduate school. Graduate programs are highly specialized, so itâs important to have a clear understanding of your academic and professional interests. Program Requirements: Research the prerequisites for the graduate programs youâre interested in, including required coursework, standardized tests (like the GRE), and any relevant work or research experience. Make sure you meet these requirements or have a plan to do so. Financing: Think about how you will finance your graduate education. Consider tuition costs, availability of scholarships, assistantships, or grants, and whether youâll need to take out loans. Weigh the potential return on investment of a graduate degree in your field. Research potential scholarship opportunities. Time Commitment: Understand the time commitment involved in graduate school. Masterâs programs typically take 1-3 years, while doctoral programs can take 4-7 years or more. Consider how this fits into your long-term personal and professional plans. This use of immersion methodology at the tertiary level is highly distinctive, not only for HawaiÊ»i, but on a national level. The growth of the program is closely tied to its leadership role in reestablishing Hawaiian as the medium of education in preschools (1984) and in K-12 education (1986), as well as in establishing a teacher certification program (1998), masters of arts programs (1998), and a doctoral program (2006). The Hawaiian Studies program basically serves: Those majoring in Hawaiian Studies; Those pursuing a Certificate in Hawaiian Language, Hawaiian Culture, and/or Multidisciplinary Hawaiian Studies; Those pursuing a minor in Hawaiian Studies; and Those taking courses for their own interest and to fulfill University requirements. The program provides a unique educational opportunity for students interested in culture, economics, politics, sociology, linguistics, music, anthropology, biology, geography, history, and dance. subcontent.text: Chaminade University BS Environmental Science & BS Environmental Studies Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Chaminade University BS Environmental Science & BS Environmental Studies Programs Home AFNRM Environmental Science Program Description: B.S. Environmental Science : Climate change. Ecosystem degradation. The extinction of species. Our world is facing environmental threats unprecedented in the history of humanity â and needs professionals armed with the tools to not only understand environmental problems but how to address them. The multi-disciplinary approach in Chaminadeâs bachelorâs of science in Environmental Sciences offers just that. Building on a foundation of knowledge and using observation and research, students are challenged to consider environmental problems and their solutions from different perspectives, from a scientific lens to a legal, social or cultural one. B.S. Environmental Studies : Environmental studies and stewardship have a rich history in Hawaiiâknown both as an incredible location for biodiversity and unique ecosystems and as the âextinction capital of the planet.â Today, amid growing threats to our planet, the need for experts who are able to navigate the complex web of environmental issues and offer insight and solutions has never been higher. The Environmental Studies major prepares you for those rigors. Our program offers a multi-disciplinary approach, allowing you to analyze environmental problemsâand their potential responsesâthrough a variety of perspectives, including policy and law, science, economics, ethics and values and cultural sensitivity and awareness. Our students enjoy small class sizes, individualized instruction and attention, a number of hands-on opportunities and, perhaps most importantly of all, hands-on learning that can happen right in their own backyardâthe rich habitats that exist across the islands. Experiential Learning Students are invited to participate in numerous service-learning projects that benefit Hawaiiâs fragile ecosystems, as well as give experience in the field. Among many varied projects, students have been involved: Counting migratory whale populations Removing alien algae from the reef TPSS 351 Enterprise Management Assessing native plant populations Removing miconia (an invasive alien plant species) from Hawaii forest habitat Apply Now Program Contact Information Program Contact Information (808) 440-4204 hharakun@chaminade.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to Chaminade University Competition of pre-program courses Cost and time commitment: Starting in Fall 2023, Chaminade Universityâs HawaiÊ»i Guarantee provides local high school graduates entering as freshmen the same tuition rate as University of Hawaiâi at Manoaâs annual resident undergraduate tuition AND an achievable pathway to graduate in four years. subcontent.text: HawaiÊ»i Pacific University Environmental Science & Studies Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us HawaiÊ»i Pacific University Environmental Science & Studies Programs Home AFNRM Environmental Science Program Description: The challenges of today's environment -- air and water pollution, deforestation and species loss, peak oil consumption and climate change -- are complex and interconnected issues. The interdisciplinary fields of environmental science and environmental studies are both dedicated to the study of these critical problems with the aim of identifying feasible solutions. Environmental Science focuses on the study of natural systems and the application of technology to protect and improve the environment while Environmental Studies focuses on the interaction between human and natural systems and the connection between science and policy. Environmental and sustainability issues are overarching and complex; addressing these challenges requires a unique set of skills. Because of this, both majors utilize an interdisciplinary approach toward critical analysis and problem-solving while providing students with experience in the use of a wide range of tools. Students from both majors work together in many of the same upper division courses to foster respect for diverse perspectives and abilities and to build skills for working effectively within interdisciplinary teams. Which path is for me? Environmental Science (B.S.) The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) major is designed for those students with an interest in the more technical aspects of environmental systems. Students take a series of rigorous courses in chemistry, physics, biology, earth systems science, and mathematics. Upper level B.S. students can choose to follow a general environmental science track or complement their environmental science courses with a biology or chemistry concentration. Environmental Studies (B.A.) The Bachelor of Art (B.A.) major is designed for students with an interest in the policy and management aspects of environmental and sustainability issues. Coursework includes a foundation in environmental science. Students build upon that foundation with courses in economics, policy, communication, management, and ethics to gain a breadth of perspective for examining environmental and sustainability issues. This means that students in geography will acquire a true liberal arts education, while being able to develop specialization within one of the subfields of geography. Popular subfields are physical geography (climatology, biogeography, geomorphology), cultural geography (landscape analysis, resources management), and methods (quantitative methods, remote sensing, cartography, and GIS). The Island of HawaiÊ»i offers a setting of diverse natural and cultural environments ideal for geographic studies. Field excursions are an integral and enriching component of the studentâs geographic education at UH Hilo. Computer based spatial analysis, cartography, GIS, and remote sensing image processing contribute to a balanced and modern curriculum. In addition to the major in Geography , the department also offers a minor in Geography, and a Certificate in Planning. subcontent.text: UH Hilo Marine Science Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Marine Science Program Home AFNRM Marine Science Program Description: The Marine Science Department at UH Hilo has the resources to prepare the next generation of marine scientists. Located just 10 minutes from the shoreline and our research vessel, our students have access to HawaiÊ»i Islandâs unique variety of tropical marine environments all year long. Our Bachelorâs degrees in Marine Science have been carefully designed to provide students the opportunity to study the unique variety of marine environments found around the Island of HawaiÊ»i. We believe the best way to study the ocean is to be immersed in it. We prepare students to be innovative, successful life-long learners, and engaged stewards of the marine environment. The Marine Option Program (MOP) provides numerous field trips and experiences throughout the year. All faculty have active research programs, and we rely on undergraduates to participate as volunteers, employees, and project leaders on research projects. Students are encouraged to conduct their own research projects and can earn academic credit working on a MOP Project or a Senior Thesis. Opportunities exists to intern with our Boating Safety Program , Dive Safety Program , Analytical Lab , the HawaiÊ»i Cooperative Fishery Research Unit , as well as with local NGOs and federal and state agencies. subcontent.title: HawaiÊ»i Pacific University Marine Biology, Affairs and Oceanography Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: HawaiÊ»i Pacific University Marine Biology, Affairs and Oceanography Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us HawaiÊ»i Pacific University Marine Biology, Affairs and Oceanography Programs Home AFNRM Marine Science Program Description: B.S. Marine Biology: The study of life in the oceans - from microscopic plankton to the largest animals on earth, the blue whales. Like biology, marine biology has many, diverse fields of study contained within it including the study of the molecules within cells (molecular biology), the functions and adaptations of organisms (physiology), and populations of organisms and their interactions with each other and their environment (ecology). What unites these areas as marine biology is the saltwater environment, whether it be the coastal wetlands and estuaries, rocky shorelines and beaches, coral reefs and kelp forests, or the vast open-ocean habitat and abyssal sea. This biology draws on other sciences such as chemistry, physics, geology, and oceanography, and includes disciplines such as marine microbiology, phycology (the study of algae), marine toxicology, fisheries and aquaculture, deep-sea ecology, invertebrate zoology, ichthyology (the study of fish), marine mammalogy, and marine conservation biology. B.A. Marine Affairs: The Ocean needs scientific study, but it also needs skilled advocates trained in marine science to effect change in policy, law, business, and communications. The Bachelor of Arts in Marine Affairs is an interdisciplinary marine science degree that focuses on the fundamentals of marine science, the nature of the changing systems, sustainability of ocean resources, and social and environmental justice. Marine Affairs professionals are well prepared to advocate, educate, communicate, and liaise between the existing marine resource problems and the solutions that society can implement. Students in this major will be prepared to contribute to ocean advocacy in professional positions and/or could pursue advanced degrees in science, administration, policy, resource management, and/or law. Students further refine their career paths by selecting a minor in business, criminal justice, management, public administration, strategic communication, or sustainability. This program requires a research practicum or internship related to the studentâs desired specialization. B.S. Oceanography: Oceanography is the interdisciplinary study of the global oceans -- from shallow coastal areas to the deepest ocean trenches, from the tropics to the polar seas. It is usually divided into four sub-disciplines: Physical Oceanography â the study of waves, currents, tides, and ocean energy. Geological Oceanography â the study of the sediments, rocks, and structure of the seafloor and coastal margins. Chemical Oceanography â the study of the composition and properties of seawater and how it is affected by physical mixing processes and interactions with the seafloor, the atmosphere, and ocean life. Biological Oceanography â the study of marine organisms and their interactions with the ocean environment. All of these sub-disciplines are highly interrelated, as well as being closely aligned to other fields such as meteorology/atmospheric science, geophysics, and ocean engineering. As you might expect, biological oceanography shares many aspects with marine biology, but is generally more focused on the interactions of specific parameters within the marine environment -- paying particular attention to the affects of chemical, physical, or geographic properties of the ocean -- and marine organism distribution and/or the patterns of biological populations in the sea. HPUâs oceanography program includes all of the sub-disciplines of oceanography. subcontent.text: UH Hilo Environmental Science Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH Hilo Environmental Science Program Home AFNRM Environmental Science Program Description: Environmental Studies/Science is an overlap of many academic fields, such as biology, geology, chemistry, marine science, geography, anthropology, agriculture, political science, economics, and sociology. These degrees provide an innovative multidisciplinary approach for undergraduate students interested in a broad range of environmental topics while providing a strong foundation in major concepts in a variety of fields. In addition to the majors, the department also offers an Environment Studies Certificate . The Environmental Studies track of the Bachelor of Arts in Geography educates students for meaningful lifetime engagement with the major environmental challenges facing society. Students pursue an interdisciplinary curriculum that combines course work in both the natural sciences and social sciences. The degree prepares students for diverse career opportunities in the private sector, all levels of government, and in non-governmental organizations dealing with environmental policy and resources management. The Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science provides an interdisciplinary science concentration for students seeking careers in the fields of environmental consulting, research, and science teaching. In contrast to the BA option, the BS major in Environmental Science requires students to take a more structured core of natural science courses from a variety of disciplines. This degree also requires the student to select either a biological or physical science concentration within the major. Apply Now Contact Program Chair Kathryn Besio Program Chair (808) 932-7253 besio@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to UH Hilo Competition of General Education courses Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $306 Total number of credits 120 Approximate total program tuition costs: $36,720 Estimated program length: 4 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: While there are no official program-to-program articulations for the UH Hilo BS in Agriculture, there are course articulations that facilitate credit transfers between campuses. There is also a UH System wide transfer policy for general education classes. For more information, please consult your advisor or visit individual program pages. Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. Bachelor of Sciences (B.S.) in Earth Sciences The B.S. in Earth Sciences is a rigorous science degree for careers with a variety of companies, government agencies, and/or in research, including academia. Students may follow one of 6 areas of concentration: General Earth Science Environmental and Hydrology Geophysics and Tectonics Planetary Science Volcano Science Research Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) in Environmental Earth Science The B.A. in Environmental Earth Science has a more flexible curriculum for careers in teaching, industry or with government agencies. It includes an education track, in partnership with the College of Education to become certified to teach middle school and high school in Hawai'i. This degree offers slightly more flexibility to take courses in Atmospheric, Oceanographic, and Environmental Sciences. The curriculum, while well-rounded, emphasizes volcanology and environmental geology. Both laboratory and field activities are important components of the program, and students can expect to develop their descriptive, analytical, and interpretive skills. The bachelor of science (BS) degree in geology is a rigorous program that prepares students for graduate study or work as a professional geologist. The bachelor of arts (BA) degree is similar, but is intended for students interested in careers in science education or natural resource management. Minors in geology and earth-space science are available for students who wish to major in marine science, astronomy, geography, or natural science. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Global Environment Science Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Global Environment Science Program Home AFNRM Global Environment Program Description: The Bachelor of Science in Global Environmental Science (GES) program at the University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa (UHM) Department of Oceanography in the School of Ocean and Earth Science and Technology (SOEST) trains students to be knowledgeable in Earth-system science and think creatively about solving present and future challenges facing communities and natural resources. This BS program offers 3 tracks: Environmental Health Sciences - The Environmental Health Sciences track enables students in the Global Environmental Science Program to concentrate their academic studies in areas of significant importance in the relationship between environmental issues and public health. Environmental Planning - Global environmental problems like human-induced climate change challenge local strategies to manage natural resources, protect sensitive speciesâ habitats, and ensure the long-term health of ecosystems. Sustainability Science - Sustainability Science probes interactions between global, social, and human systems, the complex mechanisms that lead to degradation of these systems, and concomitant risks to human well-being. Each GES student performs faculty-mentored original research, writes a thesis, and presents their findings to the public. Faculty mentors include SOEST facultyâglobal leaders in the fields of ocean, earth, atmospheric, climate, and space sciencesâalong with other UHM faculty experts in natural resource management, coral reefs, water quality, marine biology, environmental planning, public health, environmental anthropology, and sustainability. Throughout the GES degree program, students are engaged in fieldwork, laboratory work, and field trips, and have access to deep ocean and coastal research vessels, and SOESTâs world-class Hawaiâi Institute of Marine Biology. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Biological Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Molecular Bioscience & Biotechnology Program Home AFNRM Molecular Program Description: The cutting-edge tools of molecular biology, genetics, cell biology, tissue culture, and biochemistry are transforming the environmental, medical, and agricultural sciences. In the field of biotechnology, these bioscience tools are harnessed to make products and solve problems faced by society. The biotechnology program emphasizes developing a strong foundation in the molecular and biochemical principles underpinning living cells (animals, microbes, and plants). The program combines hands-on laboratory research with courses covering various facets of molecular, cellular, and organismal biosciences (outlined below). The program facilitates excellence in biotechnology education by involving undergraduate students in rich interactions with faculty in both the classroom and research laboratories. MBB graduates have excellent job prospects upon graduation. Graduates are amply prepared to enter graduate studies in the biological, environmental, medical, and agricultural sciences and are profession-ready for job opportunities in industry (biomedical, health-care diagnostics, pharmaceutical, forensics, agricultural, environmental, and biotechnological) and in governmental research. With additional courses in education, the BS degree in MBB also qualifies graduates to teach at the elementary, middle, and high school levels. The MBBE faculty have a commitment to and passion for teaching, combined with renowned research expertise in their chosen disciplines. The faculty provide independent research experiences for undergraduate students (as MBBE 499), and many have well-funded research programs utilizing state-of-the art equipment and techniques. On-campus research facilities that students can use to enhance their education and research experience include the Biological Electron Microscope Facility; the Greenwood Molecular Biology Facility; and the Center for Advanced Studies in Genomics, Proteomics and Bioinformatics. Graduates have accepted engineering positions such as designing process equipment and systems for biological production and treatment, or implementing site preparation for construction or bioremediation of environmental contamination. They are prepared to help engineer systems to develop renewable sources of energy, and to improve the value of natural products produced in Hawaii for food and therapeutic applications. Increasing numbers of graduates from BE are meeting demands from growing biotech industries in Hawaii, for example for the production of systems for culturing human tissues for medical replacement and for screening, extracting, and producing antibiotics and other pharmaceutical compounds from Hawaii's unique natural biota. Many Bioengineers are employed with forward thinking institutions like NASA that are interested in engineering self-sustaining habitable environments in space as well as on Earth.
