subcontent.text: UH West Oâahu Respiratory Care | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Respiratory Care Program Home Health Services Respiratory Care Program Description: Respiratory Care involves the treatment of those with asthma, cystic fibrosis, bronchiolitis, lung injury, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and other respiratory-related ailments. Those trained in the field evaluate, treat, monitor and aid in the prevention of many breathing disorders. Kapiâolani Community College is one of many accredited two-year Respiratory Therapy programs across the nation and the only program in the state. Through programs like these, students learn the technical training needed to work in the field and are well-prepared to earn the credentials of a Certified and Registered Respiratory Therapist. UH West Oâahuâs Bachelor of Applied Science degree, with a concentration in Respiratory Care , is designed to supplement the technical training that a student receives in an accredited associate degree Respiratory Therapy program. Students develop job skills that are needed to excel in the industry, such as critical thinking and communication skills. The program also exposes students to the historical, cultural, and social context of the profession. In addition, courses in research and contemporary health care issues expand the depth in the studentsâ applied health sciences knowledge base. UH West Oâahu courses are delivered both in-class and through distance learning instruction. Apply Now Program Contact Dr. Ricardo Custodio Professor Program Contact (808) 689-2327 ricardo8@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Kapiolani Community College, Associate's in Science Degree - Respiratory Care Practitioner Admission to University of HawaiÊ»i West OÊ»ahu *See Articulation Agreement below for transfer student requirements Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $306 Additional fees: Up to $130 per semester Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total UH West OÊ»ahu PUBA program tuition costs: ~$37,760 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status) PUBA program courses and prerequisite courses: 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the UH West OÊ»ahu RESP program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree pre-program requirements for the UH West OÊ»ahu RESP program. RESP program Prerequisite Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in ENG 22 OR Placement into ENG 100 MATH 103: College Algebra *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in MATH 82, OR placement into MATH 103 HWST 107: Hawaiian Piko *Prerequisite: None PSY 100: *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100 AND MATH 82 HLTH 125: Survey of Medical Terminology *Prerequisite: None MICRO 130: General Microbiology *Prerequisite: None *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: The UH West OÊ»ahu BAS: Concentration in respiratory care (RESP) offers working professionals who have earned the Associate in Science (A.S.) degree in respiratory care at Kapiâolani Community College (KCC) the opportunity to earn a baccalaureate degree and to continue for advanced education in respiratory care. The additional requirements in the liberal arts and sciences will contribute to increasing academic skills development, advancing knowledge, attaining career goals, and meeting the needs of the health care community in the areas of leadership, clinical practice, research and education. University of HawaiÊ»i West OÊ»ahu Bachelors in Applied Science - Respiratory Care Program ( Articulation Agreement - Fall 2021 ) Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. text: Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing Systems | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing Systems Home Pathways and Programs Building & Construction RCC MEPS Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing Systems Pathway Map to Employment Careers in Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) focus on the essential systems that power, heat, cool, and provide water to buildings and infrastructure. Professionals in this field design, install, and maintain mechanical systems like HVAC (heating, ventilation, and air conditioning), electrical wiring and lighting, and plumbing for water and waste systems. Entry-level roles include apprenticeships and technician positions, while advanced careers, such as engineers or MEP project managers, require specialized training and certifications. These roles are vital to ensuring safety, efficiency, and sustainability in residential, commercial, and industrial structures. Students in the Mechanical, Electrical, & Plumbing program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into this field with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities to help them understand the current landscape of this industry. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the Mechanical, Electrical, & Plumbing program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore the industry through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in Mechanical, Electrical, & Plumbing may require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training might be required, you may also be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview: The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey: If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement: As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. subcontent.text:
Mechanical, Electrical, & Plumbing Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Mechanical, Electrical, & Plumbing
			    ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi For entry-level positions in the Mechanical, Electrical, & Plumbing industry, several industry-related credentials can enhance your qualifications and demonstrate foundational knowledge and skills. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. The following are some NON-CREDIT (not related to college) programs you can take that will help you in your career journey. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for Building & Construction related careers: OSHA 10 For Construction - The OSHA 10-Hour Construction training is a key requirement for many entry-level craftsmen positions either for union and non-union construction jobs. This training educates workers on hazard recognition and OSHA safety standards. Participants gain knowledge of workplace and job site safety, including hazard avoidance, workersâ rights, and how to file an OSHA complaint. Upon completion, workers receive a 10-hour card, demonstrating their understanding of OSHA standards and commitment to maintaining a safe work environment. This comprehensive training provides an essential foundation for safety and compliance in the construction industry. Range of training duration: 10 hours Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for construction professionals. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours OSHA Fall Prevention and Prevention Certification: Falls are the leading cause of construction accidents and traumatic occupational death according to the U.S. Department of Labor. As a result, workers are required to complete fall protection training when working at a height of 6-feet or higher, or when a worker might be exposed to fall hazards. This 1-hour course satisfies the training and retraining requirements for OSHA 29 CFR 1926 Subpart M Fall Protection Standard, Including Residential Construction Fall Protection. Range of program duration: 1-2 Hours Forklift Operator Certification: Forklifts, also known as powered industrial trucks, are vital tools used to lift and transport cargo in construction and a variety of other industries. OSHA requires employers to ensure that all operators are forklift certified through formal instruction, practical training and a performance evaluation. The forklift certification course fully complies with OSHA's general industry and construction standards for forklift operator training. Throughout the two-hour course, you'll learn about all formal instruction topics needed to earn a forklift license and safely operate Class I â Class VII forklifts. Range of program duration: 2 Hours These training programs can lead to the following entry level Jobs: Construction Laborer Forklift operator Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. Hawaii Career Pathways builds bridges between schools and industries so students can get training and education for high-skill, high-wage professions. subcontent.text: Honolulu Community College Architecture, Engineering & Construction Technologies Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Architecture, Engineering & Construction Technologies Program Home Building and Construction RCC HCC AEC Program Description: The Architecture, Engineering and Construction Technologies (AEC) program is designed to prepare students for immediate employment as architectural or engineering drawing technicians, or construction management interns. It also prepares in-service professionals for employment upgrading. Some students also use the program to prepare for employment in building construction, interior design drawing, kitchen and bath design, solar energy planning, construction estimating, land surveying, and various other fields. If you are interested in using the program as a step on the way to a bachelorâs degree in architecture or engineering, please see a Honolulu Academic Counselor. Incoming students choose either an architectural technology track, or a construction management track. More than 70 percent of the courses are shared by the two tracks, either track is appropriate for students who are also interested in engineering technology. 3D printing and scanning and other advanced technology activities are also part of the program. The program leads to an Associate in Science degree, and there is a shorter Certificate of Achievement available for students with special non-degree objectives. Both degree and certificate students must earn a grade of âCâ or higher in all required AEC, MATH & ENG courses. Students are required to have access to a "newer" desktop or laptop computer running a Windows operating system. Systems running IOS (Apple/Mac) will not be compatible with the program software needs unless the system has the capability of using Windows as an alternate operating system. Students will also be required to have a working camera and microphone for courses that have an online meeting component. A minimum 17-inch screen on laptops to complete assigned drawings and other projects outside of class is highly recommended. 27-inch desktop screens are preferable. Refer to the Autodesk.com website for system/ hardware minimum requirements. New students are required to attend an AEC orientation session. There is also a requirement of 20 hours of AEC-related school and community service apart from coursework before completion of the program. Program Offerings: Associates of Science (AS), Architecture Technologies Focus, 62 Credits Associates of Science (AS), Construction Management Focus, 62 Credits Certificate of Achievement (CA), Architecture Technologie Focus, 33 Credits Certificate of Achievement (CA), Construction Management Focus, 33 Credits Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Norman Takeya Program Coordinator (808) 844-2376 ntakeya@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Drake Zintgraff Program Counselor (808) 845-9218 drakez@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for Honolulu Community College Placement into ENG 100 Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits: 62 Approximate total program tuition costs: $8,122 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the Honolulu Community College AEC program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100 SP 251: Principles of Effective Public Speaking *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100 *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. From building our nationâs infrastructure to making our transportation and energy systems more efficient, wherever scientists and engineers are found, so are engineering technicians and technologists. Engineering techs may assist with setting up equipment, conducting experiments, and collecting data, or involved in the design and development end of the process, using computer-aided design and drafting (CADD) equipment. Students will also gain knowledge in data gathering methodologies including remote sensing systems, optics and GIS technology. This prepares you for the State of Hawai'i Maintenance Electrician License test. Electrical Keeps Kaua'i Running Electricity is essential, yet invisible. Imagine life without it! The EIMT program helps you become part of the island's electrical workforce (one of six key professions): Linemen & Utility Engineers: Install & maintain power lines. Journey-Person Electricians: Install electrical systems in buildings. Security & Telecom Technicians: Install low-voltage systems. Residential Wiremen: Install electrical systems in homes. Solar Installation Technicians: Install solar power systems. Maintenance Electricians: Maintain electrical systems. Want to join them? The EIMT program is your first step. We also offer individual certificates for specific electrical skills, like solar energy system installation or industrial motor controls. Program Offerings: Associate of Applied Science (AAS), Electrical Installation and Maintenance Technology, 62 Credits Certificate of Achievement (CA), Electrical Installation and Maintenance Technology, 47 Credits Certificate of Competence (CO), Electrical Installation Maintenance Technology, 18 Credits Certificate of Competence (CO), Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing, 21 Credits Certificate of Competence (CO), Solar Energy Technology Technician, 15 Credits Apply Now Contact Program Counselor John Constantino Program Counselor (808) 245-0112 johncons@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for KauaÊ»i Community College Qualify fo ENG 106 Qualify for MATH 82X Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 62 Approximate total program tuition costs: $8,122 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. An open-exit option allows the students to identify their career objectives and participate in program exploration. The curriculum is designed to prepare students with entry level knowledge and manipulative skills for employment in the electrical industry. The program combines theory with laboratory activities as an effective means of developing the skills essential to the electrical trade. The student begins with the fundamentals of electricity and wiring of simple circuits, then progresses to residential interior wiring, three phase alternating current power, and wiring of more complex circuits and equipment. Safety is stressed as an integral part of each shop task. Emphasis is placed on wiring in accordance with the provisions contained in the National Electrical Code. Program Offerings: Associates of Applied Science (AAS), EIMT, 62 Credits Certificate of Achievement (CA), EIMT, 47 Credits Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Louis Maghanoy Program Coordinator (808) 845-9476 louismag@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Jill Teraizumi Program Counselor (808) 845-9228 koidej@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for Honolulu Community College MATH 50, or placement into MATH 150 or higher. subcontent.text: Mechanical, Electrical & Plumbing (MEP) Programs Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Mechanical, Electrical & Plumbing (MEP) Programs Admission Requirements Home Pathways & Programs Admission Requirements High school students interested in the mechanical, electrical & plumbing industry should take advantage of opportunities to build relevant skills, gain experience, and explore career pathways while still in high school. Take Relevant High School Courses: Building & Construction pathway courses Gain Hands-On Experiences: Internship, shadowing or volunteering Earn Entry Level Certifications: OSHA 10 Dual Credit Opportunities: Take Early College courses Explore your Social Capital: Talk to your family and friends who are working or have worked in the construction industry. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to select an education program, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs associated with RCC: KapiÊ»olani Community College Windward Community College Leeward Community College Honolulu Community College KauaÊ»i Community College HawaiÊ»i Community College UH Maui College * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map *HawaiÊ»i Pacific University: HPU understands that each student has a unique academic history and individual talents. This is why HPU takes a holistic approach to reviewing applications, and considers all the information provided on your application to make an admissions decision. For more admissions information, please visit the HPU Admissions website . Employment may be in construction, food processing, manufacturing, utilities, astronomical observatories, or related industries. The job requires good physical health, above average eye/hand coordination, mechanical reasoning, and good form perception and spatial relationship. Job responsibilities may include fabricating, repairing, or maintaining metal products on equipment, buildings, and systems. The concentration provides students with technical and managerial skills to implement comprehensive sustainable operations and maintenance of facilities management systems. This concentration prepares students for professional positions within a wide variety of technically advanced building and infrastructure sectors such as military, municipal, industrial, retail, commercial, resort, hospital. Ultimately, the concentration develops facilities professionals who are capable of solving real-world problems to transition existing and future Hawaiâi building and critical infrastructure systems toward greater efficiency and effectiveness. subcontent.text: UH MÄnoa Mechanical Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Mechanical Engineering (BS) Program Home Building and Construction RCC Mechanical Engineering Program Description: The Department of Mechanical Engineering offers a Bachelor of Science degree in Mechanical Engineering (BS ME) . This degree requires completion of at least 121 credit hours of coursework. The curriculum consists of a group of required courses chosen to provide the students with the basic tools for the professional practice of mechanical engineering and to assist students in developing a sense of responsibility as professionals. The objectives of the lower division curriculum are to build a foundation in the basic sciences and mathematics, provide an introduction to engineering design and professional ethics, develop communications and computer programming skills, and acquire an appreciation for the humanities and social sciences. The objectives of the upper division program are to provide a sound foundation in the engineering sciences; build on that foundation for applications in the areas of energy conversion, mechanical systems and control, experimentation, and manufacturing; and encourage creativity culminating in a capstone design experience. To provide sufficient flexibility, technical elective courses enable students to acquire additional competence in areas compatible with their career objectives. All electives are subject to the approval of an adviser. Apply Now Program Prerequisites: Admission to UH MÄnoa Competition of General Education courses Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $441 Total number of credits: 121 Approximate total program tuition costs: $53,361 Estimated program length: 4 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the UH Manoa BS in Mechanical Engineering program. subcontent.text: Honolulu Community College Welding Technology Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Welding Technology Program Home Building and Construction RCC HCC Welding Technology Program Description: The Welding Technology (WELD) programâs mission is to serve the community as a learning-centered, open door program that provides technical training to meet the demands of the welding industry and the needs of the individual. An open-exit option allows the students to identify their career objectives and participate in program exploration. The Welding curriculum is designed to meet the minimum skill standards established by the American Welding Society (AWS) for entry-level welders. Training is given in both theory and practical skills in the various phases of welding and cutting. This includes arc welding, plasma and air carbon arc cutting, oxyacetylene welding, TIG welding, MIG welding, gas metal and flux core arc welding, welding inspecting testing principles and fabrication techniques. Entry-level welders are employed in a wide range of industries that use welding and welding-related tasks. This range of industries includes small, medium, and large union and non-union facilities. Students have the option of pursuing a Certificate of Achievement or Associate of Applied Science degree. Program Offerings: Associates of Applied Science (AAS), Welding Technology, 63-64 Credits Certificate of Achievement (CA), Welding Technology, 26 Credits Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Jeff Schultz Program Coordinator (808) 845-9486 jeff8@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Jill Teraizumi Program Counselor (808) 845-9228 koidej@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for Honolulu Community College Placement into ENG 100; MATH 50 or placement into MATH 150 or higher Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits: 63-64 Approximate total program tuition costs: $8,253 - $8,384 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. An open-exit option allows the students to identify their career objectives and participate in program exploration. The Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Program prepares students for employment as technicians in the design, operation, service, repair, installation and sales of these systems and equipment. The program combines theory with extensive practical hands-on training designed to simulate the actual work environment and skills needed to excel in this challenging field. Labs afford the student the opportunity to install, repair, and/or operate actual field equipment, such as commercial package and split system A/C; liquid chillers; commercial ice machines; and domestic equipment. subcontent.title: HPU Electrical Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: HPU Electrical Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Electrical Engineering Program Home Building and Construction RCC Electrical Program Description: The Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering degree at HPU involves the application of engineering principles to electrical systems and devices for purposes of diagnostics, maintenance, innovation or design, development, testing and commissioning with core expertise in electrical circuits, signals and systems, control and microcontroller systems, electronics, digital hardware, communications technology, embedded systems, and power. Students apply fundamentals in topics of electricity, electromagnetism, and electronics to proceed toward specialization in advanced topics, such as computer architecture, network engineering, renewable energy, robotics and automation, intelligent control, image and audio processing, and modeling of engineering process-based systems. The program offers students a concentration in Engineering Sustainability. Additionally, students have an option to undertake a Thesis and one extra semester of study to attain a Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering with Honors. Graduates can find employment in a wide variety of industries such as heavy industry and manufacturing, government roles, consultancy firms in engineering and business, instrumentation, aviation, robotics, building and construction, healthcare, hospitality, military, and many other areas.Communications while providing students the flexibility to tailor their degree to fit their career interests. Electrical Engineering is a profession concerned with the design of electrical, electronic, and electro-magnetic systems. Sub-disciplines within this profession include biomedical engineering. bioengineering, electronic circuits, computers, lasers and optics, networks, signal and image processing, solid-state devices, and telecommunications. Electrical engineers design and build fiber-optic communication, memory chips, solar cells, compact disk players, television, cell phones, laptop computers, Internet routers, stereo components, robots, radio, modern aircraft control, electrical power plants, flat panel displays, electric and hybrid cars, biomedical equipment, portable media players, and air traffic control radar. Much of "high technology" is designed and built by electrical engineers. subcontent.text: UH MÄnoa Construction Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Construction Engineering (BS) Program Home Building and Construction RCC Construction Engineering Program Description: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CECE) focuses on the activities of people and their interaction with the environment. The civil engineer conceives, plans, designs, constructs, operates, and maintains buildings, bridges, highways, airports, railways, tunnels, waterways ports and harbors, dams, water supply and wastewater treatment systems, and earthworks. Important considerations of the civil engineer in providing infrastructure and buildings is improved health and safety for people, minimized impact to the environment, sensitivity to costs and resources, and overall sustainability. Civil engineering continuously improves its methods and each new or upgraded component improves the standard of living for large populations. The cities we live in and most of their vital infrastructure are the creation of civil engineers. Our undergraduate program, leading to the Bachelor of Science in Construction Engineering Degree (B.S.CNST) , is collecting the data necessary in order to apply to be accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org in 2021. The B.S.CNST degree requires at least 124 credit hours of coursework and it is designed to be completed in eight semesters. The curriculum provides a broad-based background of fundamentals, including humanities and social sciences, basic sciences, mathematics, and engineering construction. Course requirements also include 57 credit hours of civil and construction engineering courses from the following areas: applied mechanics, structural analysis, hydraulics, surveying, transportation, soil mechanics, and construction engineering. The undergraduate experience culminates in a senior capstone course in which students apply the knowledge they have gained throughout their undergraduate coursework toward the planning and design of a comprehensive construction project. text: Residential & Commercial Construction | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Residential & Commercial Construction Home Pathways and Programs Building & Construction Residential & Commercial Construction Residential & Commercial Construction Pathway Map to Employment Careers in residential and commercial construction offer diverse opportunities to work in building and infrastructure development, ranging from homes and apartment complexes to office buildings and retail spaces. Professionals in this field can specialize in areas like carpentry, plumbing, electrical work, masonry, or project management. Entry-level roles, such as construction laborers or apprentices, provide hands-on experience, while advanced positions, such as contractors, architects, or site supervisors, require additional education or certifications. These careers combine technical skills with problem-solving and teamwork to create functional and sustainable structures for communities. Students in the Residential and Commercial Construction program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into this field with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities to help them understand the current landscape of this industry. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the Residential and Commercial Construction program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore the industry through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in Residential and Commercial Construction may require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training might be required, you may also be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview: The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey: If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement: As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text:
Residential and Commercial Construction Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Residential and Commercial Construction
			    ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi For entry-level positions in the residential and commercial construction industry, several industry-related credentials can enhance your qualifications and demonstrate foundational knowledge and skills. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. The following are some NON-CREDIT (not related to college) programs you can take that will help you in your career journey. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for Building & Construction related careers: OSHA 10 For Construction - The OSHA 10-Hour Construction training is a key requirement for many entry-level craftsmen positions either for union and non-union construction jobs. This training educates workers on hazard recognition and OSHA safety standards. Participants gain knowledge of workplace and job site safety, including hazard avoidance, workersâ rights, and how to file an OSHA complaint. Upon completion, workers receive a 10-hour card, demonstrating their understanding of OSHA standards and commitment to maintaining a safe work environment. This comprehensive training provides an essential foundation for safety and compliance in the construction industry. Range of training duration: 10 hours Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for construction professionals. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours OSHA Fall Prevention and Prevention Certification: Falls are the leading cause of construction accidents and traumatic occupational death according to the U.S. Department of Labor. As a result, workers are required to complete fall protection training when working at a height of 6-feet or higher, or when a worker might be exposed to fall hazards. This 1-hour course satisfies the training and retraining requirements for OSHA 29 CFR 1926 Subpart M Fall Protection Standard, Including Residential Construction Fall Protection. Range of program duration: 1-2 Hours Forklift Operator Certification: Forklifts, also known as powered industrial trucks, are vital tools used to lift and transport cargo in construction and a variety of other industries. OSHA requires employers to ensure that all operators are forklift certified through formal instruction, practical training and a performance evaluation.  The forklift certification course fully complies with OSHA's general industry and construction standards for forklift operator training. Throughout the two-hour course, you'll learn about all formal instruction topics needed to earn a forklift license and safely operate Class I â Class VII forklifts. Range of program duration: 2 Hours Forklift Operator Certification: Forklifts, also known as powered industrial trucks, are vital tools used to lift and transport cargo in construction and a variety of other industries. OSHA requires employers to ensure that all operators are forklift certified through formal instruction, practical training and a performance evaluation.  The forklift certification course fully complies with OSHA's general industry and construction standards for forklift operator training. Throughout the two-hour course, you'll learn about all formal instruction topics needed to earn a forklift license and safely operate Class I â Class VII forklifts. Range of program duration: 2 Hours Scissor Lift Certification: Aerial and scissor lifts play an important role in construction and many other industries. These versatile lifts come in several types with various applications and operating hazards. This course will teach you how to maximize worksite safety while working on or around aerial and scissor lifts.  Only trained persons may operate aerial lifts and scissor lifts. This awareness-level certificate course complies with training requirements for aerial lifts and related scaffolding equipment found in OSHA standard 1926.454. It does not provide an OSHA-accepted certification or certification card. Range of program duration: 2 Hours These training programs can lead to the following entry level Jobs: Construction Laborer Truck Driver Warehouse Laborer Truck Driver Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Honolulu Community College Architecture, Engineering & Construction Technologies Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Architecture, Engineering & Construction Technologies Program Home Building and Construction RCC HCC AEC Program Description: The Architecture, Engineering and Construction Technologies (AEC) program is designed to prepare students for immediate employment as architectural or engineering drawing technicians, or construction management interns. It also prepares in-service professionals for employment upgrading. Some students also use the program to prepare for employment in building construction, interior design drawing, kitchen and bath design, solar energy planning, construction estimating, land surveying, and various other fields. If you are interested in using the program as a step on the way to a bachelorâs degree in architecture or engineering, please see a Honolulu Academic Counselor. Incoming students choose either an architectural technology track, or a construction management track. More than 70 percent of the courses are shared by the two tracks, either track is appropriate for students who are also interested in engineering technology. 3D printing and scanning and other advanced technology activities are also part of the program. The program leads to an Associate in Science degree, and there is a shorter Certificate of Achievement available for students with special non-degree objectives. Both degree and certificate students must earn a grade of âCâ or higher in all required AEC, MATH & ENG courses. Students are required to have access to a "newer" desktop or laptop computer running a Windows operating system. Systems running IOS (Apple/Mac) will not be compatible with the program software needs unless the system has the capability of using Windows as an alternate operating system. Students will also be required to have a working camera and microphone for courses that have an online meeting component. A minimum 17-inch screen on laptops to complete assigned drawings and other projects outside of class is highly recommended. 27-inch desktop screens are preferable. Refer to the Autodesk.com website for system/ hardware minimum requirements. New students are required to attend an AEC orientation session. There is also a requirement of 20 hours of AEC-related school and community service apart from coursework before completion of the program. From building our nationâs infrastructure to making our transportation and energy systems more efficient, wherever scientists and engineers are found, so are engineering technicians and technologists. Engineering techs may assist with setting up equipment, conducting experiments, and collecting data, or involved in the design and development end of the process, using computer-aided design and drafting (CADD) equipment. Students will also gain knowledge in data gathering methodologies including remote sensing systems, optics and GIS technology. subcontent.text: Kauaâi Community College Electrical Installation & Maintenance Technology Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Electrical Installation & Maintenance Technology Program Home Building and Construction RCC Kauaâi CC Carpentry Program Description: The EIMT program equips you for entry-level electrician jobs with the technical knowledge and hands-on skills to meet industry standards (National Electrical Code & energy conservation codes). This prepares you for the State of Hawai'i Maintenance Electrician License test. Electrical Keeps Kaua'i Running Electricity is essential, yet invisible. Imagine life without it! The EIMT program helps you become part of the island's electrical workforce (one of six key professions): Linemen & Utility Engineers: Install & maintain power lines. Journey-Person Electricians: Install electrical systems in buildings. Security & Telecom Technicians: Install low-voltage systems. Residential Wiremen: Install electrical systems in homes. Solar Installation Technicians: Install solar power systems. Maintenance Electricians: Maintain electrical systems. Want to join them? The EIMT program is your first step. We also offer individual certificates for specific electrical skills, like solar energy system installation or industrial motor controls. An open-exit option allows the students to identify their career objectives and participate in program exploration. The curriculum is designed to prepare students with entry level knowledge and manipulative skills for employment in the electrical industry. The program combines theory with laboratory activities as an effective means of developing the skills essential to the electrical trade. The student begins with the fundamentals of electricity and wiring of simple circuits, then progresses to residential interior wiring, three phase alternating current power, and wiring of more complex circuits and equipment. Safety is stressed as an integral part of each shop task. Emphasis is placed on wiring in accordance with the provisions contained in the National Electrical Code. Program Offerings: Associates of Applied Science (AAS), EIMT, 62 Credits Certificate of Achievement (CA), EIMT, 47 Credits Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Louis Maghanoy Program Coordinator (808) 845-9476 louismag@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Jill Teraizumi Program Counselor (808) 845-9228 koidej@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for Honolulu Community College MATH 50, or placement into MATH 150 or higher. subcontent.text: Residential, Commercial Construction (RCC) Programs Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Residential, Commercial Construction Programs Admission Requirements Home Pathways & Programs Admission Requirements High school students interested in the residential and commercial construction industry should take advantage of opportunities to build relevant skills, gain experience, and explore career pathways while still in high school. Take Relevant High School Courses: Building & Construction pathway courses Gain Hands-On Experiences: Internship, shadowing or volunteering Earn Entry Level Certifications: OSHA 10 Dual Credit Opportunities: Take Early College courses Explore your Social Capital: Talk to your family and friends who are working or have worked in the construction industry. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to select an education program, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs associated with RCC: KapiÊ»olani Community College Windward Community College Leeward Community College Honolulu Community College KauaÊ»i Community College HawaiÊ»i Community College UH Maui College * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map *HawaiÊ»i Pacific University: HPU understands that each student has a unique academic history and individual talents. This is why HPU takes a holistic approach to reviewing applications, and considers all the information provided on your application to make an admissions decision. For more admissions information, please visit the HPU Admissions website . An open-exit option allows the students to identify their career objectives and participate in program exploration. The Welding curriculum is designed to meet the minimum skill standards established by the American Welding Society (AWS) for entry-level welders. Training is given in both theory and practical skills in the various phases of welding and cutting. This includes arc welding, plasma and air carbon arc cutting, oxyacetylene welding, TIG welding, MIG welding, gas metal and flux core arc welding, welding inspecting testing principles and fabrication techniques. Entry-level welders are employed in a wide range of industries that use welding and welding-related tasks. This range of industries includes small, medium, and large union and non-union facilities. Students have the option of pursuing a Certificate of Achievement or Associate of Applied Science degree. Electrical Engineering is a profession concerned with the design of electrical, electronic, and electro-magnetic systems. Sub-disciplines within this profession include biomedical engineering. bioengineering, electronic circuits, computers, lasers and optics, networks, signal and image processing, solid-state devices, and telecommunications. Electrical engineers design and build fiber-optic communication, memory chips, solar cells, compact disk players, television, cell phones, laptop computers, Internet routers, stereo components, robots, radio, modern aircraft control, electrical power plants, flat panel displays, electric and hybrid cars, biomedical equipment, portable media players, and air traffic control radar. Much of "high technology" is designed and built by electrical engineers. subcontent.text: UH MÄnoa Construction Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Construction Engineering (BS) Program Home Building and Construction RCC Construction Engineering Program Description: Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CECE) focuses on the activities of people and their interaction with the environment. The civil engineer conceives, plans, designs, constructs, operates, and maintains buildings, bridges, highways, airports, railways, tunnels, waterways ports and harbors, dams, water supply and wastewater treatment systems, and earthworks. Important considerations of the civil engineer in providing infrastructure and buildings is improved health and safety for people, minimized impact to the environment, sensitivity to costs and resources, and overall sustainability. Civil engineering continuously improves its methods and each new or upgraded component improves the standard of living for large populations. The cities we live in and most of their vital infrastructure are the creation of civil engineers. Our undergraduate program, leading to the Bachelor of Science in Construction Engineering Degree (B.S.CNST) , is collecting the data necessary in order to apply to be accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org in 2021. The B.S.CNST degree requires at least 124 credit hours of coursework and it is designed to be completed in eight semesters. The curriculum provides a broad-based background of fundamentals, including humanities and social sciences, basic sciences, mathematics, and engineering construction. Course requirements also include 57 credit hours of civil and construction engineering courses from the following areas: applied mechanics, structural analysis, hydraulics, surveying, transportation, soil mechanics, and construction engineering. The undergraduate experience culminates in a senior capstone course in which students apply the knowledge they have gained throughout their undergraduate coursework toward the planning and design of a comprehensive construction project. subcontent.text: HPU Electrical Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Electrical Engineering Program Home Building and Construction RCC Electrical Program Description: The Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering degree at HPU involves the application of engineering principles to electrical systems and devices for purposes of diagnostics, maintenance, innovation or design, development, testing and commissioning with core expertise in electrical circuits, signals and systems, control and microcontroller systems, electronics, digital hardware, communications technology, embedded systems, and power. Students apply fundamentals in topics of electricity, electromagnetism, and electronics to proceed toward specialization in advanced topics, such as computer architecture, network engineering, renewable energy, robotics and automation, intelligent control, image and audio processing, and modeling of engineering process-based systems. The program offers students a concentration in Engineering Sustainability. Additionally, students have an option to undertake a Thesis and one extra semester of study to attain a Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering with Honors. Graduates can find employment in a wide variety of industries such as heavy industry and manufacturing, government roles, consultancy firms in engineering and business, instrumentation, aviation, robotics, building and construction, healthcare, hospitality, military, and many other areas.Communications while providing students the flexibility to tailor their degree to fit their career interests. subcontent.text: UH West Oâahu Respiratory Care | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Respiratory Care Program Home Health Services Respiratory Care Program Description: Respiratory Care involves the treatment of those with asthma, cystic fibrosis, bronchiolitis, lung injury, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and other respiratory-related ailments. Those trained in the field evaluate, treat, monitor and aid in the prevention of many breathing disorders. Kapiâolani Community College is one of many accredited two-year Respiratory Therapy programs across the nation and the only program in the state. Through programs like these, students learn the technical training needed to work in the field and are well-prepared to earn the credentials of a Certified and Registered Respiratory Therapist. UH West Oâahuâs Bachelor of Applied Science degree, with a concentration in Respiratory Care , is designed to supplement the technical training that a student receives in an accredited associate degree Respiratory Therapy program. Students develop job skills that are needed to excel in the industry, such as critical thinking and communication skills. The program also exposes students to the historical, cultural, and social context of the profession. In addition, courses in research and contemporary health care issues expand the depth in the studentsâ applied health sciences knowledge base. UH West Oâahu courses are delivered both in-class and through distance learning instruction. Apply Now Program Contact Dr. Ricardo Custodio Professor Program Contact (808) 689-2327 ricardo8@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Kapiolani Community College, Associate's in Science Degree - Respiratory Care Practitioner Admission to University of HawaiÊ»i West OÊ»ahu *See Articulation Agreement below for transfer student requirements Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $306 Additional fees: Up to $130 per semester Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total UH West OÊ»ahu PUBA program tuition costs: ~$37,760 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status) PUBA program courses and prerequisite courses: 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the UH West OÊ»ahu RESP program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: The UH West OÊ»ahu BAS: Concentration in respiratory care (RESP) offers working professionals who have earned the Associate in Science (A.S.) degree in respiratory care at Kapiâolani Community College (KCC) the opportunity to earn a baccalaureate degree and to continue for advanced education in respiratory care. The additional requirements in the liberal arts and sciences will contribute to increasing academic skills development, advancing knowledge, attaining career goals, and meeting the needs of the health care community in the areas of leadership, clinical practice, research and education. University of HawaiÊ»i West OÊ»ahu Bachelors in Applied Science - Respiratory Care Program ( Articulation Agreement - Fall 2021 ) Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs.
