subcontent.text: UH at MÄnoa Kinesiology & Rehabilitation Science, Health & Exercise Science | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Kinesiology & Rehabilitation Science, Health & Exercise Science Home Health KRS & HES Program Description: The Kinesiology & Rehabilitation Science Bachelor of Science degree in Health & Exercise Science is part of the allied health care discipline, primarily dealing with the study of how individuals can influence their own state of wellness, the response and adaptation of the human body to physical activity and sports participation, and how modern management skills can be used to help others achieve a higher state of wellness and better use of their leisure time. This program area has been structured to enable the student to design an academic curriculum that reflects their individual interests in this program. Career paths within this area of study include, but are not limited to: athletic training exercise physiology sports nutrition physical therapy sports psychology/rehabilitation counseling coaching/personal training Additionally, this degree program has been designed to fulfill the requirements for entry into graduate programs in the area of health sciences (e.g. Athletic Training, Physical Therapy, Occupational Therapy, Physicians Assistant, Physician, Nurse, Nurse Practitioner). Apply Now Contact Program Counselor Da Houl Program Counselor (808) 956-7606 houl@hawaii.edu Contact HES Program Coordinator Paulette Yamada HES Program Coordinator pyamada@hawaii.edu Contact KRS Department Chair Cris Stickley KRS Department Chair cstickle@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to UH Manoa UH Manoa General Education required courses Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total program tuition costs: $48,744 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) Program Prerequisite courses: 1.5 years HES, KRS Program: 2.5 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. subcontent.text: UH at MÄnoa Kinesiology & Rehabilitation Science, Health & Physical Education Teacher | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Kinesiology & Rehabilitation Science Health & Physical Education Teacher Home Health KRS & HPETE Program Description: The Kinesiology & Rehabilitation Science Bachelor of Science degree in Health & Physical Education Teacher Education (HPETE) program is currently a member in good standing of the Association for Advancing Quality in Educator Preparation (AAQEP), with our next AAQEP full accreditation review scheduled for Spring 2021. The College was nationally accredited from 2001 to 2018 by NCATE, the National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education. A professional preparation curriculum is provided for students who wish to be licensed to teach health and physical education in grades: K-6 (Elementary), 6-12 (Secondary) or K-12 health and physical education. This health and physical education program is for future professionals who are passionate about contributing to the growth, development, health, fitness and wellness, and lifelong physical activity of all individuals, but especially among youth. The student who majors in this program of study must demonstrate competence in motor skills and achieve and maintain health-related fitness. Additionally, future professionals will gain comprehensive knowledge relative to content in health and physical education including, effective teaching strategies, National and state standards, cultural competence, assessment, and accountability. While this program can lead to teacher licensure, before you can pursue courses for the licensure track, you must be admitted into the licensure track. Although you will leave with teacher certifications, this degree is also marketable to help you pursue a career in youth sport, fitness, and many other opportunities related to health and physical activity. Along with technical skills, students will also learn project management and entrepreneurship to support independent work or small business ventures. Fashion & Artisan Design (FAD) The Fashion and Artisan Design program is tailored for students interested in careers in culturally inspired artistry and fashion. In addition to honing their creative skills, students will gain knowledge in project management and entrepreneurship to support independent work or small business ventures. Film & Media Entertainment (FME) The Film and Media Production program is designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills to obtain an entry-level career in the industry and/or pursue advanced learning at the collegiate level. Students will learn the skills necessary for jobs within the industry (commercial studios, production companies, and television), including production, direction, artistry and set design, camera operation, script editing and supervision, etc. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. text: Digital Design | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Digital Design Home Pathways and Programs CM Digital Design Digital Design Pathway Map to Employment Careers in digital design offer a wide range of opportunities in fields such as graphic design, web development, animation, and multimedia production. Professionals in this area use industry-standard software to create visual content for websites, advertisements, video games, apps, and digital marketing campaigns. Students in the Digital Design program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into this field with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities to help them understand the current landscape of this industry. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the Digital Design program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore the industry through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in Digital Design may require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training might be required, you may also be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview: The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey: If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement: As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. 			    ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi For entry-level or entrepreneurial positions in the Digital Design field, several industry-related credentials can enhance your qualifications and demonstrate foundational knowledge and skills. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. The following are some NON-CREDIT (not related to college) programs you can take that will help you in your career journey. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for Digital Design related careers: Adobe Certified Professional (ACP) in Photoshop: Photoshop is a powerful image editing and graphic design software by Adobe and is considered an industry-standard tool for professionals in photography, graphic design, digital art, and web development. High school students can pursue this certification, which teaches photo retouching, digital painting, creating digital art, designing logos, making posters, and developing website layouts. Range of program duration: 17 hours Digital Art Fundamentals: Students who take this course will be able to apply successful problem-solving techniques using industry standard applications in the creative digital and production process; demonstrate basic animation principles and skills; and use the vocabulary and technological processes of digital graphics.  Course taught through KapiÊ»olani Community College. Theses training programs can lead to the following Jobs: Photographer Web Designer (Entry level) Content Creator Digital Illistrator (Entry Level) Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Windward Community College Creative Media Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Visual Arts or Creative Media (AA) Program Home CM Creative Media Program Description: The Associate in Arts (AA) degree is a two-year transfer liberal arts degree consisting of at least 60 semester credits at the 100 and 200 levels. To earn an AA degree, Windward Community College students must complete 60 credits in courses numbered 100 or above with a grade point average of at least 2.0. Students who are awarded an AA degree from a UH community college must have a community college cumulative GPA of 2.0 or higher for all course work taken in fulfillment of AA degree requirements. There are three general academic tracks in the program: crop production, landscaping, and resource management. Students can work toward an Associate in Applied Science in Sustainable Tropical Crop Production or Horticulture and Landscape Maintenance; or work with the Program Coordinator to develop an Associate in Technical Studies in Cultural and Natural Resource Management. Farmer development training is condensed in a Certificate of Competence. Program Concentrations: VISUAL ART Concentration: The Associate in Arts in Liberal Arts degree with a Concentration in Art provides students with a strong studio art experience and art history curriculum that integrates conceptual and technical artistic skills with personal and creative exploration. THEATRE Concentration: The Associate in Arts in Liberal Arts degree with a Concentration in Theatre provides students with a strong performing arts experience and integrates conceptual and practical performance skills with personal and creative exploration. Upon completion of this 60-credit program, which satisfies all the requirements for the AA degree in Liberal Arts, students will be prepared to transfer to a four-year institution to further their study (BA/BFA) in the various areas of theatre arts, including acting, musical theatre, playwriting, stage combat, and theatre production, or continue on their journey of becoming a professional artist. Program Certificates: CREATIVE MEDIA Certificate (24 credits): Students in the Academic Subject Certificate in Creative Media focus on video game design or filmmaking, learn the foundational skills of their craft, and produce a final project with professional equipment which conforms to professional standards. Upon completion of this 24-credit certificate, students will be prepared to launch their own entrepreneurial careers, to seek industry jobs or to pursue advanced academic study of their craft. Apply Now Contact Theatre Program Coordinator Nicholas Logue Theatre Program Coordinator (808) 236-9138 logue@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Justin (HaÊ»aheo) Pagan Program Counselor (808) 235-7460 paganj@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for Windward Community College Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 60 Approximate total program tuition costs: $8,122 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the Windward Community College Liberal Arts program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in ENG 22 or placement into ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in MATH 75X, OR placement into MATH 100 Program Specific Courses: VISUAL ART Concentration: ART 113: Introduction to Drawing *Prerequisite: None, RECOMMENDED ART 101 ART 116: Introduction to 3D Composition *Prerequisite: None THEATRE Concentration: THEA 101: Introduction to Drama and Theatre *Prerequisite: None THEA 221: Acting I *Prerequisite: None CREATIVE MEDIA Concentration: ART/CM 126: 3D Computer Graphics I *Prerequisite: âCâ or better ing ART 112 CM 120: Introduction to Digital Video *Prerequisite: None *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: Students who complete the Associate of Art degree in Liberal Arts at Windward Community College may apply to transfer to the following programs via a transfer agreement with the 4-year university programs listed below. UH West OÊ»ahu - Bachelors of Arts - Creative Media ( Articulation Agreement - Spring 2020 ) Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. subcontent.text: Leeward Community College Digital Media Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Digital Media (AS) Program Home CM Digital Media Program Description: Explore the options in digital communications: web design, animation, digital video, internet publishing, and more! Our Digital Media program offers you: A solid foundation of art and design with the practical technical skills Integrated training in art theory, web development, computer graphics, and digital photography Work with non-linear digital video, streaming media and web animation, motion graphics, and 2D and 3D animation Four specializations in the AS degree: Character Animation, Creative Media, Digital Video for the Web, and Internet Publishing Digital Media Program Details: Associate in Science (AS), Digital Media (60 credits) provides creative individuals with the art and design training needed to explore and express ideas using leading-edge technology and skill-sets in one of five specializations: Animation and Motion Graphics, Creative Media, Digital Photography, Digital Video for the Web, and Internet Publishing. You will develop skills required for a vast array of digital media careers, including web design and development, multimedia-production, digital video production, corporate communications, two-dimensional and three-dimensional animation, and interactive media. Academic Subject Certificate (ASC), Creative Media (21 credits) is designed for those who plan to earn a bachelorâs degree in one of two specializations: Animation & Computer Games or Interactive Media. Through your specialization, you will gain the art and design training needed to explore and express ideas using leading-edge technology, and a balance of technical skills and aesthetic development, culminating in a portfolio-building project. MUST BE TAKEN WITH DEGREE PROGRAM. Certificate of Achievement (CA), Digital Media (30 credits) is designed to provide you with entry-level skills or job upgrading for positions under direct supervision in Multi-Media and Web Development. Certificate of Competence (CO), Digital Photography (9 credits) provides you with both the technical and visual communication skills required for a variety of careers related to photography and imaging. Certificate of Competence (CO), Digital Video for the Web (9 credits) challenges you with real-world video production in a variety of global and local contexts. You will experience storytelling, animation, editing, broadcasting and directing. Certificate of Competence (CO), Graphic Design (9 credits) provides training in practical, technical, and theoretical desktop publishing skills used by the graphic arts and allied industries in the areas of publication and print promotion. Certificate of Competence (CO), Motion Graphics (9 credits) prepares you for a variety of careers in the Multimedia industries. You will build a strong foundation in Digital Art, visual and information design and animation for Film and TV. Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Irwin Yamamoto Program Coordinator (808) 455â0513 iyamamot@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Blake Hunrick Program Counselor (808) 455-0243 hunrick@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for Leeward Community College Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 60 Approximate total program tuition costs: $7,860 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the Leeward Community College Digital Media program. subcontent.text: Culture, Arts, Media & Entertainment Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Culture, Arts, Media & Entertainment Digital Design Admission Requirements Home Pathways & Programs Admission Requirements High school students interested in entering the Digital Design industry should start by building a strong foundation in visual art, design principles, and digital tools. Taking courses in graphic design, digital media, or web development can be helpful. Practicing with design software like Adobe Creative Suite (Photoshop, Illustrator, InDesign) or free tools like GIMP and Canva allows students to develop technical skills early. Creating a portfolio of personal or school projects can showcase their style and capabilities. Students should also consider seeking internships, joining design clubs, or freelancing to gain real-world experience and insights into industry trends. The basic admissions requirements can include: Course prerequisites: Some programs have specific prerequisite coursework that must be completed before applying. These prerequisites usually include general education requirements such as ART 112 Intro to Digital Arts, these will vary by program and campus (see campus program page for more details). GPA requirements: Some programs have minimum GPA requirements that students must meet with all prerequisite courses. These requirements can vary per campus. Application process: Certain programs will have a detailed set of application requirements such as submitting a written personal statement, and professional reference letters or interviewing with the program. Field or work experience: Having experience with agriculture through internships, part time jobs, work-based learning experiences or a students own social capital will give an advantage when applying for some programs. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to select an education program, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs associated with Digital Design: KapiÊ»olani Community College Windward Community College Leeward Community College Honolulu Community College KauaÊ»i Community College HawaiÊ»i Community College UH Maui College * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i Hilo * University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map * Chaminade University of Honolulu: Cumulative high school GPA of 2.50 or higher High school students in dual enrollment or running start programs will need to submit official college transcripts Provide a written statement describing your interest in pursuing your degree at Chaminade University of Honolulu, and any related extracurricular activities that have prepared you for your educational goals. This statement must be a minimum of 250 words. Test Scores (Optional) * HawaiÊ»i Pacific University: HPU understands that each student has a unique academic history and individual talents. This is why HPU takes a holistic approach to reviewing applications, and considers all the information provided on your application to make an admissions decision. For more admissions information, please visit the HPU Admissions website . What is CONSIDERED: Grade Point Average - GPA SAT and/or ACT scores (or English Proficiency if educated outside of the US) Extracurricular activities Personal statement (essay) and/or resume Academic area of interest Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.title: Kapiâolani Community College New Media Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Kapiâolani Community College New Media Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us New Media (AS) Program Home CM New Media Program Description: The New Media Arts (NMA) program is a two year AS degree program located at Kapiâolani Community College (KapiÊ»olani CC) in Honolulu, HawaiÊ»i. The NMA mission is to prepare students for employment in the fields of interface design and animation: AS, New Media Arts with a specialization in Interface Design (69-74 credits) The Associate in Science degree, New Media Arts with a specialization in Interface Design, prepares students for careers as interface designers with a focus on web design. Interface Design course topics include graphic design, web design, front-end interface programming, typography, graphic symbolism, digital multimedia, and motion graphic design. Additional courses include digital imaging, design history and portfolio development. The program is intended to serve students preparing for a career in interface design and professionals updating and refining their job skills. The program integrates classroom instruction with hands-on production skills in a learning environment that encourages the full design process for interface design as dictated by the industry and utilized in the field. The Associate in Science degree, New Media Arts with a specialization in Interface Design, will introduce students to the theory, technology, aesthetics, business, and production process of interface design. AS, New Media Arts with a specialization in Animation (72-77 credits) The Associate in Science degree, New Media Arts with a specialization in Animation, prepares students for careers in 3D computer animation, video game development, and emerging industries employing 3D computer graphics. The program is intended to serve professionals updating and refining their job skills and students preparing for a career in animation. The program integrates classroom instruction with hands-on production experience in a learning environment that encourages the collaborative process inherent in professional practice. The Associate in Science degree, New Media Arts with a specialization in Animation, will introduce students to the field of 3D computer animation, exploring the complex interplay of theory, aesthetics, technology, and production methodologies. Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Mach Fukada Program Coordinator (808) 984 3243 fukada@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Eri Nomura Program Counselor (808) 984 3306 eri4@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for KapiÊ»olani Community College The New Media Arts program begins with foundation studies in Fine Arts. Prior to entering the program, students take prerequisite Art courses that include studies in art history, drawing, design, and photography. The core principles from these foundation fine arts courses are built upon and reinforced throughout the curriculum for both specializations. As a selected admission program, the following are required PRIOR to applying to the New Media Arts Program: NMA Prerequisite courses: ENG 100 ART 101 ART 112 ART 113 For Interface Design: ART 115 For Animation: ART 115, or ART 116, or ART 123 Art Portfolio Personal Statement Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 69-77 Approximate total program tuition costs: $9,039 to $10,087 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the KapiÊ»olani Community College New Media Arts program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics Prerequisite: âCâ or better in MATH 75X, OR placement into MATH 100 AND Placement into ENG 22 Program Specific Courses: ART 101: Introduction to Visual Arts *Prerequisite: None ART 112: Introduction to Digital Arts *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100, RECOMMENDED ART 101 ART 113: Introduction to Drawing *Prerequisite: RECOMMENDED, ART 101 ART 115: Introduction to 2D Design *Prerequisite: RECOMMENDED, ART 101 *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: Students who complete the Associate of Science degree in New Media Arts at KapiÊ»olani Community College may apply to transfer to the following programs via a transfer agreement with the 4-year university programs listed below. You may find this degree of interest if you want to pursue software development as a career path or go to graduate school in computer science. In addition to the general track, the ICS Department also offers three specialized BS CS tracks: Data Science , Security Science and Creative Computational Media . The Bachelor of Arts in Information & Computer Science (BA ICS) degree allows you to combine computer science with another discipline. You might find the BA degree of interest if you are also interested in biology, entrepreneurship, game design, graphic arts, financial engineering, foreign languages, or other disciplines. For example, we have a BA degree with a concentration in Creative Computational Media . Upon completion of a B.A. in Hawaiian Studies , our students are expected to demonstrate knowledge, understanding, critical analysis and synthesis of the following: Knowing our genealogical ties to PapahÄnaumoku, our mother earth, and ko HawaiÊ»i paeÊ»Äina as our ancestral homeland. Students can explain that Kanaka Maoli are one LÄhui connected by our ancestors HÄloa and Haumea across nÄ kai Ê»ewalu. Students can explain the interconnectedness of all knowledge, contemporary and ancestral, from a Kanaka Maoli perspective. Students are capable of Kanaka Maoli applications, protocols and disciplines. Students can discuss, practice, and advance Kanaka Maoli experiences in the context of world indigenous peoples. subcontent.text: UH Maui College Creative Media Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Creative Media (AS) Program Home CM Creative Media Program Description: Creative Media is commercial art: the convergence of art, technology, and commerce. Academy for Creative Media Maui incorporates storytelling, media analysis, screenwriting, graphic design, illustration, photography, audio/video production and editing, motion graphics, animation, web technology, marketing, and journalism. We emphasize foundational knowledge, skills, understanding of intellectual property and ethical concerns, and best practices in the field to foster professional attitudes for success in advertising, web marketing, publishing, motion picture and television production, animation, gaming, app development, VR, and emergent media. Students enjoy project-based growth experiences which elevate critical thinking, awareness of related industries, and the vast career possibilities for commercial artists both in the islands and far beyond our shores. Our 60 credit Creative Media Associate in Science (A.S.) degree consists of core classes, general education, and six credits of electives. To develop a focused skill-set, students are encouraged to commit to a pathway in: Creative Media Animation Filmmaking Graphic Design To prepare students for the job market, graduates are exposed to industry-specific skills in preparation for the workforce, exploring entrepreneurism, or continuing for a four-year degree. Majors are required to earn a letter grade of C or better for core and specialization courses. Students planning a transfer should consult a counselor about future requirements. Notably, articulation agreements afford all A.S. graduates an efficient path to pursue a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) degree in Creative Media at the University of HawaiÊ»i West OÊ»ahu. Our Filmmakers and Animators often transfer into the University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa's Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) degree in Cinematic Arts. Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Brian Kohne Program Coordinator (808) 984-3315 bkohne@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for UH Maui College Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 60 Approximate total program tuition costs: $8,122 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. subcontent.text: UH Hilo ART (BA) Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Resources Contact Us ART (BA) Program Home CM Digital Art Media Program Description: The baccalaureate program in art (BA) is the study of visual art. The program explores the creative, experimental, and developmental aspects of art. The study of art involves the practice of art in the studio environment, art as an expression of our cultural heritage, and an understanding of the history of art. The program provides students, the university, and the community with visual arts experiences in regional, national, and international contexts. Lower-division courses provide study in basic theory, study of different media, and the development of skills in the application and practice of studio art. Courses in the upper-division pursue advanced theory and studio applications involving explorations of individual expression. The program emphases are painting, drawing, and printmaking studio. Other specific areas of study can be arranged through consultation with the Art Department and the College of Arts and Sciences. The Digital Media Art Certificate can be completed as part of the Art Major for the Bachelor of Arts Degree , or it can be a stand-alone certificate for students not majoring in art. The Digital Media Certificate requires foundation classes in drawing and 2D design, contemporary art history, and a selection of upper level studio classes with digital media focus. subcontent.text: UH West Oâahu Creative Media Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Creative Media (BA) Program Home CM Creative Media Program Description: Students who chose to study creative media will receive an innovative educational experience that weaves art and design, narrative, information science, and technologies necessary for a broad range of careers in government and non-government organizations, educational institutions, technological firms and private firms and agencies. The program recognizes evolving technology drives content creation and emerging media platforms. While honoring both art and mediaâs foundations, UH West Oâahuâs Creative Media program embraces digital media literacy experienced through video, animation, video games, design, social media, web and app development, virtual and augmented reality, other forms of media communication and design and digital storytelling. The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Creative Media degree, concentration in General Creative Media, is offered via distance education to our students who reside on the neighbor islands and have completed the first two years of coursework from a neighbor island in a Media/Art program at a community college within the UH system. Creative Media Concentrations: Communications and New Media Technologies: The Communications and New Media Technologies concentration moves beyond training for traditional jobs in broadcasting and film to a world of online digital content by providing a hands-on approach where skills are learned by doing. Students will gain a variety of communication, computer, and graphic design skills, preparing them for careers in management, advertising, media, communications, public relations and more. Design and Media: The Design and Media concentration educates and trains designers for the visual communication needs of industry and society. Students will graduate with career-appropriate portfolios and be ready to analyze and discuss design trends and issues relevant to todayÊ»s workforce. Video Game Design and Development: Integrating various media domains, such as design, storytelling, and technology, the general creative media concentration provides study and extended practice in the studentâs chosen area of competence. Course requirements address development and maintenance of existing artistic skills; foster support for a broader understanding of related disciplines including humanities and technology; and provide experience in working in multidisciplinary teams on realistic problems. General Creative Media: The General Creative Media concentration integrates design, storytelling, and technology. Students will produce, format and distribute content across all major media platforms and produce a professional portfolio to acquire a job within the media industry or corporate environment. subcontent.title: UH MÄnoa Cinematic Arts Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: UH MÄnoa Cinematic Arts Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Cinematic Arts (BA) Program Home CM Cinematic Arts Program Description: As HawaiÊ»iâs film school, the School of Cinematic Arts (SCA) is at the forefront of cinematic arts in the Pacific. Located in Honolulu at the University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa, SCA is dedicated to academic and creative excellence through its Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree designed to encourage innovation and collaboration with emphasis on HawaiÊ»i, the Pacific, and Asia. Focused in the heart of a state with a robust film and television industry, SCA encourages professional development, mentorship, and community engagement through a variety of programs including internships, master classes, and industry screenings such as the HawaiÊ»i International Film Festival. SCA offers a core curriculum in three tracks: Cinematic Arts, Animation and Digital Cinema: Cinematic Arts: Cinematic Arts is the central track for SCA majors providing a strong foundation in cinema history, culture, storytelling, and cinematic production. This track provides students the flexibility to focus on areas such as producing, screenwriting, documentary, media studies, as well as the focused study and extended practice in the studentâs chosen area of competence. Track requirements are interdisciplinary and allow for a broader understanding of cinema as an art, mode of storytelling, business, and cultural product. Animation: The SCA Animation track focuses on storytelling through the art of animation. Students explore traditional, experimental, and computer animation techniques to best tell their personal and unique stories from HawaiÊ»i, the Pacific, and all corners of the globe. Students gain a well-rounded understanding of the various roles, skills, and techniques used in the animation industry, enabling them to perform each task themselves when making an independent film, or recognizing areas of interest in which they want to specialize. Admission to the animation track is based on the submission of an artistâs portfolio. Digital Cinema: Students in the Digital Cinema track focus on all aspects of filmmaking: screenwriting, directing, producing, cinematography, editing, and post-production sound. The program promotes diverse storytelling through the production of narrative, experimental, documentary, and indigenous short films. Production courses are taught using industry-standard film equipment, which allows students to gain an understanding of the technical aspects of filmmaking while using current technology. This track fosters a collaborative and professional environment for learning. Admission to the digital cinema track is based on the submission of an artistâs portfolio. Creative Computational Media (CCM) Certificate: The undergraduate Creative Computational Media (CCM) Certificate Program provides students and industry professionals with training necessary to enter exciting and lucrative immersive media job markets, such as video game and eSports design and development, digital film production and special effects, new media theatre and dance performance, interactive digital media installation development, and exhibit design for museums, theme parks, or marketing/advertising. CCM is offered in collaboration with the School of Cinematic Arts (SCA), the Department of Theatre & Dance (College of Arts, Languages & Letters), the Department of Electrical Engineering (College of Engineering), and the Department of Information and Computer Sciences (ICS) (College of Natural Sciences). Apply Now Contact Program Counselor Brett Service Program Counselor (808) 956-7674 service@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply to UH Manoa, select âCinematic Arts - BAâ as your planned course of study Choose between the 3 tracks as your major concentration: Cinematic Arts, Animation, and Digital Cinema. subcontent.text: HPU Cinematic Multimedia Arts Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Cinematic Multimedia Arts (BA) Program Home CM Cinematic Multimedia Arts Program Description: The BA in Cinematic Multimedia Arts degree allows students to develop technical, design, and narrative skills in a wide range of cinematic and multimedia disciplines, including cinematic production, scriptwriting, animation, motion graphics, nonlinear editing, audio production, web design, graphic design, game design and critical media analysis. Students engage in multicultural experiential learning across multiple platforms and digital technologies, and in a transdisciplinary, collaborative environment. Animation and Multimedia Design Concentration: This concentration prepares students to work and produce in the online, mass media, information, and entertainment industries. The major focuses on developing multiple media literacy competencies, analytic abilities, and narrative skills. In this program, students develop motion graphics, animation, and digital design skills while creating mixed media portfolios and capstone projects. The applied audio-visual, graphical, and online skills that students learn are informed by a foundation in digital software skills, writing, critical analysis and creative development. Multimedia Cinematic Production Concentration: This concentration prepares students to work and produce in the audio- visual, mass media, information, and entertainment industries. The major focuses on developing multiple media literacy competencies, analytic abilities, and narrative skills. In this program, students can choose a capstone project focusing on creative cinematic narrative production, animation, or documentary production. The applied audio-visual, graphical, and online skills that students learn are informed by a foundation in communication and critical analysis and an emphasis on writing and narrative design. subcontent.title: UH MÄnoa Communications Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: UH MÄnoa Communications Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Communications (BA) Program Home CM Communications Program Description: The Communication (COM) program , founded in 1966, focuses on active learning and inquiry in fundamental communication processes with specific emphasis on media arts (digital cinema and multimedia), communication in communities (local, global, organizational, and intercultural), and information and communication technologies (ICTs) as preparation for fruitful careers, enlightened citizenship, and lifelong learning. Drawing on the rich field of mediated communication, our students understand the implications of emerging technologies as well as how messages travel across space and time, interpreted by diverse audiences. Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Communication students complete three foundation courses that provide a breadth of understanding of the field of Communication. Students then take electives across three areas of specialization to deepen their understanding of one or more subfields. The program culminates with a senior capstone project where students follow their interests to conduct original research, launch a persuasive campaign, or design a creative project. The three focus areas of this program are: Communication in Communities: This area focuses on communication in social, organizational, and professional communities ranging from small groups working together face-to-face or online, to large organizations communicating with international publics. Intercultural communication, international communication, organizational communication, and public relations are traditional academic areas of scholarship that inform this track. The capstone in communication in communities involves project development within either local or global communities. Students explore specific project areas in consultation with their professors and client organizations. The capstone course includes the written reflection and portfolio components common to all capstone courses in communication. Project options may include: Public relations campaign. Organizational communication audit. Program for preparing, training, and supporting people in dealing with cultural diversity. Information & Communication Technologies (ICTÊ»s) & Policy: This area focuses on information and communication technologies and how they both influence and are shaped by society. Students learn how ICTs, such as the Internet, social media, mobile phones, online gaming and virtual worlds, digital video, peer-to-peer networks, and other emerging network technologies, serve as masspersonal interactive communication channels that are shaped by the medium characteristics and affordances. ICTs and Policy demonstrates how social and technical developments contribute toward understanding a dynamically evolving media landscape. The capstone project in ICTs and Policy focuses on specific ICTs and policy problems related to HawaiÊ»i and the Asia Pacific region. There are several options, including: Traditional research project related to some aspect of ICTs. Policy analysis to address an issue related to ICTs. Applied technology project related to ICTs. Media Arts: The Media Arts area focuses on visual communication design aesthetics and creative digital media production processes that effectively communicate. Software programs used include Adobe Creative Cloud Suite of applications including Photoshop and PremierePro. The media arts capstone course includes a comprehensive media project and the written reflection and portfolio components common to all capstone courses in communication. These courses meet degree requirements for the UH Manoa Communication program. text: Fashion & Artisan Design | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Fashion & Artisan Design Home Pathways and Programs CM FAD Fashion & Artisan Design (FAD) Pathway Map to Employment Careers in fashion and artisan design blend creativity with cultural expression, offering opportunities in fields such as fashion design, textile arts, jewelry making, and handcrafted goods. These careers often focus on creating culturally inspired designs that reflect heritage and traditions, while also embracing contemporary trends. Professionals in this field may work as independent designers, start their own small businesses, or join larger fashion houses or artisan cooperatives. Alongside their creative expertise, they apply project management and entrepreneurship skills to successfully run their businesses, manage production, and market their unique designs. Students in the Fashion & Artisan Design program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into this field with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities to help them understand the current landscape of this industry. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the Fashion & Artisan Design program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore the industry through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in Fashion & Artisan Design may require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training might be required, you may also be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview: The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey: If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement: As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text:
Fashion & Artisan Design Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Fashion & Artisan Design
			    ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi For entry-level or entrepreneurial positions in the Fashion & Artisan Design field, several industry-related credentials can enhance your qualifications and demonstrate foundational knowledge and skills. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. The following are some NON-CREDIT (not related to college) programs you can take that will help you in your career journey. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for Fashion & Artisan Design related careers: Adobe Certified Professional (ACP) in Photoshop: Photoshop is a powerful image editing and graphic design software by Adobe and is considered an industry-standard tool for professionals in photography, graphic design, digital art, and web development. High school students can pursue this certification, which teaches photo retouching, digital painting, creating digital art, designing logos, making posters, and developing website layouts. Range of program duration: 17 hours Fashion INcubator Series: This dynamic program offers an immersive experience in both industrial sewing and fashion product development. Participants will gain hands-on expertise in operating and maintaining industrial sewing machines and steam irons, and mastering essential sewing techniques. Delve into the intricacies of mass production with a focus on efficient fabric layout, cutting, and garment construction. Explore the journey from fashion concept to market-ready product, including target market analysis, strategic sales planning, and optimizing manufacturing processes. Additionally, uncover the complexities of clothing production through sourcing, sampling, and logistics, while completing a production tech pack. This comprehensive training provides a robust foundation for a thriving career in the fashion and garment industries.  Series taught through University of Hawaii Maui College. Theses training programs can lead to the following entry level Jobs: Merchandising Displayer & WIndow Trimmers Artist Retail worker Designer Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: UH Maui College Liberal Arts W/Fashion Technology Degree Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Liberal Arts W/Fashion Technology Degree Program Home CM Creative Media Program Description: Liberal Arts education refers to the disciplines of literature, languages, philosophy, history, mathematics, anthropology, psychology, and science. In classical antiquity, the liberal arts were considered essential for citizens to know in order to take an active part in civic life. Related subjects include sociology, communications, art, statistics, creative media, sustainability, education, music, law, and criminal justice. Coursework in these areas satisfies the General Education requirements for career and technical programs at UH Maui College. A General Education curriculum in college is to create well-rounded individuals who are equipped to navigate a complex and diverse world, with skills and knowledge that extend beyond their chosen majors. The cornerstones of a Liberal Arts Education include Critical Thinking, Complex Problem Solving, and Written and Oral Communication Skills. FASHION TECHNOLOGY Academic Subject Certificate (ASC): The Fashion Technology program provides comprehensive training in apparel production and fashion design required by entrepreneurs and businesses in the fashion industry. The program develops technical skills required for job entry, retraining for the garment industry, and upgrading of sewing and pattern making skills for those already employed in the field. Laboratory activities promote the development of skills in designing, pattern drafting, and construction of basic and advanced apparel. The use of industry equipment and sewing techniques are demonstrated in group instruction. When special techniques and problems are encountered, students are given specialized instruction. Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Moana KahoÊ»ohanohano Program Coordinator (808) 984-3495 jolynnm@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for UH Maui College Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 63 Approximate total program tuition costs: $8,253 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the UH Maui College Creative Media program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in ENG 22, OR placement into ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in MATH 75X, OR placement into MATH 100, AND placement into ENG 100 Program Specific Courses: ART 104: Introduction to Printmaking *Prerequisite: RECOMMENDED, ART 113 CM 123: Photoshop and Illustrator *Prerequisite: RECOMMENDED, ICS 101 BUS 120: Principles of Business *Prerequisite: âCâ or better ENG 19 or placement into ENG 22 BUS 125: Starting a Business *Prerequisite: âCâ or better ENG 19 or placement into ENG 22 *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: Students who complete the Associate of Art degree w/ASC in Fashion Technology at UH Maui College may apply to transfer to University of HawaiÊ»i at ManoaÊ»s Fashion Design & Merchandising program, however, there is NO formal transfer agreement. Please meet with your UHMC and UH Manoa Advisors to confirm courses needed. Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs.
