subcontent.text: UH MÄnoa Fashion Design & Merchandising Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Fashion Design & Merchandising Program Home CM Fashion & Merchandising Program Description: Bachelor of Science (BS) in Fashion Design & Merchandising : Design or Merchandising Tracks The mission of the instruction program in FDM is to provide students with appropriate knowledge and skills for career positions in apparel and fashion-related industries; to promote understanding of the effects of global social, economic, sustainable, and political issues on apparel and fashion-related industries and on modes of dress; to foster appreciation of the role of dress and appearance as these reflect and shape individual behavior, social and economic exchange, and cultural conditions; to nurture intellectual growth and creativity, and to support the mission of the College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources by fostering student acquisition of problem-solving, analytic, and communication skills. The FDM curriculum provides students with the knowledge and skills needed for career positions in apparel- and fashion-related fields. Students learn fashion industry operating methods; develop buying and merchandising plans; study textile fibers and fabrics; create fashion apparel lines; examine Hawaiian, Asian, and western costume artifacts; analyze the effects of social, political, and economic conditions on local, national, and global industry operations and consumer needs; and study current concerns relating to social responsibility, ethical issues, and environmental impacts as these relate to fashion businesses and consumers. Courses cover these and related topics: Social and cultural aspects of dress Costume history Textile properties Fashion forecasting/marketing Apparel design and construction; Fashion CAD Fashion promotion and fashion show production Retail buying and merchandise management International trade issues; Retail entrepreneurship Branding; Visual merchandising and retail store design Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Youngjin Bahng, PhD Program Coordinator (808) 956-2237 yb7@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply to UH MÄnoa Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total tuition costs: $56,520 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the UH Manoa Fashion Merchandising program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: Placement in to ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics *Prerequisite: None Program Specific Courses: FDM 200: Culture, Gender, & Appearance (Same at FT 200 at Honolulu Community College) *Prerequisite: None FDM 205: Basic Apparel Construction (Same at FT 205 at Honolulu Community College) *Prerequisite: None FDM 221: Textiles I (Same at FT 221 at Honolulu Community College) *Prerequisite: None *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. subcontent.title: Culture, Arts, Media & Entertainment Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Culture, Arts, Media & Entertainment Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Culture, Arts, Media & Entertainment Fashion & Artisan Design Admission Requirements Home Pathways & Programs Admission Requirements High school students aiming for a career in Fashion and Artisan Design should focus on developing their creativity, craftsmanship, and knowledge of fashion basics. Taking courses in art, sewing, textiles, or fashion design can provide valuable skills and insight. Practicing sketching, pattern-making, and learning to work with different materials helps students build a foundation in design. Creating a portfolio with original designs, sketches, and handmade pieces is essential for showcasing their personal style. Students can gain experience by interning with local designers, volunteering for fashion shows, or starting small custom projects, all of which help build connections and a unique portfolio for future opportunities in the industry. The basic admissions requirements can include: Course prerequisites: Some programs have specific prerequisite coursework that must be completed before applying. These prerequisites usually include general education requirements such as ART 101 Intro to Visual Arts, these will vary by program and campus (see campus program page for more details). GPA requirements: Some programs have minimum GPA requirements that students must meet with all prerequisite courses. These requirements can vary per campus. Application process: Certain programs will have a detailed set of application requirements such as submitting a written personal statement, and professional reference letters or interviewing with the program. Field or work experience: Having experience with agriculture through internships, part time jobs, work-based learning experiences or a students own social capital will give an advantage when applying for some programs. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to select an education program, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs associated with Fashion & Artisan Design: KapiÊ»olani Community College Windward Community College Leeward Community College Honolulu Community College KauaÊ»i Community College HawaiÊ»i Community College UH Maui College * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i Hilo * University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map * Chaminade University of Honolulu: Cumulative high school GPA of 2.50 or higher High school students in dual enrollment or running start programs will need to submit official college transcripts Provide a written statement describing your interest in pursuing your degree at Chaminade University of Honolulu, and any related extracurricular activities that have prepared you for your educational goals. This statement must be a minimum of 250 words. Test Scores (Optional) * HawaiÊ»i Pacific University: HPU understands that each student has a unique academic history and individual talents. This is why HPU takes a holistic approach to reviewing applications, and considers all the information provided on your application to make an admissions decision. For more admissions information, please visit the HPU Admissions website . What is CONSIDERED: Grade Point Average - GPA SAT and/or ACT scores (or English Proficiency if educated outside of the US) Extracurricular activities Personal statement (essay) and/or resume Academic area of interest Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Recommended Fashion & Artisan Design Early College Courses | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Recommended Fashion & Artisan Design Early College Courses Home Pathways & Programs CM Early College Below are the recommended college courses that high school students can complete as participants in HawaiÊ»iâs Dual Credit Program , which includes Early College (EC) and Running Start (RS) programs. The following identified course will meet degree requirements for each track (2-year associate degree or 4-year bachelor degree) and may reduce a student's time to degree completion. These courses can be taken in partnership with any University of HawaiÊ»i Community College (UHCC) Campus and aligns generally with the HIDOE Culture, Arts & Media Entertainment Pathway, Fashion & Artisan Design Programs of Study. For UHCC campus and program of study specific EC courses, please see college campus pages. It is highly recommended that students reach out to their high school counselor and/or a postsecondary counselor/advisor at the UH campus prior to enrolling in any early postsecondary opportunities (including EC and RS). subcontent.text: Honolulu Community College Fashion Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Fashion Program Home CM Fashion Program Description: The Fashion Technology programâs mission is to serve the community as a learning-centered, open door program that provides technical training to meet the demands of the fashion industry and the needs of the individual. An open-exit option allows the students to identify their career objectives and participate in program exploration. Program Description: The curriculum is designed to provide competency for a wide range of occupations in the fashion industry. Theoretical knowledge and practical skills are applied in clothing construction, industrial sewing, flat patternmaking, designing, textiles, fashion sketching, grading, marking and cutting, and computerized grading and marking. Internship or cooperative education experiences are available to interested students. This broad background enables students to select various occupations such as designer, patternmaker, cutter, or custom dressmaker. Programs offered are: Associates of Applied Science (AAS) degree in Fashion Technology (61 Credits): Certificate of Achievement (CA) in Fashion Technology (43 Credits): Certificate of Competence (CO) in: Flat Patternmaking (9 Credits) Cutting Room Functions (9 Credits) Computerized Grading, Marking & Patternmaking (6 Credits) Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Elsie Casamina-Fernandez Program Coordinator elsief@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Erica Balbag-Gerard Program Counselor (808) 845-9401 ebalbag@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for Honolulu Community College Recommended: Daily access to a working sewing machine but not mandatory Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits: 61 Approximate total program tuition costs: $7,991 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the Honolulu Community College Fashion Technology program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in MATH 75X, OR placement into MATH 100 Program specific courses: These are NOT required courses but help students gain important skills for Fashion Technology: ART 101: Introduction to Visual Arts *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in ENG 100 ART 113: Introduction to Drawing *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100 BLAW 200: Legal Environment of Business *Prerequisite: ENG 100, AND placement into MATH 100 *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: Students who complete the Associate of Applied Science degree in Fashion Technology at Honolulu Community College may apply to transfer to University of HawaiÊ»i at ManoaÊ»s Fashion Design & Merchandising program, however, there is NO formal transfer agreement. Please meet with your Honolulu CC and UH Manoa Advisors to confirm courses needed. Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. Upon completion of a B.A. in Hawaiian Studies , our students are expected to demonstrate knowledge, understanding, critical analysis and synthesis of the following: Knowing our genealogical ties to PapahÄnaumoku, our mother earth, and ko HawaiÊ»i paeÊ»Äina as our ancestral homeland. Students can explain that Kanaka Maoli are one LÄhui connected by our ancestors HÄloa and Haumea across nÄ kai Ê»ewalu. Students can explain the interconnectedness of all knowledge, contemporary and ancestral, from a Kanaka Maoli perspective. Students are capable of Kanaka Maoli applications, protocols and disciplines. Students can discuss, practice, and advance Kanaka Maoli experiences in the context of world indigenous peoples. The B.A. in Hawaiian Studies has 5 areas of concentration: HÄlau o Laka: Native Hawaiian Creative Expression KÅ«kulu Aupuni: Envisioning the Nation Kumu Kahiki: Comparative HawaiâinuiÄkea and Indigenous Studies MÄlama âÄina: Hawaiian Perspectives on Resource Management Moâolelo âÅiwi: Native History and Literature Apply Now Contact Program Academic Advisor Lehua Nishimura Program Academic Advisor (808) 956-0642 cherini@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply and be accepted to UH MÄnoa Complete the general education requirements Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total tuition costs: $56,520 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. text: Film & Media Entertainment | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Film & Media Entertainment Home Pathways and Programs CM FME Film & Media Entertainment (FME) Pathway Map to Employment Careers in film and media entertainment offer a range of opportunities in production, directing, set design, camera operation, and script editing. Professionals in this field may work as production assistants, camera operators, script supervisors, or set designers, helping to bring creative visions to life. These roles require a mix of technical expertise and artistic creativity, with opportunities for advancement in areas such as directing, producing, or editing as professionals gain experience in the industry. Students in the Film & Media Entertainment program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into this field with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities to help them understand the current landscape of this industry. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the Film & Media Entertainment program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore the industry through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in Film & Media Entertainment may require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training might be required, you may also be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview: The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey: If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement: As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text:
Fashion & Artisan Design Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Film, Media & Entertainment
			    ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi For entry-level or entrepreneurial positions in the Film & Media Entertainment field, several industry-related credentials can enhance your qualifications and demonstrate foundational knowledge and skills. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. The following are some NON-CREDIT (not related to college) programs you can take that will help you in your career journey. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for Film & Media Entertainment related careers: Adobe Certified Professional (ACP) in Photoshop: Photoshop is a powerful image editing and graphic design software by Adobe and is considered an industry-standard tool for professionals in photography, graphic design, digital art, and web development. High school students can pursue this certification, which teaches photo retouching, digital painting, creating digital art, designing logos, making posters, and developing website layouts. Range of program duration: 17 hours Fundamentals of Production Assistant: This 4-part, intensive, asynchronous, on-line certification program serves as a direct pathway to becoming a production assistant, or working in the production department, of any media production (feature film, short film, TV series, commercial, branded digital content, virtual productions, etc.) Range of program duration: 16 Hours Stage 32 Accounting in Media Production: This 5-part Master Certification Course covers the fundamental skills required to work as a production accountant, or in the production accounting office, on any media production including, but not limited to, feature films, short films, TV series, commercials, branded digital content, VR content, etc. Each course â watching the lesson and taking the test that follows â takes approximately 4-hours, so the 5-part course can be completed in approximately 20 total learning hours. Each course can be taken at any time. Students who successfully complete this program will receive a industry-recognized credential from Stage 32. Range of program duration: 20 Hours Unreal Engine for Filmmakers: This online training is an 8-week, intensive, hands-on program delivered twice a week. In addition to the live meetings, students are expected to work independently for about 15 hours a week on projects. The course is a deep dive for those with no or minimal prior training in Unreal, or for those already trained on other computer graphics software. The student final project is the completion of a 1-3+ minute Unreal Engine video. Upon completing the program students receive an industry-recognized certification. The total program hours: 176. Theses training programs can lead to the following entry level Jobs: Audio & Video Technician Media & Communication Equipment Worker Actor, Musician, Singer Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Windward Community College Creative Media Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Visual Arts or Creative Media (AA) Program Home CM Creative Media Program Description: The Associate in Arts (AA) degree is a two-year transfer liberal arts degree consisting of at least 60 semester credits at the 100 and 200 levels. To earn an AA degree, Windward Community College students must complete 60 credits in courses numbered 100 or above with a grade point average of at least 2.0. Students who are awarded an AA degree from a UH community college must have a community college cumulative GPA of 2.0 or higher for all course work taken in fulfillment of AA degree requirements. There are three general academic tracks in the program: crop production, landscaping, and resource management. Students can work toward an Associate in Applied Science in Sustainable Tropical Crop Production or Horticulture and Landscape Maintenance; or work with the Program Coordinator to develop an Associate in Technical Studies in Cultural and Natural Resource Management. Farmer development training is condensed in a Certificate of Competence. Program Concentrations: VISUAL ART Concentration: The Associate in Arts in Liberal Arts degree with a Concentration in Art provides students with a strong studio art experience and art history curriculum that integrates conceptual and technical artistic skills with personal and creative exploration. THEATRE Concentration: The Associate in Arts in Liberal Arts degree with a Concentration in Theatre provides students with a strong performing arts experience and integrates conceptual and practical performance skills with personal and creative exploration. Upon completion of this 60-credit program, which satisfies all the requirements for the AA degree in Liberal Arts, students will be prepared to transfer to a four-year institution to further their study (BA/BFA) in the various areas of theatre arts, including acting, musical theatre, playwriting, stage combat, and theatre production, or continue on their journey of becoming a professional artist. Program Certificates: CREATIVE MEDIA Certificate (24 credits): Students in the Academic Subject Certificate in Creative Media focus on video game design or filmmaking, learn the foundational skills of their craft, and produce a final project with professional equipment which conforms to professional standards. Upon completion of this 24-credit certificate, students will be prepared to launch their own entrepreneurial careers, to seek industry jobs or to pursue advanced academic study of their craft. Apply Now Contact Theatre Program Coordinator Nicholas Logue Theatre Program Coordinator (808) 236-9138 logue@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Justin (HaÊ»aheo) Pagan Program Counselor (808) 235-7460 paganj@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for Windward Community College Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 60 Approximate total program tuition costs: $8,122 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the Windward Community College Liberal Arts program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in ENG 22 or placement into ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in MATH 75X, OR placement into MATH 100 Program Specific Courses: VISUAL ART Concentration: ART 113: Introduction to Drawing *Prerequisite: None, RECOMMENDED ART 101 ART 116: Introduction to 3D Composition *Prerequisite: None THEATRE Concentration: THEA 101: Introduction to Drama and Theatre *Prerequisite: None THEA 221: Acting I *Prerequisite: None CREATIVE MEDIA Concentration: ART/CM 126: 3D Computer Graphics I *Prerequisite: âCâ or better ing ART 112 CM 120: Introduction to Digital Video *Prerequisite: None *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: Students who complete the Associate of Art degree in Liberal Arts at Windward Community College may apply to transfer to the following programs via a transfer agreement with the 4-year university programs listed below. UH West OÊ»ahu - Bachelors of Arts - Creative Media ( Articulation Agreement - Spring 2020 ) Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. subcontent.text: Leeward Community College Digital Media Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Digital Media (AS) Program Home CM Digital Media Program Description: Explore the options in digital communications: web design, animation, digital video, internet publishing, and more! Our Digital Media program offers you: A solid foundation of art and design with the practical technical skills Integrated training in art theory, web development, computer graphics, and digital photography Work with non-linear digital video, streaming media and web animation, motion graphics, and 2D and 3D animation Four specializations in the AS degree: Character Animation, Creative Media, Digital Video for the Web, and Internet Publishing Digital Media Program Details: Associate in Science (AS), Digital Media (60 credits) provides creative individuals with the art and design training needed to explore and express ideas using leading-edge technology and skill-sets in one of five specializations: Animation and Motion Graphics, Creative Media, Digital Photography, Digital Video for the Web, and Internet Publishing. You will develop skills required for a vast array of digital media careers, including web design and development, multimedia-production, digital video production, corporate communications, two-dimensional and three-dimensional animation, and interactive media. Academic Subject Certificate (ASC), Creative Media (21 credits) is designed for those who plan to earn a bachelorâs degree in one of two specializations: Animation & Computer Games or Interactive Media. Through your specialization, you will gain the art and design training needed to explore and express ideas using leading-edge technology, and a balance of technical skills and aesthetic development, culminating in a portfolio-building project. MUST BE TAKEN WITH DEGREE PROGRAM. Certificate of Achievement (CA), Digital Media (30 credits) is designed to provide you with entry-level skills or job upgrading for positions under direct supervision in Multi-Media and Web Development. Certificate of Competence (CO), Digital Photography (9 credits) provides you with both the technical and visual communication skills required for a variety of careers related to photography and imaging. Certificate of Competence (CO), Digital Video for the Web (9 credits) challenges you with real-world video production in a variety of global and local contexts. You will experience storytelling, animation, editing, broadcasting and directing. Certificate of Competence (CO), Graphic Design (9 credits) provides training in practical, technical, and theoretical desktop publishing skills used by the graphic arts and allied industries in the areas of publication and print promotion. Certificate of Competence (CO), Motion Graphics (9 credits) prepares you for a variety of careers in the Multimedia industries. You will build a strong foundation in Digital Art, visual and information design and animation for Film and TV. Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Irwin Yamamoto Program Coordinator (808) 455â0513 iyamamot@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Blake Hunrick Program Counselor (808) 455-0243 hunrick@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for Leeward Community College Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 60 Approximate total program tuition costs: $7,860 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the Leeward Community College Digital Media program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in ENG 22, OR placement into ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in MATH 82X, OR placement into MATH 100 Program Specific Courses: ART 107D: Introduction to Digital Photography *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100, RECOMMENDED ART 112 ART 113: Introduction to Drawing *Prerequisite: None DMED 150: Film Analysis & Storytelling *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100 *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: Students who complete the Associate of Science degree in Digital Media at Leeward Community College may apply to transfer to the following programs via a transfer agreement with the 4-year university programs listed below. UH West OÊ»ahu - Bachelors of Arts - Creative Media ( Articulation Agreement - Spring 2020 ) Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. subcontent.title: Film, Media & Entertainment Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Film, Media & Entertainment Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Film, Media & Entertainment Admission Requirements Home Pathways & Programs Admission Requirements High school students interested in the Film, Media & Entertainment industry should focus on developing storytelling and technical skills. Taking classes in film, media studies, theater, or creative writing can help build a foundation. Gaining experience with cameras, video editing software like Adobe Premiere Pro or iMovie, and learning basic lighting and sound techniques are also beneficial. Creating short films, vlogs, or podcasts allows students to build a portfolio and develop their voice. They should seek internships, volunteer on local productions, or join film clubs to network and gain hands-on experience, setting them up for success in this competitive industry. The basic admissions requirements can include: Course prerequisites: Some programs have specific prerequisite coursework that must be completed before applying. These prerequisites usually include general education requirements such as ART 107D Intro to Digital Photography, these will vary by program and campus (see campus program page for more details). GPA requirements: Some programs have minimum GPA requirements that students must meet with all prerequisite courses. These requirements can vary per campus. Application process: Certain programs will have a detailed set of application requirements such as submitting a written personal statement, and professional reference letters or interviewing with the program. Field or work experience: Having experience with agriculture through internships, part time jobs, work-based learning experiences or a students own social capital will give an advantage when applying for some programs. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to select an education program, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs associated with Film, Media & Entertainment: KapiÊ»olani Community College Windward Community College Leeward Community College Honolulu Community College KauaÊ»i Community College HawaiÊ»i Community College UH Maui College * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i Hilo * University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map * Chaminade University of Honolulu: Cumulative high school GPA of 2.50 or higher High school students in dual enrollment or running start programs will need to submit official college transcripts Provide a written statement describing your interest in pursuing your degree at Chaminade University of Honolulu, and any related extracurricular activities that have prepared you for your educational goals. This statement must be a minimum of 250 words. Test Scores (Optional) * HawaiÊ»i Pacific University: HPU understands that each student has a unique academic history and individual talents. This is why HPU takes a holistic approach to reviewing applications, and considers all the information provided on your application to make an admissions decision. For more admissions information, please visit the HPU Admissions website . What is CONSIDERED: Grade Point Average - GPA SAT and/or ACT scores (or English Proficiency if educated outside of the US) Extracurricular activities Personal statement (essay) and/or resume Academic area of interest Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Kapiâolani Community College New Media Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us New Media (AS) Program Home CM New Media Program Description: The New Media Arts (NMA) program is a two year AS degree program located at Kapiâolani Community College (KapiÊ»olani CC) in Honolulu, HawaiÊ»i. The NMA mission is to prepare students for employment in the fields of interface design and animation: AS, New Media Arts with a specialization in Interface Design (69-74 credits) The Associate in Science degree, New Media Arts with a specialization in Interface Design, prepares students for careers as interface designers with a focus on web design. Interface Design course topics include graphic design, web design, front-end interface programming, typography, graphic symbolism, digital multimedia, and motion graphic design. Additional courses include digital imaging, design history and portfolio development. The program is intended to serve students preparing for a career in interface design and professionals updating and refining their job skills. The program integrates classroom instruction with hands-on production skills in a learning environment that encourages the full design process for interface design as dictated by the industry and utilized in the field. The Associate in Science degree, New Media Arts with a specialization in Interface Design, will introduce students to the theory, technology, aesthetics, business, and production process of interface design. AS, New Media Arts with a specialization in Animation (72-77 credits) The Associate in Science degree, New Media Arts with a specialization in Animation, prepares students for careers in 3D computer animation, video game development, and emerging industries employing 3D computer graphics. The program is intended to serve professionals updating and refining their job skills and students preparing for a career in animation. The program integrates classroom instruction with hands-on production experience in a learning environment that encourages the collaborative process inherent in professional practice. The Associate in Science degree, New Media Arts with a specialization in Animation, will introduce students to the field of 3D computer animation, exploring the complex interplay of theory, aesthetics, technology, and production methodologies. Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Mach Fukada Program Coordinator (808) 984 3243 fukada@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Eri Nomura Program Counselor (808) 984 3306 eri4@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for KapiÊ»olani Community College The New Media Arts program begins with foundation studies in Fine Arts. Prior to entering the program, students take prerequisite Art courses that include studies in art history, drawing, design, and photography. The core principles from these foundation fine arts courses are built upon and reinforced throughout the curriculum for both specializations. As a selected admission program, the following are required PRIOR to applying to the New Media Arts Program: NMA Prerequisite courses: ENG 100 ART 101 ART 112 ART 113 For Interface Design: ART 115 For Animation: ART 115, or ART 116, or ART 123 Art Portfolio Personal Statement Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 69-77 Approximate total program tuition costs: $9,039 to $10,087 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the KapiÊ»olani Community College New Media Arts program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics Prerequisite: âCâ or better in MATH 75X, OR placement into MATH 100 AND Placement into ENG 22 Program Specific Courses: ART 101: Introduction to Visual Arts *Prerequisite: None ART 112: Introduction to Digital Arts *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100, RECOMMENDED ART 101 ART 113: Introduction to Drawing *Prerequisite: RECOMMENDED, ART 101 ART 115: Introduction to 2D Design *Prerequisite: RECOMMENDED, ART 101 *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Guided by courses in various Humanities disciplines, students develop critical thinking skills and learn to argue for interpretation of texts that powerfully shape our world. Students in the concentration select one of three tracks: Film and Television Studies Music/Theatre Journalism/Media Analysis They also explore the arts through coursework in creative media, creative writing, or music practice. This coursework provides a foundation for many career paths, including journalism or further study at the graduate level. subcontent.title: UH MÄnoa Theatre & Dance Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: UH MÄnoa Theatre & Dance Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Theatre & Dance Program Home CM Theatre & Dance Program Description: Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Theatre & Dance This degree has two concentrations, in Theatre or Dance. Students must complete 40 credit hours, including 7 credits of core requirements in Hawaiian performance, stage production, and a practicum. Dance Concentration: This concentration is designed for students with a broad interest in dance and allows them maximum flexibility to satisfy requirements in their areas of greatest interest. In addition to the core requirements, students complete 28 credit hours of required dance concentration courses in hula; Asian or Oceanic dance; ballet, contemporary, hip hop, or queer dance; visual media for dance/screendance; improvisation; choreography; kinesiology, global perspectives on dance; indigenous dance studies, or dance history; as well as a senior capstone project. Students also need to complete 5 credit hours in elective courses selecting from dance lecture, studio practice, performance, and repertory classes. Students are required to perform in at least one UHM dance production per year. Theatre Concentration: This concentration is designed for students with a broad interest in theatre and allows maximum flexibility for satisfying requirements in areas of greatest interest. In addition to the core requirements, students complete 33 credit hours of required but broad-based courses in the areas of acting; movement or voice, performance or history of Hawaii, Asia, or the Pacific; design or technical theatre; world theatre; theatre for young audiences; directing, playwriting or stage management; and additional practicum courses in performance, stagecraft, costume, production management, stage management, dramaturgy, etc. Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) in Theatre & Dance This audition-only degree is designed for those wishing to pursue professional careers in performance and has two concentrations: in Dance, and in Acting for Theatre, Screen and New Media. Students must complete 62 credit hours, including 8 credits of core requirements in Hawaiian performance, stage production, and two practicums. Dance Concentration: This concentration is designed for students who wish to pursue professional careers as dance performers, choreographers, scholars, administrators, and/or teachers. Admission to the program is by audition only , but incoming students may declare a BA major in Theatre and Dance with a selection of the Dance concentration on their university application and then audition for the BFA degree Dance concentration. In addition to the core requirements of the BFA in Theatre and Dance, students complete 27 credit hours in Dance concentration courses including visual media for dance/screen dance; improvisation; choreography; kinesiology, global perspectives on dance; indigenous dance studies, or dance history; performance or repertory, as well as a senior choreography project, and, 27 credit hours in Dance technique courses including hula; Asian and Oceanic dance; ballet, contemporary, hip hop, and queer dance. Students are required to perform in at least two UHM dance productions per year and to register for a dance studio practice course every semester. Graduation requirements include the submission of a portfolio with a resume and self-assessment essay, an exit interview, and the completion of a survey. For Audition Application: Professor Kara Jhalak Miller Acting for Theatre, Screen, and New Media Concentration: This concentration is designed for students who wish to pursue professional careers as actors in theatre, television, film, and digital performance. Admission to the program is by audition only , but incoming students may declare a BA major in Theatre and Dance with a selection of the Theatre concentration on their university application and then audition for the Acting for Theatre, Screen, and New Media concentration of the BFA degree during the spring semester of their first year at UHM. In addition to the core requirements of the BFA in Theatre and Dance, students complete 36 credit hours of technique courses in acting, voice, and movement, 12 credits in theatre fundamentals, 6 credits in dance classes, and 6 additional acting elective credits. Graduation requirements include the submission of a professional website and a self-assessment essay, an exit interview, and the completion of a survey. For Audition Application: Assistant Professor Joshua âBabaâ Tavares Creative Computational Media (CCM) Certificate The undergraduate Creative Computational Media (CCM) Certificate provides students and industry professionals with training necessary to enter exciting and lucrative immersive media job markets, such as video game and eSports design and development, digital film production and special effects, new media theatre and dance performance, interactive digital media installation development, and exhibit design for museums, theme parks, or marketing/advertising. CCM is offered in collaboration with the School of Cinematic Arts, the Department of Theatre & Dance, the Department of Electrical Engineering, and the Department of Information and Computer Sciences. Apply Now Contact Undergraduate Theatre Advisor Maile Speetjens Undergraduate Theatre Advisor (808) 956-7677 speetjen@hawaii.edu Contact Undergraduate Dance Advisor Pei-Ling Kao Undergraduate Dance Advisor (808) 956-7677 spkao@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply to UH MÄnoa For BFA, students must audition for admission (see above) Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total tuition costs: $56,520 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the UH Manoa Theatre & Dance program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: Placement in to ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics *Prerequisite: None Program Specific Courses: DANCE 150: Introduction to Dance *Prerequisite: None THEA 101: Introduction to World Drama & Theatre (Listed as DRAM 101 at UHCCÊ»s) *Prerequisite: None THEA 221: Introduction to Acting for Stage & Screen (Listed as DRAM 221 at UHCCÊ»s) *Prerequisite: None *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. It provides the necessary education and training to students who are seeking entry-level positions as digital media artists and/or transfer to a Baccalaureate granting institution. It provides professionals already in the field with updated technology training. This program leads to an Associate of Science in Creative Media degree. subcontent.text: UH Maui College Creative Media Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Creative Media (AS) Program Home CM Creative Media Program Description: Creative Media is commercial art: the convergence of art, technology, and commerce. Academy for Creative Media Maui incorporates storytelling, media analysis, screenwriting, graphic design, illustration, photography, audio/video production and editing, motion graphics, animation, web technology, marketing, and journalism. We emphasize foundational knowledge, skills, understanding of intellectual property and ethical concerns, and best practices in the field to foster professional attitudes for success in advertising, web marketing, publishing, motion picture and television production, animation, gaming, app development, VR, and emergent media. Students enjoy project-based growth experiences which elevate critical thinking, awareness of related industries, and the vast career possibilities for commercial artists both in the islands and far beyond our shores. Our 60 credit Creative Media Associate in Science (A.S.) degree consists of core classes, general education, and six credits of electives. To develop a focused skill-set, students are encouraged to commit to a pathway in: Creative Media Animation Filmmaking Graphic Design To prepare students for the job market, graduates are exposed to industry-specific skills in preparation for the workforce, exploring entrepreneurism, or continuing for a four-year degree. Majors are required to earn a letter grade of C or better for core and specialization courses. Students planning a transfer should consult a counselor about future requirements. Notably, articulation agreements afford all A.S. graduates an efficient path to pursue a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) degree in Creative Media at the University of HawaiÊ»i West OÊ»ahu. Our Filmmakers and Animators often transfer into the University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa's Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) degree in Cinematic Arts. subcontent.title: UH MÄnoa Communications Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: UH MÄnoa Communications Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Communications (BA) Program Home CM Communications Program Description: The Communication (COM) program , founded in 1966, focuses on active learning and inquiry in fundamental communication processes with specific emphasis on media arts (digital cinema and multimedia), communication in communities (local, global, organizational, and intercultural), and information and communication technologies (ICTs) as preparation for fruitful careers, enlightened citizenship, and lifelong learning. Drawing on the rich field of mediated communication, our students understand the implications of emerging technologies as well as how messages travel across space and time, interpreted by diverse audiences. Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Communication students complete three foundation courses that provide a breadth of understanding of the field of Communication. Students then take electives across three areas of specialization to deepen their understanding of one or more subfields. The program culminates with a senior capstone project where students follow their interests to conduct original research, launch a persuasive campaign, or design a creative project. The three focus areas of this program are: Communication in Communities: This area focuses on communication in social, organizational, and professional communities ranging from small groups working together face-to-face or online, to large organizations communicating with international publics. Intercultural communication, international communication, organizational communication, and public relations are traditional academic areas of scholarship that inform this track. The capstone in communication in communities involves project development within either local or global communities. Students explore specific project areas in consultation with their professors and client organizations. The capstone course includes the written reflection and portfolio components common to all capstone courses in communication. Project options may include: Public relations campaign. Organizational communication audit. Program for preparing, training, and supporting people in dealing with cultural diversity. Information & Communication Technologies (ICTÊ»s) & Policy: This area focuses on information and communication technologies and how they both influence and are shaped by society. Students learn how ICTs, such as the Internet, social media, mobile phones, online gaming and virtual worlds, digital video, peer-to-peer networks, and other emerging network technologies, serve as masspersonal interactive communication channels that are shaped by the medium characteristics and affordances. ICTs and Policy demonstrates how social and technical developments contribute toward understanding a dynamically evolving media landscape. The capstone project in ICTs and Policy focuses on specific ICTs and policy problems related to HawaiÊ»i and the Asia Pacific region. There are several options, including: Traditional research project related to some aspect of ICTs. Policy analysis to address an issue related to ICTs. Applied technology project related to ICTs. Media Arts: The Media Arts area focuses on visual communication design aesthetics and creative digital media production processes that effectively communicate. Software programs used include Adobe Creative Cloud Suite of applications including Photoshop and PremierePro. The media arts capstone course includes a comprehensive media project and the written reflection and portfolio components common to all capstone courses in communication. Apply Now Contact Program Director Hanae Kramer Program Director (808) 956-3780 hanae@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Acceptance to UH MÄnoa Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total tuition costs: $56,520 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the UH Manoa Communication program. Our program emphasizes multicultural team and community building in a personalized learning environment. The program emphasizes multicultural perspectives, authentic communication, valuing diversity, professional and personal empowerment, and enhanced self-awareness. Students develop oral, written, group, interpersonal, intercultural, and organizational communication skills that prepare them for leadership and citizenship in a diverse civil democratic society. The mission of the Communication Department is guided by the assumption that culture permeates every level of communication. Consequently, our mission is to: explore and promote diverse theories and perspectives related to communication; facilitate practical skills for effective communication in multicultural contexts; develop leaders that can relate to global and local cultures; cultivate healthy individuals, relationships, organizations, and communities; promote dialogue among diverse individuals, communities, and organizations. The UH Hilo Department of Communication offers a Bachelor of Arts in Communication , and courses in the areas of communication in: interpersonal intercultural organizational public media Apply Now Contact Program Chair Jing Yin Program Chair (808) 932-7216 jingyin@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to UH Hilo Competition of General Education courses Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $306 Total number of credits 120 Approximate total program tuition costs: $36,720 Estimated program length: 4 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. subcontent.text: University of Chaminade Communications Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Communications Program Home CM Communications Program Description: Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Communication The power of communicating effectively shouldnât ever be underestimated. Effective communication can change minds. It can move people, stir them. It can trigger tears or laughter. âThe art of communication,â speechwriter James Hume said, âis the language of leadership.â Indeed, it is. And thatâs all the more true in the Digital Ageâthe age of âgoing viralâ and of nearly instantaneous impact. When the medium can be just as important as the message, and when thereâs always a new or emerging digital platform to get comfortable with. Our Communication major is designed to help you serve as a leader, whatever your specialization. Our coursework offers a broad-based set of skills, with key opportunities along the way for developing passions, pursuing individualized learning and taking on internships. Experiential Learning Opportunities Learn the newest strategies of communicating and building relationships with consumers through the internet, sponsorships, and events. Get a grounding in the traditional communication tools of advertising and personal selling. Learn how creativity is driven by strategy, and how all of it fits into the needs of the organization. Get the opportunity for hands-on experience with the tools of the trade: video, print, and web. Service-learning projects will give you the opportunity to help others with your creativity, while receiving course credit. Youâll receive real-world public relations experiences by promoting a project that benefits low-income families and the homeless. Participate in competitions, often with classmates in a team. Chaminade teams have won national awards at the American Advertising Federation student competition, among others. Apply Now Contact Program Contact Cheryl Edelson Dean (808) 735-4826 cedelson@chaminade.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to Chaminade University Cost and time commitment: Starting in Fall 2023, Chaminade Universityâs HawaiÊ»i Guarantee provides local high school graduates entering as freshmen the same tuition rate as University of Hawaiâi at Manoaâs annual resident undergraduate tuition AND an achievable pathway to graduate in four years. The program recognizes evolving technology drives content creation and emerging media platforms. While honoring both art and mediaâs foundations, UH West Oâahuâs Creative Media program embraces digital media literacy experienced through video, animation, video games, design, social media, web and app development, virtual and augmented reality, other forms of media communication and design and digital storytelling. The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Creative Media degree, concentration in General Creative Media, is offered via distance education to our students who reside on the neighbor islands and have completed the first two years of coursework from a neighbor island in a Media/Art program at a community college within the UH system. Creative Media Concentrations: Communications and New Media Technologies: The Communications and New Media Technologies concentration moves beyond training for traditional jobs in broadcasting and film to a world of online digital content by providing a hands-on approach where skills are learned by doing. Students will gain a variety of communication, computer, and graphic design skills, preparing them for careers in management, advertising, media, communications, public relations and more. Design and Media: The Design and Media concentration educates and trains designers for the visual communication needs of industry and society. Students will graduate with career-appropriate portfolios and be ready to analyze and discuss design trends and issues relevant to todayÊ»s workforce. Video Game Design and Development: Integrating various media domains, such as design, storytelling, and technology, the general creative media concentration provides study and extended practice in the studentâs chosen area of competence. Course requirements address development and maintenance of existing artistic skills; foster support for a broader understanding of related disciplines including humanities and technology; and provide experience in working in multidisciplinary teams on realistic problems. General Creative Media: The General Creative Media concentration integrates design, storytelling, and technology. Students will produce, format and distribute content across all major media platforms and produce a professional portfolio to acquire a job within the media industry or corporate environment.
