subcontent.text: UH MÄnoa Cinematic Arts Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Cinematic Arts (BA) Program Home CM Cinematic Arts Program Description: As HawaiÊ»iâs film school, the School of Cinematic Arts (SCA) is at the forefront of cinematic arts in the Pacific. Located in Honolulu at the University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa, SCA is dedicated to academic and creative excellence through its Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree designed to encourage innovation and collaboration with emphasis on HawaiÊ»i, the Pacific, and Asia. Focused in the heart of a state with a robust film and television industry, SCA encourages professional development, mentorship, and community engagement through a variety of programs including internships, master classes, and industry screenings such as the HawaiÊ»i International Film Festival. SCA offers a core curriculum in three tracks: Cinematic Arts, Animation and Digital Cinema: Cinematic Arts: Cinematic Arts is the central track for SCA majors providing a strong foundation in cinema history, culture, storytelling, and cinematic production. This track provides students the flexibility to focus on areas such as producing, screenwriting, documentary, media studies, as well as the focused study and extended practice in the studentâs chosen area of competence. Track requirements are interdisciplinary and allow for a broader understanding of cinema as an art, mode of storytelling, business, and cultural product. Animation: The SCA Animation track focuses on storytelling through the art of animation. Students explore traditional, experimental, and computer animation techniques to best tell their personal and unique stories from HawaiÊ»i, the Pacific, and all corners of the globe. Students gain a well-rounded understanding of the various roles, skills, and techniques used in the animation industry, enabling them to perform each task themselves when making an independent film, or recognizing areas of interest in which they want to specialize. Admission to the animation track is based on the submission of an artistâs portfolio. Digital Cinema: Students in the Digital Cinema track focus on all aspects of filmmaking: screenwriting, directing, producing, cinematography, editing, and post-production sound. The program promotes diverse storytelling through the production of narrative, experimental, documentary, and indigenous short films. Production courses are taught using industry-standard film equipment, which allows students to gain an understanding of the technical aspects of filmmaking while using current technology. This track fosters a collaborative and professional environment for learning. Admission to the digital cinema track is based on the submission of an artistâs portfolio. Creative Computational Media (CCM) Certificate: The undergraduate Creative Computational Media (CCM) Certificate Program provides students and industry professionals with training necessary to enter exciting and lucrative immersive media job markets, such as video game and eSports design and development, digital film production and special effects, new media theatre and dance performance, interactive digital media installation development, and exhibit design for museums, theme parks, or marketing/advertising. CCM is offered in collaboration with the School of Cinematic Arts (SCA), the Department of Theatre & Dance (College of Arts, Languages & Letters), the Department of Electrical Engineering (College of Engineering), and the Department of Information and Computer Sciences (ICS) (College of Natural Sciences). Apply Now Contact Program Counselor Brett Service Program Counselor (808) 956-7674 service@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply to UH Manoa, select âCinematic Arts - BAâ as your planned course of study Choose between the 3 tracks as your major concentration: Cinematic Arts, Animation, and Digital Cinema. You may find this degree of interest if you want to pursue software development as a career path or go to graduate school in computer science. In addition to the general track, the ICS Department also offers three specialized BS CS tracks: Data Science , Security Science and Creative Computational Media . The Bachelor of Arts in Information & Computer Science (BA ICS) degree allows you to combine computer science with another discipline. You might find the BA degree of interest if you are also interested in biology, entrepreneurship, game design, graphic arts, financial engineering, foreign languages, or other disciplines. For example, we have a BA degree with a concentration in Creative Computational Media. subcontent.text: Honolulu Community College Music & Entertainment Learning Experience (MELE) Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Music & Entertainment Learning Experience (MELE) Program Home CM MELE Program Description: MELE - Music & Entertainment Learning Experience - utilizes a comprehensive music business and production curriculum meeting the requirements for entry-level training of music industry and production professionals. The curriculum focuses on combining academic experience with real-world applications to prepare students to work in the rapidly evolving global music industry of the 21st century. The program core offers a rounded curriculum grounding students in the basics of the music industry, sound recording and the business of music. The MELE program offers two distinct degree paths. The Associate of Science (AS) in Music Business & Production and the Associate of Science (AS) in Audio Engineering Technology which may be earned during a four-semester sequence: AS in MELE Music Business & Production: This curriculum requires special focus on business related courses, including accounting, business law, and economics, as well as music business courses. Music business courses include a survey of the music business, music publishing, intellectual properties, and others. AS in MELE Audio Engineering Technology: This curriculum focuses on the engineering and production of music recording. Audio engineering courses include studio production, audio engineering, and studio maintenance and electronics. This use of immersion methodology at the tertiary level is highly distinctive, not only for HawaiÊ»i, but on a national level. The growth of the program is closely tied to its leadership role in reestablishing Hawaiian as the medium of education in preschools (1984) and in K-12 education (1986), as well as in establishing a teacher certification program (1998), masters of arts programs (1998), and a doctoral program (2006). The Hawaiian Studies program basically serves: Those majoring in Hawaiian Studies; Those pursuing a Certificate in Hawaiian Language, Hawaiian Culture, and/or Multidisciplinary Hawaiian Studies; Those pursuing a minor in Hawaiian Studies; and Those taking courses for their own interest and to fulfill University requirements. The program provides a unique educational opportunity for students interested in culture, economics, politics, sociology, linguistics, music, anthropology, biology, geography, history, and dance. subcontent.text: UH MÄnoa Journalism Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Journalism Program Home CM Journalism Program Description: Journalism believes that a Free Press embodied in the First Amendment of the Constitution is the cornerstone of democracy. In the words of Thomas Jefferson, âOur liberty depends on the freedom of the press, and that cannot be limited without being lost.â Ethical journalism is an extension of a Free Press. The Journalism program subscribes to the principles embodied in the Society of Professional Journalistsâ Code of Ethics . The Journalism program believes that âpublic enlightenment is the forerunner of justice and the foundation of democracyâ and that âethical journalism strives to ensure the free exchange of information that is accurate, fair and thorough.â In that vein, the Journalism program teaches students to report and write clearly about news of public importance in different styles and mediums, including via online media â such as on websites and mobile apps â as well as through traditional print and broadcast channels. During these training processes, students develop professional-level abilities to think critically and to gather, analyze, and organize information in the belief that an informed public is critical to a healthy democracy. Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Journalism : Journalism majors learn how to make better media. They write. They record audio and video. They take photographs. They edit. Along the way, they develop deep critical-thinking skills as well as abilities to gather, organize and understand information about their communities. And then â continuing this communication process through its full cycle â they share what they have learned clearly and responsibly across multiple media platforms, including social media. Our program is professional in its orientation, and students are encouraged to work for campus media such as Ka Leo O HawaiÊ»i (the campus newspaper) or KTUH-FM (the campus radio station) and to participate in an extensive program of professional internships, including at prominent media organizations based on OÊ»ahu, such as The Star-Advertiser , Hawaii News Now , and Civil Beat . subcontent.text: HPU Communication Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Communication Program Home CM Communication Program Description: Communication Studies empowers students to become successful and mindful global citizens by engaging in effective and ethical communication. Communication Studies provides knowledge and skills that are critical for success and enrichment in our personal, professional and civic lives. The discipline of Communication focuses on how people use messages to generate and share meanings across various contexts, cultures, and media. Known as ârhetoricâ in the Western academic tradition, communication pedagogy has been a central concern of Greek, Roman, Medieval, Renaissance, Asian, Indigenous and modern culture. Today, the study and applications of communication embraces the Internet, e-commerce, mobile communications, global diplomacy, advertising, public relations, journalism, broadcasting, intercultural and interpersonal communication, as well as public speaking, digital mechanisms and media studies. The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Communications Studies and Practices has two concentrations: Concentration in Communication Studies: In the Communication Studies concentration, an emphasis on effective communication techniques, media technology, and culture is built on a foundation of communication theory and research. Concentration in Strategic Communication: The concentration in Strategic Communication combines the areas of Advertising, Public Relations, Media and Marketing Communication to reflect todayâs converging industries and job opportunities. Required classes focus on integration of Advertising, Public Relations, Media and Marketing Communications while providing students the flexibility to tailor their degree to fit their career interests. subcontent.title: HPU Cinematic Multimedia Arts Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: HPU Cinematic Multimedia Arts Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Cinematic Multimedia Arts (BA) Program Home CM Cinematic Multimedia Arts Program Description: The BA in Cinematic Multimedia Arts degree allows students to develop technical, design, and narrative skills in a wide range of cinematic and multimedia disciplines, including cinematic production, scriptwriting, animation, motion graphics, nonlinear editing, audio production, web design, graphic design, game design and critical media analysis. Students engage in multicultural experiential learning across multiple platforms and digital technologies, and in a transdisciplinary, collaborative environment. Animation and Multimedia Design Concentration: This concentration prepares students to work and produce in the online, mass media, information, and entertainment industries. The major focuses on developing multiple media literacy competencies, analytic abilities, and narrative skills. In this program, students develop motion graphics, animation, and digital design skills while creating mixed media portfolios and capstone projects. The applied audio-visual, graphical, and online skills that students learn are informed by a foundation in digital software skills, writing, critical analysis and creative development. Multimedia Cinematic Production Concentration: This concentration prepares students to work and produce in the audio- visual, mass media, information, and entertainment industries. The major focuses on developing multiple media literacy competencies, analytic abilities, and narrative skills. In this program, students can choose a capstone project focusing on creative cinematic narrative production, animation, or documentary production. The applied audio-visual, graphical, and online skills that students learn are informed by a foundation in communication and critical analysis and an emphasis on writing and narrative design. Secondary areas are possible in writing or multimedia. Graduates will develop practical skill sets to work for educational organizations, businesses, nonprofit organizations, and government agencies that deal in, represent, or interact with artists and the artsâperhaps in addition to managing a freelance artistic career. Areas of study may include: arts production and performance history, appreciation, and analysis of the arts business as it relates to the arts new media and writing in the arts secondary, university, and continuing education Graduates who focus on MUSIC will be prepared to pursue careers at music studios, radio stations, concert halls, arts councils, hotels, resorts, cruise lines, amusement and theme parks, and entertainment law firms. Possible positions include music administrator, promoter, music marketing or operating manager, manager for entertainment and media, music producer, event staff, consulting, studio and/or recording artist. Graduates who focus on THEATRE will be prepared to pursue careers at theatre houses, acting conservatories, equity playhouses, film/tv production companies, arts councils, cruise lines, amusement and theme parks, and entertainment law firms. Possible positions include actors/actresses, motivational speakers, voice-over artists, acting coaches, drama therapists, casting agents, production assistants, directors, stage managers, dramaturgs, designers (scenic, lighting, costume, etc.), producers, box office managers, press agents, and public relations specialists. Graduates who focus on ART HISTORY and VISUAL ART will seek positions at museums, (academic or commercial) art galleries, serve as art dealers, art critics, writers related in art and culture subjects in newspapers and magazines, lectures for travel and government organizations, and consulting for dealers and collectors. They are practically trained to organize (academic and commercial) exhibitions, to write exhibition catalogues (entries and essays), exhibition captions, and promoting/marketing works of art. text: Learning Support Profession (LSP) | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Learning Support Professional (LSP) Home Pathways and Programs Education LSP Learning Support Professionals Pathway Map to Employment Careers in the education field can be diverse and unique, depending on how you want to serve students. The Learning Support Profession (LSP) program of study (POS) is designed for individuals interested in addressing students' social, emotional, and psychological needs through roles such as school counselors, psychologists, and social workers. High school students enrolled in the LSP POS will have the chance to lay the groundwork for these vital career paths by exploring the roles and responsibilities involved, along with work-based learning opportunities. The map below illustrates various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting from high school and leading to employment within the state.; The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the Learning Support Professional program of study in high school, you will be introduced to key concepts, gain a comprehensive understanding of the field, and have the opportunity to explore education through work-based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. Pursuing a career as a school counselor, school psychologist, or school social worker will require further education depending on your chosen path, often necessitating schooling beyond a bachelor's degree. While additional training is needed, you may be able to obtain entry-level certifications or complete courses that will allow you to work in the field immediately after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview : The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey : If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement : As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.title: Education Teaching as a Profession Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Education Teaching as a Profession Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Learning Support Profession ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi There are several benefits to obtaining entry-level training programs or certifications to further your journey to a career as a learning support professional. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. Here are a few reasons why obtaining one or more of theses certifications would help you on your path to working in the education field: Enhanced Knowledge and Skills : Entry-level certifications and training provide you with foundational knowledge and skills related to education. This can give you a head start in understanding basic concepts and pedagogy, making it easier to grasp more advanced teaching concepts during your studies. Practical Experience : Entry-level certifications and training can provide you with exposure to classroom settings, allowing you to become familiar with the different teaching environments, and understanding age and grade level teaching preferences. Professional Capacity Building Opportunities : Obtaining entry-level certifications and training can help you build connections and peer relationships with teachers and administrators. Capacity building within the education field will allow you to enhance and develop your knowledge, skills and stay updated on new pedagogical approaches, technologies, and curriculum changes in local schools systems. Improved Employability : Possessing entry-level certification and training can make you more competitive in the job market and increase your chances of finding employment as a teacher in the location, grade level and content area of your choice. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for careers in education can vary depending on the specific role and grade level you want to teach. Here are some common entry-level training options for careers in education: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification : High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for education professionals. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Mental Health Technician : Mental health is just as important as physical health when it comes to a person's overall well-being. Mental health technicians care for patients with mental or emotional conditions or disabilities. Acting under a health practitioner's order, technicians monitor a patient's physical and emotional health; observe and sometimes interact, teach, counsel, or support the patient; restrain patients when needed; and assist patients with their daily tasks such as bathing and cleaning. Range of program duration: 1 to 2 semesters Registered Behavior Technician : Registered Behavior Technician (RBT) training prepares participants to meet all criteria to be eligible to become a nationally recognized RBT, a paraprofessional certified in behavior analysis. RBTs assist in delivering behavior-analytic services and practice under the direction and close supervision of an RBT Supervisor and/or an RBT Requirements Coordinator, who are responsible for all work RBTs perform. RBT certification was originally designed for settings in which a BCBA or BCaBA is already providing behavior-analytic services. Thus, applying to become an RBT is most likely to occur after the applicant has been employed by the organization in which they will continue their work assisting qualified BCBAs and/or BCaBAs in their service-delivery activities. This course includes a job shadowing experience during the last two weeks. Range of program duration: 5 weeks Theses training programs can lead to the following Jobs: Educational Assistant (HIDOE) Skill Trainer Communication Aid (HIDOE) Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Any Community College | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Any Community College Associate of Arts - Liberal Arts Degree Home Pathways and Programs Education Any CC Program Description: Students aspiring to become school counselors, school social workers, or school psychologists can start their journey at any community college by enrolling in a Liberal Arts degree program. This program allows students to complete the first two years of their general education in the supportive and smaller environment of a community college. Afterward, they can transfer to a four-year university to pursue their bachelorâs degree. All five University of Hawaiâi community colleges offer this degree path, providing a solid foundation for students aiming for careers in educational support services. Choosing to attend a community college to earn an associate's degree in Liberal Arts before transferring to a university can be a great idea for several reasons: Cost Savings: Lower Tuition: Community colleges generally have significantly lower tuition costs compared to universities. Starting at a community college can save you and your family a lot of money. Living Expenses: Many students can live at home while attending community college, which further reduces costs. Smaller Class Sizes: Personal Attention: Community colleges often have smaller class sizes, which means you can get more personal attention from your instructors. This can be particularly helpful as you adjust to college-level coursework. Better Support: With smaller classes, you'll have more opportunities to ask questions and get help, which can lead to a stronger academic foundation. Flexibility: Part-Time Options: Community colleges often offer flexible schedules, including part-time options and evening classes. This can be beneficial if you need to work while studying. Exploring Interests: The Liberal Arts program allows you to explore various subjects such as literature, history, psychology, and the arts, helping you decide what you might want to major in when you transfer to a university. Smooth Transition to University: Transfer Agreements: The University of Hawaiâi community colleges have transfer agreements with the three University of Hawaiâi campuses, making it easier to transfer credits. This ensures that the courses you take will count toward your bachelorâs degree. Transfer Assistance: Community colleges have advisors specifically to help students plan their transfer to a university, ensuring you take the right courses and meet all requirements. Career Exploration: Career Services: Many community colleges offer career services, including counseling and job placement, which can help you explore different career options and gain practical experience. Cost and time commitment: Associate in Arts Degree (AA Liberal Arts) Approximate number of credits: 60 Approximate AA Liberal Arts program tuition costs: $7,860 Estimated AA Liberal Arts program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 2 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree general program related requirements for all University of Hawaiâi Community College, AA Liberal Arts degree programs. Program related courses: PSY 100: Survey of Psychology Prerequisite: Check institution pages for campus specific prerequisites HWST 107: Hawaiâi: Center of the Pacific Prerequisite: Check institution pages for campus specific prerequisites *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment at this institution. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. subcontent.text: Any Bachelor Degree | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Any Bachelor Degree Home Pathways and Programs Education Program Description: Students aspiring to become school counselors, school social workers, or school psychologists will typically need to earn a Master's Degree. To reach this level, they must first obtain a bachelor's degree. A student can choose from a variety of bachelorâs degree programs offered at four-year universities. Applying for a master's degree with a bachelor's degree in any field is advantageous due to several key factors: Interdisciplinary Nature of Many Graduate Programs: Many master's programs are designed to accommodate students from diverse academic backgrounds. These programs often focus on building specialized knowledge and skills, which can be acquired regardless of the student's undergraduate field. Foundation and Prerequisite Courses: Graduate programs sometimes offer foundational or prerequisite courses to bridge any gaps in knowledge. This allows students without specific undergraduate training to catch up on necessary concepts early in their master's program. Holistic Admissions Criteria: Admissions committees consider a range of factors beyond the undergraduate major, such as work experience, letters of recommendation, personal statements, and standardized test scores (like the GRE or GMAT). This holistic approach recognizes that a student's potential and aptitude for the graduate program can be demonstrated through various means. Skill Transferability: Many skills acquired in one discipline are transferable to another. Critical thinking, research, writing, and problem-solving are examples of skills that are valuable across many fields of study. Thus, students from diverse academic backgrounds can succeed in graduate programs that value these skills. Program-Specific Requirements: While some master's programs have specific prerequisites, many do not. Programs that do have prerequisites might allow students to complete these requirements during the early stages of the master's program or through additional coursework. Cost and time commitment: Bachelor Degree (BA/BS) Approximate number of credits: 120-160 Approximate BA/BS program tuition costs: $56,520 Estimated BA/BS program length:  (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester)  4-4.5 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree general program related requirements for most bachelor degree programs. subcontent.text: Chaminade University (BS) Secondary Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Master in Counseling Psychology Home Pathways Education LSP Master in Counseling Program Description (Graduate Level): The American Psychological Association defines counseling psychology as encompassing âa broad range of culturally sensitive practices that help people improve their well-being, alleviate distress and maladjustment, resolve crises, and increase their ability to function better.â We couldnât have said it better ourselves. Our program is aimed at preparing graduates for tough but rewarding practice-based work in communities and schools, helping children and adults adapt to educational, work-related, family-based or societyâs demands and problems associated with emotional and mental disorders. Put another way, our graduates help peopleâevery dayâlead happier, more fulfilling lives. We offer two concentrations: Mental Health Counseling and School Counseling. Mental Health - Students who complete this concentration will be able to: Identify core counseling theories, principles, concepts, techniques and facts. Identify counseling theories, principles, concepts, techniques and facts in mental health counseling. Facilitate the counseling process with clients. Identify the relationship between adaptation and change and the counseling process. School Counseling - Students who complete this concentration will be able to: Identify core counseling theories, principles, concepts, techniques and facts. Identify counseling theories, principles, concepts, techniques and facts in school counseling. Facilitate the counseling process with clients. Identify the relationship between adaptation and change and the counseling process. Apply Now Contact (808) 739-8340 graduate@chaminade.edu Program Prerequisites: This GRADUATE level program requires applying students to have at least a bachelor degree. Hold at least a baccalaureate or masterâs degree (depending on the program of interest) from a regionally accredited college/university in the U.S. or equivalent from a foreign institution Be proficient in English Submit application and application fee* Submit official transcripts (Undergraduate transcripts) Upon receipt of the completed graduate application file, all applicants will participate in a formal interview with a member of the MSCP faculty. If deemed necessary, a second interview with the Program Director and/or another MSCP faculty member may be required. If the completed graduate application file is not received in a timely manner, this will delay the interview process, thus delaying the applicantâs possible entry into the program. subcontent.text:
Education Teaching as a Profession Early Childhood Education Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us TEACHING AS A PROFESSION Elementary/middle/High School
			    ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi There are several benefits to obtaining entry-level training programs or certifications to further your journey to a career in Education. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. Here are a few reasons why obtaining one or more of theses certifications would help you on your path to working in the education field: Enhanced Knowledge and Skills : Entry-level certifications and training provide you with foundational knowledge and skills related to education. This can give you a head start in understanding basic concepts and pedagogy, making it easier to grasp more advanced teaching concepts during your studies. Practical Experience : Entry-level certifications and training can provide you with exposure to classroom settings, allowing you to become familiar with the different teaching environments, and understanding age and grade level teaching preferences. Professional Capacity Building Opportunities : Obtaining entry-level certifications and training can help you build connections and peer relationships with teachers and administrators. Capacity building within the education field will allow you to enhance and develop your knowledge, skills and stay updated on new pedagogical approaches, technologies, and curriculum changes in local schools systems. Improved Employability : Possessing entry-level certification and training can make you more competitive in the job market and increase your chances of finding employment as a teacher in the location, grade level and content area of your choice. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for careers in education can vary depending on the specific role and grade level you want to teach. Here are some common entry-level training options for careers in education: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification : High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for education professionals. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Parapro Assessment : The ParaPro Assessment is a computer-based assessment option for Educational Assistants (EA) and part-time Paraprofessional Tutors (PPT) to meet Department of Education minimum qualifications for employment.  The exam is designed to assess the knowledge and skills of prospective and practicing paraprofessionals in the education system.  There are study guides available for this approximately 2 and a half hour test that covers reading, writing and math competencies.  For more information, visit the ParaPro Assessment . Range of program duration: Test is 90 questions and takes approximately 2 and a half hours to complete. Substitute Teacher Certification Course : A substitute teacher is an individual who temporarily takes on the responsibilities of a regular classroom teacher when the teacher is absent. Substitute teachers step in to facilitate the learning process in the absence of the regular teacher and ensure that the educational environment continues to function smoothly.  With a high school diploma or equivalency, upon successful completion of a Substitute Teaching Certification program from a state-approved teacher education (SATE) program, interested participants can apply to be a substitute teacher for the State of HawaiÊ»i Department of Education . Range of program duration: 6 weeks Registered Behavioral Technician Training Credential: A person with a RBT credential can provide one-to one behavioral intervention services to students with special needs during the school day in academic and non-academic related activities and performs other related duties as assigned. The training to become and RBT covers measurement, assessment, skill acquisition, behavior reduction, documentation and reporting, and professional conduct and scope of practice. In addition to the 40-hour training, students will complete a competency assessment administered by a Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA), which involves an interview and direct observation of competencies based on the RBT Task List. Upon completion of this course, students will be eligible to apply for the RBT examination for their RBT credential. For more information visit the RBT credential exam. Range of program duration: 40 hours of training, 90 minutes of the exam Theses training programs can lead to the following Jobs: Educational Assistant (HIDOE) Behavioral Technician (HIDOE) Part-time Paraprofessional Tutors (PPT, in HIDOE) Teachers Aid Substitue Teacher (HIDOE) After School care worker Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. We aim to provide a collaborative and learner-centered environment that welcomes students from all backgrounds. The Associates of Science (AS) degree provides a broad set of generalist skills needed for entry-level positions in Human Services, Social Work, and Public Health. Specialized Certificates of Competence (9-15 credits) and a Certificate of Achievement (30 credits) are available for majors and those in the workforce seeking career change or advancement. Specializations include Aging, Case Management, Community Health, Family Violence, Substance Use Disorder, and Youth Development. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Elementary Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Social Work Home Pathways Education Social Work Program Description: The mission of the Department of Social Work is to provide educational excellence that advances social work with its focus on social justice. The principal responsibility is the generation, transmission, and application of knowledge for the global enterprise with special attention to Native Hawaiian, other Pacific Islander, and Asian populations in our state and region. We are proud to offer the only Bachelor of Social Work (BSW) Distance Education (DE) Option program in the state of HawaiÊ»i. The DE Option provides increased access for students who would otherwise be unable to pursue a social work degree due to geographical or scheduling barriers. PK-3/K-6 courses are offered face to face, with two days per week of courses and two days per week of assigned fieldwork. Courses are scheduled within the standard UHM semester. Our BSW program is available on a part-time or full-time schedule to all state of HawaiÊ»i students who have completed their General Education Core Requirements. Students complete the program while remaining in their home community (HawaiÊ»i, MolokaÊ»i, KauaÊ»i, Maui, LanaÊ»i, or OÊ»ahu). Most classes are delivered asynchronously online and in a condensed 5-week format while the Field Education requirements are fulfilled in community agencies, under the supervision of certified social workers. Graduates through the DE Option are awarded a BSW degree from the University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa after meeting all program requirements, including field education. The University of HawaiÊ»i (UH) awards a Master of Social Work (MSW) degree. Students may complete their degree requirements through a full-time or part-time program. The program requires 57 credit hours of course work to be completed within a four-year period, including four semesters of field education (practicum) and completion of the advanced research requirement (Plan B: Non-Thesis). The MSW curriculum of the Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health has been developed to both reflect and promote the advances of contemporary social work practice. Curriculum design and materials incorporate theory and practice approaches that have been developed throughout the country as well as those that have been created by faculty and practitioners to meet local and Pacific/Asian needs. Apply Now Pre-Social Work Advising bswadvis@hawaii.edu (808) 956-7182 Program Prerequisites: The UH Manoa BSW has Selected Admissions. This means that the following will need to be completed PRIOR to applying for the BSW program: Have been admitted (or be in the process of being admitted) to the University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa Have completed (or be in the process of completing) the University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa general education core requirements Have completed (or be in the process of completing) the knowledge-base requirement courses identified by the BSW Program with a grade of C or better Complete UHM General Education Core Requirements prior to the start of program. Applicants who have completed an articulated Associates of Arts (AA) degree from a UH Community College are considered to have met the UHM General Education Core Requirements with possible exceptions (see an academic advisor). Provide evidence of motivation for and commitment to social work (e.g., personal, volunteer, and/or social work-related experience) Once you have completed the general education requirements: You will complete the SocialWorkCAS application, including: âPersonal Informationâ section Three (3) Reference Requests (letters of recommendation) via âSupporting Informationâ section In âAcademic Historyâ section Complete âColleges Attendedâ Then upload unofficial transcript for each college attended In âProgram Materialsâ section Respond to all required questions via the âQuestionsâ tab Submit all required documents via the âDocumentsâ tab. Resume BSW Program Application: Courses in Progress/Planning to Take Form Cost and time commitment: Bachelors of Social Work: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total program tuition costs: $56,520 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status 15-18 credits per semester) 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree general program related requirements for the UH Manoa BSW program. Program Related Courses: POLS 110: Introduction to Political Science Prerequisite: Accepted to UH Manoa SW 200: Introduction to Field of Social Work Prerequisite: Accepted to UH Manoa HPSY 100: Survey of Psychology Prerequisite: Accepted to UH Manoa BIOL 171: Introduction to Biology I Prerequisite: Accepted to UH Manoa *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment at this institution. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. subcontent.text: Hawaiâi Pacific University Social Work Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Social Work Home Pathways Education Social Work Program Description: BSW: For some, "making the world a better place" is not an idealistic slogan, but a goal and a passion. If you are such a person and want to learn methods of solving problems effectively with people, you should consider a degree in social work. Some ways to help others are direct, one-to-one counseling with individual clients and families; and others are indirect, such as developing organizations and communities. Social work is a broad profession that tries to understand how individuals, groups, and communities are affected by social problems such as poverty, mental and physical illness, family difficulties, and social injustice. Social workers are employed in a variety of settings such as hospitals, schools, the legislature, and social welfare agencies that address the needs of children, adults, and elders. Wherever they find themselves, social workers use their skills to empower others to help themselves and change unresponsive social systems. The HawaiÊ»i Pacific UniversityÊ»s Bachelor of Social Work program helps students to develop the necessary knowledge, values and skills to help "make the world a better place." MSW: The online Master of Social Work (MSW) from Hawaiâi Pacific University prepares aspiring social work leaders who are drawn toward learning about multicultural social work practice and/or military/veteran social issues. It is recognized that social justice and healing are the backbone of social work. As such, the faculty view social work â in the context of this program â as an embodied practice that challenges the status quo. When you earn your Master in Social Work online from Hawaiâi Pacific University, youâll graduate prepared to pursue licensure, become a fierce advocate for social and economic justice, and empower diverse communities affected by systemic inequities. An Advanced Standing track is available for applicants who earned a Bachelor of Social Work within the last five years. Hawaiâi Pacific University School of Social Work Apply Now BSW Program Chair Bachelor of Social Work Vince Okuda, PHD Assistant Professor (808) 236-5845 vokada@hpu.edu MSW Program Chair Master in Social Work Danielle Giroux, PHD, MSW Assistant Professor (808) 566-3521 dgiroux@hpu.edu Program Prerequisites: All students interested in HPUÊ»s BSW program must apply to HPU Admissions and The School of Social Work separately: Submit HPU Student Application to HPU Admissions Once accepted to HPU, students must reach âjuniorâ status (60 credits) by the term you would be admitted if accepted to the Social Work program. You must have received a "C" or higher in the prerequisites (Introduction to Sociology, Introduction to Psychology, Introduction to Social Work courses, and a Writing course) and you must have an overall GPA of 2.75 or higher Once âjuniorâ status has been reached and you have completed the program prerequisites, you then complete the BSW Application and submit by the due date posted For the MSW: Applicants to the Master of Social Work must submit the following materials to apply: Online application RÃ©sumÃ© (optional, but can help with practicum placement) Bachelor degree transcripts: Transcripts must be submitted from all postsecondary institutions. Unofficial transcripts can be submitted for application review. Official transcripts must be submitted within the first semester of entry. Two letters of recommendation (academic and/or professional) Essay that states your purpose in undertaking graduate study at Hawaiâi Pacific University Cost and time commitment: Total Credits for graduation for the BSW: 120 For Tuition and Fee information Please visit the HPUÊ»s Website Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. Students in the teaching as a profession program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into the field of education with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the Teaching as a Profession program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore education through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in Teaching will require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training is required, you may be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview : The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey : If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement : As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.title: Education Teaching as a Profession Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Education Teaching as a Profession Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us TEACHING AS A PROFESSION ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi There are several benefits to obtaining entry-level training programs or certifications to further your journey to a career in Education. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. Here are a few reasons why obtaining one or more of theses certifications would help you on your path to working in the education field: Enhanced Knowledge and Skills : Entry-level certifications and training provide you with foundational knowledge and skills related to education. This can give you a head start in understanding basic concepts and pedagogy, making it easier to grasp more advanced teaching concepts during your studies. Practical Experience : Entry-level certifications and training can provide you with exposure to classroom settings, allowing you to become familiar with the different teaching environments, and understanding age and grade level teaching preferences. Professional Capacity Building Opportunities : Obtaining entry-level certifications and training can help you build connections and peer relationships with teachers and administrators. Capacity building within the education field will allow you to enhance and develop your knowledge, skills and stay updated on new pedagogical approaches, technologies, and curriculum changes in local schools systems. Improved Employability : Possessing entry-level certification and training can make you more competitive in the job market and increase your chances of finding employment as a teacher in the location, grade level and content area of your choice. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for careers in education can vary depending on the specific role and grade level you want to teach. Here are some common entry-level training options for careers in education: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification : High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for education professionals. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours PACE : Early Childhood Education Only: The PACE Program workshops provide the teacher training hours required for the CDA (Child Development Associate) Credential. The CDA credential plus one year teaching work experience in an Early Childhood Program qualifies candidates for an entry level position as a teacher. For those with no work experience a limited number of paid internships may be available. Range of program duration: 144 hours Parapro Assessment : The ParaPro Assessment is a computer-based assessment option for Educational Assistants (EA) and part-time Paraprofessional Tutors (PPT) to meet Department of Education minimum qualifications for employment.  The exam is designed to assess the knowledge and skills of prospective and practicing paraprofessionals in the education system.  There are study guides available for this approximately 2 and a half hour test that covers reading, writing and math competencies.  For more information, visit the ParaPro Assessment . Range of program duration: Test is 90 questions and takes approximately 2 and a half hours to complete. Substitute Teacher Certification Course : A substitute teacher is an individual who temporarily takes on the responsibilities of a regular classroom teacher when the teacher is absent. Substitute teachers step in to facilitate the learning process in the absence of the regular teacher and ensure that the educational environment continues to function smoothly.  With a high school diploma or equivalency, upon successful completion of a Substitute Teaching Certification program from a state-approved teacher education (SATE) program, interested participants can apply to be a substitute teacher for the State of HawaiÊ»i Department of Education . Range of program duration: 6 weeks Registered Behavioral Technician Training Credential :  A person with a RBT credential can provide one-to one behavioral intervention services to students with special needs during the school day in academic and non-academic related activities and performs other related duties as assigned. The training to become and RBT covers measurement, assessment, skill acquisition, behavior reduction, documentation and reporting, and professional conduct and scope of practice. In addition to the 40-hour training, students will complete a competency assessment administered by a Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA), which involves an interview and direct observation of competencies based on the RBT Task List. Upon completion of this course, students will be eligible to apply for the RBT examination for their RBT credential. Learn more information about the RBT credential exam. Range of program duration: 40 hours of training, 90 minutes of the exam Theses training programs can lead to the following Jobs: Preschool Teaching Assistant Teachers Aid Paraprofessional Tutor (PPT, in HIDOE) Educational Assistant (HIDOE) Behavioral Technician (HIDOE) Substitute Teacher (HIDOE) After School care worker Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. Hawaii Career Pathways builds bridges between schools and industries so students can get training and education for high-skill, high-wage professions. subcontent.text: Kauaâi Community College Early Childhood Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Early Childhood Education (ECED) Home Pathways Education ECED Program Description: This program prepares students with the knowledge, skills, and dispositions needed to work collaboratively with young children and families in various professional capacities. The training that students receive blends theory and practice through coursework and hands-on experiences in the real world of a preschool program preparing them to become preschool teachers, assistant teachers and/or to pursue a Bachelor's degree. There are several pathways that students graduating with the AS can follow within the State of HawaiÊ»i. Students may continue to UH West OÊ»ahu Bachelor in Social Science in Early Childhood Education, or UH Manoa Bachelor of Education in Elementary and Early Childhood Education or in Early Childhood and Special Education. Students who plan to transfer are strongly encouraged to seek academic advising upon admission to KauaÊ»i Community College. Apply Now Program Coordinator Antonia (Toni) Fontanilla Fujimoto Program Coordinator (808) 245-8373 antoniaf@hawaii.edu ECED Counselor Shelley R. Sutter Program Counselor (808) 245-8257 shelley3@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: To be admitted to the Early Childhood Education Program students must first: Be qualified for ENG 100 By the beginning of the second semester, students must: Pass the fingerprinting and background check required by the State of HawaiÊ»i Department of Human Services for individuals working with young children (fee required) Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Additional fees: Up to $50 per semester Total number of credits: 60 Approximate total program tuition costs: Approximately $8,060 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on full time status 12 to 15 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree pre-program requirements for the KauaÊ»i Community College ECED program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100 Composition I *Prerequisite - Placement into ENG 100 MATH 100: Survey of Mathematics *Prerequisite - âCâ or better in MATH 75X or 82X, OR placement into MATH 100 HWST 107: Hawaiian Piko *Prerequisite - Placement into ENG 100S PSY 100: Survey of Psychology *Prerequisite - None Program Specific Courses: HDFS 230: Human Development *Prerequisite - Placement into ENG 100 ECED 105 - Introduction to Early Childhood Education *Prerequisite - Placement into ENG 100 ECED 110 - Developmentally Appropriate Practices *Prerequisite - Placement into ENG 100 *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)* or Memorandum of Agreement (MOA): Students who complete the KauaÊ»i Community CollegeÊ»s Early Childhood Education Associate's degree program can apply via a transfer agreement with the 4-year university programs listed below. University of HawaiÊ»i West OÊ»ahu - Bachelors of Arts in Social Science with a concentration in Early Childhood Education University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa - Bachelors of Education, Elementary & Early Childhood Education ( Articulation Agreement - Fall 2019 ) Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. Early Childhood Education degree prepares students to work with young children from birth to 5 and their families. The curriculum is designed to be a full-time, 2-year (minimum 62 credits) program and is organized around a core of courses that provide skills and knowledge needed by early childhood educators. The Associate of Science (A.S.) Early Childhood Education program at the University of HawaiÊ»i Maui College is accredited by the Commission on the Accreditation of Early Childhood Higher Education Programs of the National Association for the Education of Young Children . The current accreditation term runs from July 2015 through July 2022. This degree articulates to the University of HawaiÊ»i West OÊ»ahu Bachelor in Education, Early Childhood Education concentration and the University of HawaiÊ»i MÄnoa Early Childhood Ed/Special Education Bachelor's degree programs. Students with a current CDA (Child Development Associate) credential (without ECED 193/4 credit) may apply for 4 credits of ECED 193/194 Early Childhood Field Experience 1A/1B after taking 12 credits of UHMC courses. See the Prior Learning Assessment section of the UHMC Catalog for more information and make an appointment with the program coordinator to initiate the process. Apply Now Program Coordinator Julie Powers Program Coordinator (808) 984-3291 juliepow@hawaii.edu ECED Counselor Eri Nomura ECED Counselor (808) 984-3306 eri4@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply to UH Maui College Once you have been accepted, contact the program coordinator or counselor for academic advising. Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Additional fees: $50 - $150 per semester Total number of credits: 62 - 63 Approximate total program tuition costs: ~ $8,322 - $8,853 Estimated program length (based on full time student status): 2 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the UH Maui CollegeÊ»s ECED program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus.
