subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Elementary & Early Childhood Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Elementary & Early Childhood Education Home Pathways Education Elementary & Early Childhood Program Description: Become a PK-3 Elementary School Teacher The Bachelor of Education degree in Early Childhood and Elementary Education (ECE) prepares knowledgeable, effective, and caring teachers of young children ages 3-8 years old. Graduates of the ECE program possess specialized knowledge and skills in serving the developmental needs of preschool and primary aged children and their families in early childhood education and care programs. The program provides âdual preparation,â leading to a Bachelor of Education (BEd) degree in both Early Childhood (PK-3) and Elementary education (K-6). Dual preparation graduates complete all the requirements of the elementary education majors plus an additional 18 credits in early childhood education. PK-3/K-6 courses are offered face to face, with two days per week of courses and two days per week of assigned fieldwork. Courses are scheduled within the standard UHM semester. Apply Now Program Contact Shin Ae Han sahan@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Acceptance into UH MÄnoa 2.75 GPA or higher Complete 55 credits prior to beginning the program. The 55 credits can be from UHM and/or approved transfer credits from another institution. Complete UHM General Education Core Requirements prior to the start of program. Applicants who have completed an articulated Associates of Arts (AA) degree from a UH Community College are considered to have met the UHM General Education Core Requirements with possible exceptions (see an academic advisor). Complete Licensure Track Prerequisite Courses MATH 111 MATH 112 (FS) MUS 253, THEA 470, DNCE 490 or any other (DA) course HWST 107 (DH) HDFS 230 or PSY 240 (DS) SPED 304 (DS) STE 360 or EDEF 360 Complete 40 hours of paid or voluntary group leadership field experience with K-6th grade students. The experience cannot have occurred more than 5 years prior to acceptance into the program. Interview with the program Write a personal statement Provide Three (3) Professional References Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Additional fees: $50 - $150 per semester Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total program tuition costs: ~ $57,720 Estimated program length (based on full time student status): 4 years total, 2 years for general education requirements or Associate Degree, 2 year for the BEd coursework. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at West Oâahu Social Science with Concentration in Early Childhood Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Social Science with concentration in Early Childhood Education Home Pathways Education Social Science with  Early Childhood Program Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences with a concentration in Early Childhood Education program focuses on Early Childhood Education (birth through age eight) from a theoretical orientation and places the field within broader social, historical, political, and cultural contexts. Coursework in other areas of the social sciences provides a foundation for students to critically examine early education and childcare. Early Childhood Education students will examine how parents and other family members work collaboratively with teachers to build a learning and home environment that stimulates curiosity through informal educational opportunities. The principles of quality education, multiculturalism, critical thinking, and reflective teaching are infused in all major coursework. The courses are designed to build a strong sense of social justice while also educating all students from diverse backgrounds and inspiring teachers as agents of change. Courses are taught in-class and through distance learning instruction, and in partnership with associateâs degree programs in Early Childhood Education at HawaiÊ»i Community College, Honolulu Community College, KauaÊ»i Community College, and UH Maui College. At minimum, students who wish to enter UH West OÊ»ahu âs Bachelor of Arts in Social Science degree program with a concentration in Early Childhood Education must be eligible for transfer admission by the time of application and should complete the 32 credits of ECED Core and the prerequisite coursework in Math and English required for the BA program prior to transfer. Conferral of a Bachelor of Arts degree in Social Sciences with a concentration in Early Childhood Education does not result in professional licensure. Apply Now Program Contact Brooke Rehmann rehmann@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Acceptance into UH West OÊ»ahu Complete and AS degree  OR 32 credits of the Early Childhood Education core courses at one of the following UH community colleges: HawaiÊ»i CC, AS in Early Childhood Education Honolulu CC, AS in Early Childhood Education KauaÊ»i CC, AS in Early Childhood Education UH Maui College, AS in Early Childhood Education Complete prerequisite courses in Math and English prior to transferring to UHWO. Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $306 Additional fees: $120 per semester Total number of credits: 120 total, 48-60 credits done at UHWO Approximate total program tuition costs: ~ $15,168 to $18,840 Estimated program length (based on full time student status): 2 years of coursework completed at UHWO. Time to complete AS in ECED may vary, please check the UHCC campus pages for more information. Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the UH West OÊ»ahuÊ»s BA in Social Science with a concentration in Early Childhood Education program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree program requirements and can be taken through UH Community Colleges: General Academic Courses: ENG 100 Composition I *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites MATH 111: Math for Elementary Teachers *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites HWST 107: Hawaiian Piko *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites Program Specific Courses: ECED 105 - Introduction to Early Childhood Education *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites ECED 110 - Developmentally Appropriate Practices *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites HDFS 230: Human Development *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)* or Memorandum of Agreement (MOA): Students who have completed an articulated A.S. in Early Childhood Education degree from a UH Community College can transfer to UH West OÊ»ahuâs BA in Social Science ECED through an articulation agreement (seeing an academic advisor is highly recommended to ensure correct courses are being taken). Articulated programs include: Associate in Science in Early Childhood Education from Maui College Associate in Science in Early Childhood Education from Honolulu Community College Associate in Science in Early Childhood Education from Kauai Community College Associate in Science in Early Childhood Education from Hawaii Community College Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. subcontent.text: Chaminade University (BS) Early Childhood Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Early Childhood Education (ECED) BachelorÊ»s Degree Home Pathways Education ECED Program Description: Across the state and nation, early childhood education teachers are in high demandâand thereâs little wonder why. It takes incredibly special people to work with the youngest students. Youâve got to be patient, caring and warm. Youâve got to know how to embrace the chaos, realize that fancy clothes are overrated and be ready to deal with tears and infectious gigglesâsometimes all at once. And, most importantly, youâve got to be able to make learning fun and engaging with lessons that strengthen cognitive, emotional and physical development. In other words, working in early childhood education isnât easy. But the rewards are priceless. Study after study has shown the critical importance of high-quality early learning programs in building the foundations for success in school and in career. In other words, a robust early learning program can change a childâs life. As an early childhood educator, youâll have the awesome responsibilityâand the incredible privilegeâto create positive, stimulating and practice-informed learning experiences for young children. Your mission: Instill children with a joy to learn. That, of course, is no small task. But weâll help you get there. Our Early Childhood Education bachelorâs degree is aligned with state requirements and National Association for the Education of Young Children standards. Our ECE major is also flexible, offered through online courses that allow you to fit instruction into a busy schedule. And of course, our program offers robust student supports and stresses hands-on learning. Apply Now Program Coordinator Elizabeth Park Program Coordinator (808) 735-4859 epark@chaminade.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to Chaminade University Competition of pre-program courses Cost and time commitment: Starting in Fall 2023, Chaminade Universityâs HawaiÊ»i Guarantee provides local high school graduates entering as freshmen the same tuition rate as University of Hawaiâi at Manoaâs annual resident undergraduate tuition AND an achievable pathway to graduate in four years. Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the Chaminade University. This statement must be a minimum of 250 words. subcontent.text: Education Teaching as a Profession Early Childhood Education Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us TEACHING AS A PROFESSION Early Childhood Education ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi There are several benefits to obtaining entry-level training programs or certifications to further your journey to a career in Education. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. Here are a few reasons why obtaining one or more of theses certifications would help you on your path to working in the education field: Enhanced Knowledge and Skills : Entry-level certifications and training provide you with foundational knowledge and skills related to education. This can give you a head start in understanding basic concepts and pedagogy, making it easier to grasp more advanced teaching concepts during your studies. Practical Experience : Entry-level certifications and training can provide you with exposure to classroom settings, allowing you to become familiar with the different teaching environments, and understanding age and grade level teaching preferences. Professional Capacity Building Opportunities : Obtaining entry-level certifications and training can help you build connections and peer relationships with teachers and administrators. Capacity building within the education field will allow you to enhance and develop your knowledge, skills and stay updated on new pedagogical approaches, technologies, and curriculum changes in local schools systems. Improved Employability : Possessing entry-level certification and training can make you more competitive in the job market and increase your chances of finding employment as a teacher in the location, grade level and content area of your choice. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for careers in education can vary depending on the specific role and grade level you want to teach. Here are some common entry-level training options for careers in education: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification : High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for education professionals. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours PACE : Early Childhood Education Only: The PACE Program workshops provide the teacher training hours required for the CDA (Child Development Associate) Credential. The CDA credential plus one year teaching work experience in an Early Childhood Program qualifies candidates for an entry level position as a teacher. For those with no work experience a limited number of paid internships may be available.  For more information, visit Honolulu Community CollegeÊ»s website . Range of program duration: 144 hours Theses training programs can lead to the following Jobs: Preschool Teaching Assistant Early Childhood Teachers Aid Childcare worker Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. Some programs may prefer or require applicants to have relevant experience working with children in educational settings or to have completed some relevant coursework. This could include volunteer work, tutoring, or other related experiences to be completed PRIOR to beginning the program required courses. The basic admissions requirements can include: Course prerequisites : Some programs have specific prerequisite coursework that must be completed before applying. These prerequisites usually include general education requirements such as MATH 111 or HDFS 230, these will vary by program and campus (see campus program page for more details). GPA requirements : Some programs have minimum GPA requirements that students must meet with all prerequisite courses. These requirements can vary per campus. Application process : Certain programs will have a detailed set of application requirements such as submitting a written personal statement, and professional reference letters or interviewing with the program. Field or work experience : Some programs also prioritize applicants with relevant internships or work experience in a classroom setting. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to select an education program, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs in education: KapiÊ»olani Community College, AAS in Liberal Arts with concentration in Elemetary Education, Secondary Education or Second Language Teaching KapiÊ»olani Community College, ASNS with a concentration in STEM Education Leeward Community College, Associate of Science in Teaching Honolulu Community College, Associate of Science in Early Childhood Education KauaÊ»i Community College, Associate of Science in Early Childhood Education HawaiÊ»i Community College, Associate of Science in Early Childhood Education UH Maui College, Associate of Science in Early Childhood Education * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Early Childhood Education/SPED | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Early Childhood Education/ Early Childhood sped Home Pathways Education Early Childhood-SPED Program Description: This 3-for-1 program allows candidates to earn their bachelorâs degree along with two teaching licenses at the early childhood level. This cohorted program is offered statewide and is a series of coursework taken as the final two years of the bachelorâs degree in education. This emphasis prepares teachers for young children with and without disabilities in preschool through 3rd grade (PK-3) general, inclusive, or special education settings. Who should consider this program? People who: Want to teach preschool to 3rd grade general education settings, and/or Want to teach preschool to 3rd grade special education settings, and/or Want to teach in early childhood private preschool programs, and/or Want to teach in Head Start programs or other community programs This program is accessible to students on all of the islands in the state of Hawaii. Candidates are able to complete their coursework in an online/hybrid format and will be placed into a local school for field requirements. A limited number of face-to-face meetings are required each semester, where neighbor island candidates will travel to Oahu for classes on chosen weekends. As funds permit, some travel stipends are made available to students who do not live on Oahu to help offset travel costs. Apply Now Program Contact Steven Klein kleins@hawaii.edu Program Contact Michael Sheehey msheehey@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Acceptance into UH MÄnoa 2.75 GPA or higher Complete 55 credits prior to beginning the program. The 55 credits can be from UHM and/or approved transfer credits from another institution. Complete UHM General Education Core Requirements prior to the start of program. Applicants who have completed an articulated Associates of Arts (AA) degree from a UH Community College are considered to have met the UHM General Education Core Requirements with possible exceptions (see an academic advisor). Complete 40 hours of paid or voluntary group leadership field experience with PK-6th grade students. The experience cannot have occurred more than 5 years prior to acceptance into the program. Complete Licensure Track Prerequisite Courses MATH 111 MATH 112 (FS) MUS 253, THEA 470, DNCE 490 or any other (DA) course HWST 107 (DH) HDFS 230 or PSY 240 (DS) SPED 304 (DS) STE 318 (Child Development from Prenatal Through Age Eight) STE 360 or EDEF 360 Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Additional fees: $50 - $150 per semester Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total program tuition costs: ~ $57,720 Estimated program length (based on full time student status): 4 years total, 2 years for general education requirements or Associate Degree, 2 year for the BEd coursework. Visit College of Education Scholarship information Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the UH MÄnoaÊ»s BEd Early Childhood/Early Childhood Special Education program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree program requirements and can be taken through UH Community Colleges: General Academic Courses: ENG 100 Composition I *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites MATH 111: Math for Elementary Teachers *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites HWST 107: Hawaiian Piko *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites Program Specific Courses: HDFS 230: Human Development *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)* or Memorandum of Agreement (MOA): Students who have completed an articulated A.A. degree from a UH Community College are considered to have met the UH-MÄnoa General Education Core Requirements with possible exceptions (see an academic advisor). subcontent.title: Honolulu Community College Early Childhood Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Honolulu Community College Early Childhood Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Early Childhood Education (ECED) Home Pathways Education ECED Program Description: The Associate in Science (AS) degree program prepares students for immediate employment as teachers in private early childhood programs. There are two options for the AS degree program: The Early Childhood Education - Preschool Option prepares students for immediate employment as teachers in private early childhood programs for children ages 2-6 years old. The Early Childhood Education - Infant/Toddler Option prepares students for immediate employment as infant/toddler caregivers in private early childhood programs for children from birth to 3 years old. This is the only Infant/Toddler specialization degree offered in the State of Hawaiâi. The course of study leading to the AS degree is developmentally based and emphasizes observation and opportunities to participate in programs with children through class assignments and field experiences, both on campus and in the community. The program provides candidates with varied opportunities to develop their skills for working with children and families and with a general understanding of the field of early education and care. Students who successfully complete this degree may transfer to the Early Childhood Concentration in the Social Sciences Program at the University of Hawaiâi-West Oâahu. The AS degree in Early Childhood Education meets all requirements of that program for lower division coursework. Stackable Job ready certifications: Certificate of Competence Initial Early Childhood Education (CO-IECE) The Certificate of Competence for Initial Early Childhood Education is obtained by completing three courses, ECED 105, ECED 110, and ECED 131, which meet the formal training requirement of the national Child Development Associate (CDA) credential. Students must earn a grade of âCâ or higher in all courses with an ECED alpha. Certificate of Competence for an Infant-Toddler Caregiver (CO-ITC) The Certificate of Competence for an Infant-Toddler Caregiver requires a 21-credit sequence designed to meet the Department of Human Services (DHS) requirements for both coursework and work experience to become an Infant-Toddler Caregiver. Students must earn a grade of âCâ or higher in all courses with an ECED alpha These certifications offer students the ability to enter the workforce and/or continue their educational journey in Early Childhood Education. The Certificate of Competence (C.O.) or Certificate of Achievement (C.A.) prepares students for support roles in early childhood programs. An Associate in Science (A.S.) degree prepares students to be teachers or lead practitioners in early childhood programs. Students taking Laboratory or Practicum courses are required to complete and provide documentation for the following: Fingerprinting through DHS- there is a small fee Criminal History Check and Child Welfare clearances TB Clearance First Aid & CPR Training State licensing Child Care Registry This degree is fully articulated to the Bachelor of Arts in Social Science (with a concentration in Early Childhood Education) offered through the University of Hawaiâi West Oâahu via Distance Education. There are also articulation agreements with Chaminade University of Honolulu and UH Manoa. Transfers to UH Hilo should confer with the UH Hilo counselors for the most current articulation possibilities. Students interested in any of these programs are encouraged to meet with an Early Childhood advisor in their first semester to review program requirements. subcontent.text: Chaminade University (AS) Early Childhood Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Early Childhood Education (ECED) Associateâs Degree Home Pathways Education ECED Program Description: Across the state and nation, early childhood education teachers are in high demandâand thereâs little wonder why. It takes incredibly special people to work with the youngest students. Youâve got to be patient, caring and warm. Youâve got to know how to embrace the chaos, realize that fancy clothes are overrated and be ready to deal with tears and infectious gigglesâsometimes all at once. And, most importantly, youâve got to be able to make learning fun and engaging with lessons that strengthen cognitive, emotional and physical development. In other words, working in early childhood education isnât easy. But the rewards are priceless. Study after study has shown the critical importance of high-quality early learning programs in building the foundations for success in school and in career. In other words, a robust early learning program can change a childâs life. As an early childhood educator, youâll have the awesome responsibilityâand the incredible privilegeâto create positive, stimulating and practice-informed learning experiences for young children. Your mission: Instill children with a joy to learn. That, of course, is no small task. But weâll help you get there. Our Early Childhood Education ASSOCIATES degree is aligned with state requirements and National Association for the Education of Young Children standards. Our ECE major is also flexible, offered through online courses that allow you to fit instruction into a busy schedule. And of course, our program offers robust student support and stresses hands-on learning. Apply Now Program Coordinator Elizabeth Park Program Coordinator (808) 735-4859 epark@chaminade.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to Chaminade University Competition of pre-program courses Cost and time commitment: Starting in Fall 2023, Chaminade Universityâs HawaiÊ»i Guarantee provides local high school graduates entering as freshmen the same tuition rate as University of Hawaiâi at Manoaâs annual resident undergraduate tuition AND an achievable pathway to graduate in four years. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at West Oâahu Early Childhood Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Early Childhood Education Home Pathways Education Elementary & Early Childhood Program Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences with a concentration in Early Childhood Education program focuses on Early Childhood Education (birth through age eight) from a theoretical orientation and places the field within broader social, historical, political, and cultural contexts. Coursework in other areas of the social sciences provides a foundation for students to critically examine early education and childcare. Early Childhood Education students will examine how parents and other family members work collaboratively with teachers to build a learning and home environment that stimulates curiosity through informal educational opportunities. The principles of quality education, multiculturalism, critical thinking, and reflective teaching are infused in all major coursework. The courses are designed to build a strong sense of social justice while also educating all students from diverse backgrounds and inspiring teachers as agents of change. Courses are taught in-class and through distance learning instruction, and in partnership with associateâs degree programs in Early Childhood Education at HawaiÊ»i Community College, Honolulu Community College, KauaÊ»i Community College, and UH Maui College. At minimum, students who wish to enter UH West OÊ»ahu âs Bachelor of Arts in Social Science degree program with a concentration in Early Childhood Education must be eligible for transfer admission by the time of application and should complete the 32 credits of ECED Core and the prerequisite coursework in Math and English required for the BA program prior to transfer. Conferral of a Bachelor of Arts degree in Social Sciences with a concentration in Early Childhood Education does not result in professional licensure. Apply Now Program Contact Brooke Rehmann rehmann@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Acceptance into UH West OÊ»ahu Complete and AS degree OR 32 credits of the Early Childhood Education core courses at one of the following UH community colleges: HawaiÊ»i CC, AS in Early Childhood Education Honolulu CC, AS in Early Childhood Education KauaÊ»i CC, AS in Early Childhood Education UH Maui College, AS in Early Childhood Education Complete prerequisite courses in Math and English prior to transferring to UHWO. Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $306 Additional fees: $120 per semester Total number of credits: 120 total, 48-60 credits done at UHWO Approximate total program tuition costs: ~ $15,168 to $18,840 Estimated program length (based on full time student status): 2 years of coursework completed at UHWO. Time to complete AS in ECED may vary, please check the UHCC campus pages for more information. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. subcontent.text: Maui College Early Childhood Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Associate in Science in Teaching (AST) Home Pathways Education AST Program Description: Aspire to Inspire! Becoming a teacher is one of the most rewarding careers you can choose. This Teacher Education program prepares you with a solid foundation of pedagogy to teach K-12. Degree completion gets you âcareer readyâ to be hired as a highly qualified Educational Assistant or part-time teacherâ¦ or gets you started on your 4-year Education degree. If you already have a bachelorâs degree, you could become a licensed teacher in our Career and Technical Education or Special Education alternative pathway programs. The 62-credit Associate in Science in Teaching (AST) degree program seeks to improve equity and access to teacher education for underrepresented groups and non-traditional students. The program seeks to address the critical teacher shortage in the state of Hawai`i by providing quality pre-service teachers who are locally educated and culturally sensitive to schools in their own communities. The degree is considered terminal as graduates are prepared to enter the Hawai`i Department of Education (HIDOE) as highly qualified para-educators (Educational Assistants, Part-time teachers, paraprofessional tutors). The degree is also considered transfer as graduates enter bachelor's degree programs at the university level. Stackable certifications: Special Education Certificate of Competence :This 16-credit certificate will provide you with opportunities to pursue positions as paraeducators or enhance skills as already certified teachers with a focus on Special and Inclusive Education. You will be equipped with the skills to plan, and deliver general curriculum that is inclusive of children with disabilities, as well as gain the knowledge for assessing developmental milestones and applying evidence-based practices to assess student learning. As part of this certification of competence, students will take ED 143: Registered Behavioral Technician Training (RBT) Credential course. Upon successful completion of this course, students will be eligible to sit for the RBT examination and become RBT Credentialed. For more information regarding the education programs at Leeward Community College, visit: https://teach.leeward.hawaii.edu/as-in-teaching-degree.html Apply Now Program Coordinator Jeffrey Judd Program Coordinator (808) 455-0434 jjudd@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Apply to Leeward Community College Placement into ENGLISH 100 Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Additional fees: $50 - $150 per semester Total number of credits: 62 - 63 Approximate total program tuition costs: ~ $8,322 - $8,853 Estimated program length (based on full time student status): 2 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the Leeward Community CollegeÊ»s Associate in Science in Teaching program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Concentration in Elementary Education Home Pathways Education Elementary Education Program Description: Associate in Arts degree in Liberal Arts with a concentration in: Elementary Education (60 credits) The AA degree in Liberal Arts with a concentration in Elementary Education provides students with a 60-credit program that satisfies all of the requirements for the AA degree in Liberal Arts, and prepares them with the necessary competencies to be successful working as an educational paraprofessional in elementary school settings, and/or entering a teacher licensure-track program at baccalaureate institutions. Targeted advising and a carefully planned course sequence also enable students to successfully transfer to university teacher education programs in Hawaiâi that have education-related majors, such as the University of Hawai`i at MÄnoa, College of Education. Furthermore, this degree creates a pathway for students interested in pursuing other education-related careers. Elementary Education & Second Language Teaching (60 credits) The AA degree in Liberal Arts with a concentration in Elementary Education and Second Language Teaching is a 60-credit program that provides personalized advising and a carefully planned course sequence to fulfill all of the requirements for the AA degree in Liberal Arts. This program prepares students with the necessary competencies to successfully apply to a teacher licensure-track program at baccalaureate institutions (i.e., University of Hawai`i at MÄnoa, College of Education â Multilingual Learners Program), and/or work in entry-level positions (e.g., teacher assistants, educational paraprofessionals, tutors) with second language learners in preK-12 settings. Furthermore, this degree program provides students with a framework for second language learning and teaching, skills and strategies for second language teaching, linguistic principles to support second language learning, and advocacy strategies to support second language learners. Secondary Education (60 credits) The AA degree in Liberal Arts with a concentration in Secondary Education provides students with a 60-credit program that satisfies all of the requirements for the AA degree in Liberal Arts, and prepares them with the necessary competencies to be successful in applying to a teacher licensure-track program at baccalaureate institutions, and/or working as an educational paraprofessional in middle school and high school settings. Targeted advising and a carefully planned course sequence also enable students to successfully transfer to university teacher education programs in Hawaiâi that have education-related majors, such as the University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa, College of Education and the University of Hawaiâi at West Oahu. Furthermore, this degree creates a pathway for students interested in pursuing other education-related careers. subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at West Oâahu Bachelor of Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Bachelor of Education Home Pathways Education Elementary & Early Childhood Program Description: Successful completion of the University of HawaiÊ»iâWest OÊ»ahu Bachelor of Education program enables the Education Division to recommend candidates to the Hawaiâi Teacher Standards Board for a HawaiÊ»i teaching license in the following areas: Elementary Education, grades K-6; Middle-level Education, grades 6-8, in English, Social Studies, General Science and/or Mathematics; Secondary Education, grades 6-12, in English, Social Studies, Biology, and/or Mathematics. **Students have the option to add the field of Special Education to their selected area of concentration (see below). During their program of study, teacher candidates participate in over 630 hours of field-based coursework, including introductory early field experiences, service learning, practicums, and student teaching. Course delivery occurs both on-campus and online, with flexible scheduling that recognizes candidatesâ busy family, work, and academic responsibilities. The B.Ed. does not lead to licensure outside of the state of Hawaiâi. Field placements occur in partnership with the HawaiÊ»i Department of Education schools island-wide and especially in Central and Leeward OÊ»ahu and on the WaiÊ»anae Coast. Additionally, teacher candidates complete a minimum of 40 hours of Service Learning that is integrated into required pre-professional courses. The Education Division is nationally accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP, 2020-2027). Special Education Pathway: All Education majors have the option of adding the field of Special Education to their selected general Education area of concentration (Elementary (K-6), Middle Level (6-8), or Secondary (6-12)). Teacher candidates interested in Special Education licensure can take an additional 15 credits of coursework that will qualify them to be recommended to the Hawaiâi Teacher Standards Board for a SPED teaching license. The 15 -credit âAdd a Fieldâ program of study is taken in addition to the candidateÊ»s general education curriculum. Six credits are completed during fall and spring semesters, with the remaining 9 credits taken during summer school. The program culminates in a 15-week, full-time professional student teaching semester with seminar. Candidates pursuing a Special Education teaching license will divide their student teaching between their area of concentration and special education. Apply Now Program Contact Brooke Rehmann rehmann@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Acceptance into UH West OÊ»ahu Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $306 Additional fees: $120 per semester Total number of credits: 120 total Approximate total program tuition costs: ~ $37,680 Estimated program length (based on full time student status): 4 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the UH West OÊ»ahuÊ»s Bachelor in Education program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)* or Memorandum of Agreement (MOA): Students who have completed an articulated Associate Degree from a UH Community College can transfer to UH West OÊ»ahuâs BEd program through an articulation agreement (seeing an academic advisor is highly recommended to ensure correct courses are being taken). Articulated programs include: Associate in Art in Liberal Arts, concentration in Elementary or Secondary Education from KapiÊ»olani Community College Associate in Science in Teaching from Leeward Community College Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. subcontent.text: Chaminade University (BS) Elementary Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us ELementary Education Bachelorâs Degree Home Pathways Education Elementary Education Program Description: Teachers build the future, shaping tomorrowâs leaders one by one. Or, as the historian Henry Brooks Adams once said, âTeachers affect eternity; no one can tell where their influence stops.â Thatâs never as true as in elementary education classrooms, where teachers can inspire and captivate young minds, where they can foster creativity and imagination and innovation. Where they can instill an early love for learningâand help each child recognize their special genius. After all, just think of the big influence your favorite elementary school teacher had on you. At Chaminade, we truly believe that teachers change the worldâand so our elementary education undergraduate program is designed to prepare students for that very big task. Thatâs why we keep our class sizes small, allowing for individualized attention from faculty and a strong peer-to-peer network â all aimed at maximizing feedback to hone your teaching skills. We also strongly value experiential learning, which is why students spend hours in real classroomsâobserving and participatingâbefore ever starting their semester as a student-teacher. Service-learningâlearning in the service of othersâis also a key part of our program and weâve partnered with a nearby school to ensure weâre helping in ways that are needed. Graduates of our program are licensed to teach kindergarten through sixth grade. But more importantly, theyâre ready to teachâto lead a classroom, to employ best teaching practices to help all types of students learn, and to engage young people in the joy of education. Experiential Learning (In person program only) Service-learning projects throughout the university are for our students to use what they have learned in the classroom to help others (and also get class credit). In the case of the elementary education program, service-learning is an opportunity for Chaminade students to assist struggling students in nearby elementary schools, especially at Palolo Elementary School which has a high population of students from immigrant families. Apply Now Program Coordinator Katrina Roseler Program Coordinator (808) 440-4215 katrina.roseler@chaminade.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to Chaminade University Competition of pre-program courses Cost and time commitment: Starting in Fall 2023, Chaminade Universityâs HawaiÊ»i Guarantee provides local high school graduates entering as freshmen the same tuition rate as University of Hawaiâi at Manoaâs annual resident undergraduate tuition AND an achievable pathway to graduate in four years. subcontent.text: Hawaiâi Pacific University (BA) Elementary Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us ELementary Education Bachelorâs Degree Home Pathways Education Elementary Education Program Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Elementary Education (BAEED) develops professional educators who are reflective practitioners dedicated to the scholarship of teaching and school renewal. The program is based on a standards-driven, field-based, and inquiry-oriented curriculum that employs cutting-edge educational technology to integrate content and pedagogy. Employing an electronic portfolio-based assessment system, university faculty and mentor teachers guide the candidate's progress in achieving professional knowledge, skills, and dispositions. HawaiÊ»i Pacific University's BAEED Program in Elementary Education prepares candidates to become competent, caring, and professional educators through classroom discussions and field experiences. Teacher candidates learn in small classes and enjoy individualized attention by university faculty and mentor teachers. The program prepares individuals for licensure in grades K - 6 . All students in the undergraduate program will experience two semesters of clinical practice. In the two semesters, teacher candidates will invest 225 hours per semester at a designated school. Placement at a school is determined by various factors: educational philosophy, employment of the teacher candidate at the school, proximity of the teacher candidateâs residency to the school, convenience to the teacher candidateâs outside employment, etc. Every effort is made to make the clinical practice meaningful, relevant and challenging to our students. subcontent.title: Education Teaching as a Profession Early Childhood Education Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text:
Education Teaching as a Profession Early Childhood Education Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us TEACHING AS A PROFESSION Elementary/middle/High School
			    ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi There are several benefits to obtaining entry-level training programs or certifications to further your journey to a career in Education. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. Here are a few reasons why obtaining one or more of theses certifications would help you on your path to working in the education field: Enhanced Knowledge and Skills : Entry-level certifications and training provide you with foundational knowledge and skills related to education. This can give you a head start in understanding basic concepts and pedagogy, making it easier to grasp more advanced teaching concepts during your studies. Practical Experience : Entry-level certifications and training can provide you with exposure to classroom settings, allowing you to become familiar with the different teaching environments, and understanding age and grade level teaching preferences. Professional Capacity Building Opportunities : Obtaining entry-level certifications and training can help you build connections and peer relationships with teachers and administrators. Capacity building within the education field will allow you to enhance and develop your knowledge, skills and stay updated on new pedagogical approaches, technologies, and curriculum changes in local schools systems. Improved Employability : Possessing entry-level certification and training can make you more competitive in the job market and increase your chances of finding employment as a teacher in the location, grade level and content area of your choice. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for careers in education can vary depending on the specific role and grade level you want to teach. Here are some common entry-level training options for careers in education: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification : High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for education professionals. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Parapro Assessment : The ParaPro Assessment is a computer-based assessment option for Educational Assistants (EA) and part-time Paraprofessional Tutors (PPT) to meet Department of Education minimum qualifications for employment.  The exam is designed to assess the knowledge and skills of prospective and practicing paraprofessionals in the education system.  There are study guides available for this approximately 2 and a half hour test that covers reading, writing and math competencies.  For more information, visit the ParaPro Assessment . Range of program duration: Test is 90 questions and takes approximately 2 and a half hours to complete. Substitute Teacher Certification Course : A substitute teacher is an individual who temporarily takes on the responsibilities of a regular classroom teacher when the teacher is absent. Substitute teachers step in to facilitate the learning process in the absence of the regular teacher and ensure that the educational environment continues to function smoothly.  With a high school diploma or equivalency, upon successful completion of a Substitute Teaching Certification program from a state-approved teacher education (SATE) program, interested participants can apply to be a substitute teacher for the State of HawaiÊ»i Department of Education . Range of program duration: 6 weeks Registered Behavioral Technician Training Credential: A person with a RBT credential can provide one-to one behavioral intervention services to students with special needs during the school day in academic and non-academic related activities and performs other related duties as assigned. The training to become and RBT covers measurement, assessment, skill acquisition, behavior reduction, documentation and reporting, and professional conduct and scope of practice. In addition to the 40-hour training, students will complete a competency assessment administered by a Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA), which involves an interview and direct observation of competencies based on the RBT Task List. Upon completion of this course, students will be eligible to apply for the RBT examination for their RBT credential. For more information visit the RBT credential exam. Range of program duration: 40 hours of training, 90 minutes of the exam Theses training programs can lead to the following Jobs: Educational Assistant (HIDOE) Behavioral Technician (HIDOE) Part-time Paraprofessional Tutors (PPT, in HIDOE) Teachers Aid Substitue Teacher (HIDOE) After School care worker Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. Hawaii Career Pathways builds bridges between schools and industries so students can get training and education for high-skill, high-wage professions. Candidates living on any island in the state of Hawaii can complete this program from their home island as the final two years of a bachelorâs degree. This program offers two specialization options to choose from: Secondary Special Education, Mild/Moderate (6-12) â for those looking to become special education teachers in middle or high schools. Severe Disabilities and Autism (Grades PreK-3, K-6, 6-12) â for those looking to specialize in working with students who have more comprehensive needs, often teaching in preschool, fully self-contained, or community-based instruction settings at any grade level. **Current school personnel (e.g., educational assistants and paraprofessionals) who are working in special education classrooms may be able to fulfill a majority of field requirements while employed. Please inquire for more details. STATEWIDE PROGRAM (online/hybrid) Available on all islands. Cohorted program, with candidates completing the program together as a unit for each track. Courses are online with class sessions held in the early evenings, typically 4:30pm-7:00pm on weekdays. In addition, candidates will spend time in classroom settings during the day as part of their field placements each semester. In addition, there are two face-to-face Saturday class meetings each Fall/Spring semester. Neighbor island candidates travel to Oahu and some financial support is provided to assist with travel costs associated with face-to-face program requirements. Apply Now Program Contact Steven Klein kleins@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Acceptance into UH MÄnoa 2.75 GPA or higher As part of the application process, candidates will need to complete a video recorded responses and timed essay, write a personal statement, and list three (3) references A laptop (not an ipad) is required upon admission In order to apply for this program, candidates must have completed, or be in the process of completing, the following: 57 credits or Associateâs Degree Can be from UH-MÄnoa and/or approved transfer credits from another institution (See articulations below) 40 Hours of Group Leadership Experience (Form) with school-aged children, preferably with students with disabilities UHM General Education Core and Prerequisites Must include: HWST 107 Math 100 or higher (Math 111 or 112 are highly recommended) SPED 304 (can be taken in the summer after submitting an application) Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Additional fees: $50 - $150 per semester Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total program tuition costs: ~ $57,720 Estimated program length (based on full time student status): 4 years total, 2 years for general education requirements or Associate Degree from a community college, 2 years for the BEd coursework. Visit the College of Education Scholarship for more information Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the UH MÄnoaÊ»s BEd Special Education program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree program requirements and can be taken through UH Community Colleges: General Academic Courses: ENG 100 Composition I *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites HWST 107: Hawaiian Piko *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites Program Specific Courses: HDFS 230: Human Development *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)* or Memorandum of Agreement (MOA): Students who have completed an articulated A.A. degree from a UH Community College are considered to have met the UH-MÄnoa General Education Core Requirements with possible exceptions (see an academic advisor). Articulated programs include: Associate in Science in Teaching (AST) from Leeward Community College Associate in Arts in Liberal Arts (AA), Concentration in Education from Kapiolani Community College Associate in Science in Natural Science (ASNS), Concentration in STEM Education from Kapiolani Community College Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. subcontent.title: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Health & Physical Teaching Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Health & Physical Teaching Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Health & Physical Education Teaching Home Pathways Education Health & Physical Education Program Description: The Kinesiology & Rehabilitation Science Bachelor of Science degree in Health & Physical Education Teacher Education (HPETE) program is currently a member in good standing of the Association for Advancing Quality in Educator Preparation (AAQEP), with our next AAQEP full accreditation review scheduled for Spring 2021. The College was nationally accredited from 2001 to 2018 by NCATE, the National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education. A professional preparation curriculum is provided for students who wish to be licensed to teach health and physical education in grades: K-6 (Elementary), 6-12 (Secondary) or K-12 health and physical education. This health and physical education program is for future professionals who are passionate about contributing to the growth, development, health, fitness and wellness, and lifelong physical activity of all individuals, but especially among youth. The student who majors in this program of study must demonstrate competence in motor skills and achieve and maintain health-related fitness. Additionally, future professionals will gain comprehensive knowledge relative to content in health and physical education including, effective teaching strategies, National and state standards, cultural competence, assessment, and accountability. While this program can lead to teacher licensure, before you can pursue courses for the licensure track, you must be admitted into the licensure track. Although you will leave with teacher certifications, this degree is also marketable to help you pursue a career in youth sport, fitness, and many other opportunities related to health and physical activity. The primary employers are educational institutions, both public and private, at all levels: K through 12, postsecondary (community colleges and universities). Also, government and private agencies like YMCA, physical activity and nutrition focused non-profits, Club sport organizations, City and County Recreation facilities, etc. There is no single job title for kinesiologists who have a specialization in health and physical education, but some examples include: Physical Education Teacher, Health Teacher, Athletic Director, Coach, Resource Teacher, Fitness Instructor, Managers of Fitness and Sport, etc. Apply Now Program Specialist/KRS Advisor Da Houl (808) 956-7606 houl@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Acceptance into UH MÄnoa Licensure Track Admissions Requirements 2.50 Cumulative GPA or higher 2.50 Major Cumulative GPA or higher Complete 55 credits prior to beginning the program. The 55 credits can be from UHM and/or approved transfer credits from another institution. Complete UHM General Education Core Requirements prior to the start of program. Applicants who have completed an articulated Associates of Arts (AA) degree from a UH Community College are considered to have met the UHM General Education Core Requirements with possible exceptions (see an academic advisor). K-6 teachers are typically responsible for the instruction of all core subject areas for a class of approximately 25 students and are expected to meet the academic, organizational, behavioral, and professional goals of highly qualified teachers in the United States. K-6 teachers help provide the early academic and social experiences that build a foundation for student success. PK-3/K-6 courses are offered face to face, with two days per week of courses and two days per week of assigned fieldwork. Courses are scheduled within the standard UHM semester. The BEd Elementary program offers two convenient delivery options, a campus-based option and a hybrid/online option. This program is accessible to students on all of the islands in the state of Hawaii. Candidates are able to complete their coursework in an online/hybrid format and will be placed into a local school for field requirements. A limited number of face-to-face meetings are required each semester, where neighbor island candidates will travel to Oahu for classes on chosen weekends. As funds permit, some travel stipends are made available to students who do not live on Oahu to help offset travel costs. Apply Now Program Contact Leah Maccio lmuccio@hawaii.edu Program Contact Rayna Fujii rayfujii@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Acceptance into UH MÄnoa 2.75 GPA or higher Complete 55 credits prior to beginning the program. Upon completion, you will be recommended for initial teacher licensure in kindergarten through sixth grade (K-6) general education with licensure in Elementary K-6 Education and TESOL (Teaching English to Speakers of other Languages). Graduates of the EEML program are considered âhighly effectiveâ and prepared for general elementary education classroom instruction, school language support specialist positions, or international teaching. The EEML program is a combination of methods and field-based coursework with an emphasis on school-based field experience placements in HawaiÊ»i Public schools with large populations of multilingual learners. The EEML program requires candidates to complete 12 credits of specialized methods coursework on teaching and working with multilingual learners (MLLs). In the final year of the program, candidates will take the English for Speakers of Other Languages (ESOL) Praxis exam for dual-licensure. The EEML program attracts students who are passionate about language, diversity, equity, social justice, and international education. Most importantly, teacher candidates in the EEML program love working with elementary-aged culturally and linguistically diverse students. In addition, students who should consider this programâ¦ are pursuing initial teaching licensure want to earn their TESOL license are interested in teaching multilingual learners have a passion for working with bilingual/multilingual populations are interested in diversity and applications of culture to education are interested in teaching internationally or abroad are interested in being a school language support specialist Apply Now Program Contact Elizabeth Chapman De Souza ebsouza@hawaii.edu Program Contact Monica Smith monicags@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Acceptance into UH MÄnoa 2.75 GPA or higher Complete 55 credits prior to beginning the program.
