Upon completion, graduates will be recommended for licensure in Elementary Education (K-6) and Hawaiian Language Immersion (KaiaÊ»Ålelo-Kaiapuni K-6). The Hawaiian Language Immersion component of the program entails completing 31 credit hours in Hawaiian language. Teacher candidates will have three semesters of field experience and one semester of student teaching in a Hawaiian Language Immersion (Kula Kaiapuni). Who should consider this program: Those passionate about teaching and learning the Hawaiian language are encouraged to apply. This dual licensure program will help to address the shortage in HawaiÊ»i of qualified educators to work with Hawaiian language learners, and prepare classroom teachers to effectively work with this growing population. Embedding the Hawaiian language throughout the curriculum means that these teacher candidates will experience language and pedagogical strategies necessary to teach each content area. This program follows a hybrid model designed for off-island and distance learners. Program coursework is comprised of online meetings and face-to-face meetings 2X each semester (OÊ»ahu and Other Islands). Apply Now Program Contact A. KuÊ»ulei Serna kserna@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Acceptance into UH MÄnoa 2.75 GPA or higher Complete 55 credits prior to beginning the program. The experience cannot have occurred more than 5 years prior to acceptance into the program. This cohorted program allows candidates to earn their bachelorâs degree along with two teaching licenses at the elementary level and is offered as the final two years of the bachelorâs degree in education. This emphasis prepares teachers for students with and without disabilities in kindergarten through 6th grade (K-6) general, inclusive, or special education settings. This innovative ESEE program incorporates the principles of Culturally Responsive Teaching, Co-Teaching, Universal Design for Learning (UDL), Response to Intervention (RtI), Instructional Technology, High Leverage Practices (HLPs), and Data-Based Decision Making into every aspect of the curriculum. The ESEE program has been ranked nationally in the top 25 best special education degrees by College Choice! Who should consider this program: Live or want to live on Oahu throughout the program, and Want to teach elementary (K-6) general education settings, and/or Want to teach elementary (K-6) special education settings, and/or Want to teach in elementary private school programs, and Are interested in inclusion and inclusive practices This program is delivered in a traditional face-to-face format. subcontent.text: Chaminade University (BS) Special Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us SPECIAL Education Bachelorâs Degree Home Pathways Education SPED Program Description: Itâs about giving everyone a chance, and having the compassion to teach students with disabilities to be successful learners. The Bachelor of Science in Special Education 3+1 Program is for students transferring from Leeward Community College . It is designed to prepare you for special education careers in diverse and multicultural schools. Graduates of this program can be licensed to teach Special Education K-12, PK-3, K-6, or 6-12. Students transferring from Leeward Community College must have completed a prescribed set of courses before transferring to Chaminade. Completion of 120 credits is required for the 3+1 BS in SPED. For courses to be considered transferable, they must be 100-level or higher and you must have earned a grade of C or higher. During your senior year at Chaminade, students will need to complete 33 upper-division credits: 21 credits of coursework (7 courses at CUH, 2 required, 5 recommended), and 12 credits of student teaching/seminar. subcontent.title: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Secondary Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: University of Hawaiâi at MÄnoa Secondary Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Secondary Education Home Pathways Education Secondary Education Program Description: The Bachelor of Education in Secondary Education (BEd-Secondary) is designed for students who wish to obtain eligibility for license to teach grades 6-12 in a content area. The program offers a cohesive, standards- and field-based experience that encourages teacher candidates to integrate educational theory and practice in cooperating secondary schools. Upon successful completion of the program, students will be recommended to the HawaiÊ»i Teacher Standards Board (HTSB) for initial teacher licensure. Graduates of this program become teachers in secondary educational institutions, both public (HawaiÊ»i Department of Education and Public Charter Schools) and private. Upon successful completion of the program, graduates will be recommended for licensure to teach 6-12th grade in a subject field in the state of Hawaiâi. The Secondary Program offers teaching majors in the following fields: Languages English Math Music Social Studies Sciences Apply Now Program Contact Kelly Sakuda (808) 956-4241 sakudake@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Acceptance into UH MÄnoa 2.75 GPA or higher Complete 55 credits prior to beginning the program. The 55 credits can be from UHM and/or approved transfer credits from another institution. Complete UHM General Education Core Requirements prior to the start of program. Applicants who have completed an articulated Associates of Arts (AA) degree from a UH Community College are considered to have met the UHM General Education Core Requirements with possible exceptions (see an academic advisor). Complete Licensure-Track Prerequisite Courses Complete 40 hours of paid or voluntary group leadership field experience with 6-12th grade students. The experience cannot have occurred more than 5 years prior to acceptance into the program. Interview with the program Write a personal statement Provide Three (3) Professional References Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Additional fees: $50 - $150 per semester Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total program tuition costs: ~ $57,720 Estimated program length (based on full time student status): 4 years total, 2 years for general education requirements or Associate Degree from a community college, 2 years for the BEd coursework. Visit the College of Education Scholarship for more information Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the UH MÄnoaÊ»s BEd Secondary Education program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree program requirements and can be taken through UH Community Colleges: General Academic Courses: ENG 100 Composition I *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites HWST 107: Hawaiian Piko *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites Program Specific Courses: HDFS 230: Human Development *Prerequisite - Check UHCC campus for prerequisites *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)* Students who have completed an articulated A.A. degree from a UH Community College are considered to have met the UH-MÄnoa General Education Core Requirements with possible exceptions (see an academic advisor). Articulated programs include: Associate in Science in Teaching (AST) from Leeward Community College Associate in Arts in Liberal Arts (AA), Concentration in Education from Kapiolani Community College Associate in Science in Natural Science (ASNS), Concentration in STEM Education from Kapiolani Community College Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. subcontent.text: Chaminade University (BS) Secondary Education | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Secondary Education Bachelorâs Degree Home Pathways Education Secondary Program Description: One of the most-watched TED Talks about education is from teacher Rita Pierson, whose grandparents and parents were educators, too. Speaking to a packed hall, Pierson said that sheâs seen plenty of educational reforms in her 40 years as a teacher. But, she said, whatâs rarely talked about in education is the value of making connectionsâof positive relationship-building. Young people, Pierson said, need people in their lives who will encourage them when theyâre making progress, applaud them when they succeed, and remember how tough it was to be a kid. âEvery child deserves a champion, an adult who will never give up on them, who understands the power of connection, and insists that they become the best that they can possibly be,â Pierson said, adding, with a wide smile, âWeâre educators. Weâre born to make a difference.â We couldnât agree with her more. Teachers make a positive difference in young peopleâs lives every single day, and thatâs especially true in secondary education. Need proof? Just think back on how important your positive relationships with teachers were when you were in middle and high school. Think back on that high school literature teacher who made Shakespeareâs works come alive or that seventh-grade pre-algebra teacher who wasnât happy until you understood a concept fully. We wonât lie. Teaching is not easy, especially at the secondary level. Youâll have good days, some not-so-good days and a few tough days. But weâre here to give you the educational foundation youâll need to succeed, creating learning environments that will help students thrive. Once you complete the Secondary Education program , youâll be licensed to teach grades 7 through 12 in your core content area (English, Mathematics, Science or Social Studies) in Hawaii and most other states. The best part: your coursework can be completed online, giving you extra flexibility while you gear up for student teaching opportunities in your area. This 60 credit program provides clear, explicit, coherent pathways for students intending to transfer into Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) majors at baccalaureate institutions. The program provides curricula that focus on basic science and mathematics as well as more advanced research and mentoring experiences. The degree provides students with undergraduate research opportunities as they move through STEM curricular pathways. Targeted advising and appropriate course sequencing enable the efficient transfer of STEM students. Certificate of Achievement in STEM Education (37-39 credits) The AA degree in Liberal Arts with a concentration in Elementary Education and Second Language Teaching is a 60-credit program that provides personalized advising and a carefully planned course sequence to fulfill all of the requirements for the AA degree in Liberal Arts. This program prepares students with the necessary competencies to successfully apply to a teacher licensure-track program at baccalaureate institutions (i.e., University of Hawai`i at MÄnoa, College of Education â Multilingual Learners Program), and/or work in entry-level positions (e.g., teacher assistants, educational paraprofessionals, tutors) with second language learners in preK-12 settings. Furthermore, this degree program provides students with a framework for second language learning and teaching, skills and strategies for second language teaching, linguistic principles to support second language learning, and advocacy strategies to support second language learners. title: Health Services | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
text: Health Services | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Health Services Home Pathways and Programs Health Services Nursing Services (NS) Nursing Services is a profession within the healthcare sector focused on providing care, support, and assistance to individuals, families, and communities to promote and maintain their overall health and well-being. Nurses play a crucial role in various healthcare settings, including hospitals, clinics, nursing homes, schools, home care, and more. Nursing is a rewarding profession that requires compassion, critical thinking, communication skills, and a commitment to improving the lives of patients and their communities. The Nursing Services program is designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to enter into a postsecondary nursing program, leading to an RN license or advanced level credentials in nursing or as a physician. Diagnostic Service (DS) Healthcare diagnostic services refer to a wide range of medical tests, procedures, and techniques that healthcare professionals use to diagnose and assess medical conditions, diseases, injuries, and overall health status in patients. These services provide essential information to guide treatment decisions, monitor health conditions, and ensure the well-being of individuals. The Diagnostic Services program is designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to examine, test, and evaluate in the detection, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases, injuries or other physical conditions. Diagnostic services occupations include phlebotomists. radiologists and radiology technicians, histology technicians, and medical sonographers. Public Health Services (PHS) Public health services are initiatives and programs designed to promote and protect the health of communities and populations on a larger scale. The Public Health Services program is designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills to undertake a comprehensive approach to health, while learning about social determinants such as poverty, discrimination, and inadequate access to resources and care. Additionally, students will study the patterns, causes, and effects of diseases in a variety of populations, and how the provision of healthcare has changed in response to global needs. Students will be able to interpret and communicate statistical information relating to the distribution of disease, mortality/morbidity, health disparities, health interventions, and analyze health policies and funding. Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) is a specialized field within healthcare that focuses on enhancing individuals' physical, mental, and emotional well-being to optimize their overall performance and quality of life. HPTS professionals work with clients to address a wide range of issues, including pain management, injury prevention and recovery, sports performance enhancement, stress management, and more. These services aim to help individuals reach their full potential by improving their functional abilities, reducing pain, and promoting optimal health. The Human Performance Therapeutic Services program is designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to recognize diseases, disorders, or injuries related to therapeutic and/or rehabilitation services and correlate the related anatomy and physiology symptoms to develop a plan of treatment with appropriate modalities. Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Emergency Medical Services (EMS) refer to a system of medical care and response designed to provide rapid and specialized assistance to individuals facing medical emergencies or injuries. The primary goal of EMS is to deliver timely and effective medical care at the scene of an emergency and during transportation to a medical facility. EMS plays a critical role in saving lives, reducing the severity of injuries, and providing necessary medical attention during crises. The Emergency Medical Services program is designed to prepare students for careers in the fields of emergency medicine, including in a hospital setting and pre-hospital emergency medicine. Students will work towards qualifying for an emergency medical technician (EMT) related certification and occupations. text: Public Health | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Public Health Home Pathways and Programs Health Services Public Health Public Health Pathway Map to Employment Careers in public health services are diverse and focus on promoting and protecting the health of communities and populations. Public health services play a crucial role in preventing disease, promoting health equity, and improving the overall well-being of populations. These services work to address both immediate health concerns and long-term health outcomes, with a focus on prevention, education, policy, and community engagement. Students in the public health services program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into healthcare with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in a public health services program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore healthcare through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in public health will require additional education depending on the career you want to pursue. While more training is required, you are able to attain entry level certifications that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview: The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey: If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement: As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Maui College Human Services Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Human Services Program Home Health Services Human Services Program Description: UH Maui Collegeâs Human Services program (HSER) prepares graduates to work with people of all ages in diverse health and human services settings. We aim to provide a collaborative and learner-centered environment that welcomes students from all backgrounds. The Associates of Science (AS) degree provides a broad set of generalist skills needed for entry-level positions in Human Services, Social Work, and Public Health. Specialized Certificates of Competence (9-15 credits) and a Certificate of Achievement (30 credits) are available for majors and those in the workforce seeking career change or advancement. Specializations include Aging, Case Management, Community Health, Family Violence, Substance Use Disorder, and Youth Development. subcontent.text: Leeward Community College Health Information Technology Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Health Information Technology Program Home Health Health Information Technology Program Description: As the medical industry becomes increasingly dependent on digital communication and recordkeeping, the demand for skilled employees who can collect and analyze healthcare data is critical to managing vital information for their services. Health Information Technology (HIT) professionals are responsible for the organization and accurate maintenance of computerized patient medical records. They may also be responsible for the timely and accurate submission of complex insurance documents. Successful graduates can find employment at hospitals, medical offices, and insurance companies in positions, including medical office manager, medical transcriptionist, medical records technician, and medical coding specialist. With an associate degree in Health Information Technology, you can serve your community while also building a new career for yourself. The Associate in Science (AS) Program of Study builds upon the Health Information Technology (HIT) foundation presented in the Certificate of Competence (CO) and Certificate of Achievement (CA) Programs of Study. Students will expand their records and information management skills in medical coding and medical records, including electronic records. Combined with the biological science, health statistics, and management courses, the students will be able to pursue careers as an Admissions Clerk, Cancer Registrar, Coder, Health Information Management (HIM) Technologist, Patient Access Supervisor, Privacy Officer, and/or Release of Information Technologist. subcontent.text: UH at MÄnoa Human Development and Family Studies Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Human Development and Family Studies Home Health Public Health HDFS Program Description: Human Development and Family Studies (HDFS) is a Bachelorâs of Science degree program that provides students with a comprehensive, ecological systems-based program of study in human development, family development, and family resource management. The HDFS curriculum provides students with a multitude of experiences through coursework and off-campus activities to give them the knowledge and professional skills needed for careers in family/human services. The curriculum encompasses these studies: Changing needs, dynamics, and challenges of families over time Management of human, material, financial, and community resources to meet these needs Growth and development of individuals over the human life cycle Interrelationships of individuals, families, and communities in the context of diverse socioeconomic and cultural systems. The HDFS curriculum provides students with comprehensive study of human development, family development, and family resource management. Students are prepared for positions in family service agencies; family life and parenting education programs; children's, youth, and gerontology programs; child care and early childhood education centers; and consumer affairs agencies. The courses cover these topics and more: Healthy family relationships Healthy and resilient human development at all ages Family caregiving for older adults and grandparents raising children Family public policy Family and consumer resource management Community leadership and resource development. subcontent.text: UH at MÄnoa Social Work Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Social Work Home Health Public Health Social Work Program Description: The mission of the Thompson School of Social Work & Public Health DSW Bachelor of Social Work Program is to provide students with the knowledge, values, skills, and cognitive and affective processes of the social work profession, integrated with a liberal arts education. Utilizing a generalist framework, the BSW Program provides the basis for practice within the context of a multicultural environment. Special attention is given to Native Hawaiian, Pacific Islander, and Asian communities of our state and the Pacific Region, as they interact within a global context. Social and economic justice for underrepresented and oppressed groups is emphasized within the curriculum. We are proud to offer the only Bachelor of Social Work (BSW) Distance Education (DE) Option program in the state of HawaiÊ»i. The DE Option provides increased access for students who would otherwise be unable to pursue a social work degree due to geographical or scheduling barriers. Our BSW program is available on a part-time or full-time schedule to all state of HawaiÊ»i students who have completed their General Education Core Requirements. Students complete the program while remaining in their home community (HawaiÊ»i, MolokaÊ»i, KauaÊ»i, Maui, LanaÊ»i, or OÊ»ahu). Most classes are delivered asynchronously online and in a condensed 5-week format while the Field Education requirements are fulfilled in community agencies, under the supervision of certified social workers. Graduates through the DE Option are awarded a BSW degree from the University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa after meeting all program requirements, including field education. Apply Now Contact Pre-Social Work Advising Pre-Social Work Advising (808) 956-7182 bswadvis@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: The UH Manoa BSW has Selected Admissions. This means that the following will need to be completed PRIOR to applying for the BSW program: Have been admitted (or be in the process of being admitted) to the University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa Have completed (or be in the process of completing) the University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa general education core requirements Have completed (or be in the process of completing) the knowledge-base requirement courses identified by the BSW Program with a grade of C or better Have a minimum cumulative grade point average of 2.5 Provide evidence of motivation for and commitment to social work (e.g., personal, volunteer, and/or social work-related experience) Once you have completed the general education requirements: You will complete the SocialWorkCAS application, including: âPersonal Informationâ section Three (3) Reference Requests (letters of recommendation) via âSupporting Informationâ section In âAcademic Historyâ section Complete âColleges Attendedâ Then upload unofficial transcript for each college attended In âProgram Materialsâ section Respond to all required questions via the âQuestionsâ tab Submit all required documents via the âDocumentsâ tab. Students acquire skills that provide them with a strong foundation for managing health information and information systems, medical reimbursement processes, and other administrative health data functions. Students are prepared to collaborate with interdisciplinary healthcare professionals in compliance and quality improvement efforts as they relate to the gathering, storing, and analysis of health-related data. Students also develop critical-thinking, problem-solving, and decision-making skills that are integral to the management of health data and information. Further, students acquire vital leadership skills in health informatics, revenue cycle management, data analytics, and information governance. Note: HIM concentration courses with HIM and HLTH designation are offered via distance delivery only (Online). HIM 408 and HIM 490 could contain a course component that requires a face-to-face element, please contact HIM faculty for additional information. subcontent.text: UH at MÄnoa Public Health Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Public health Home Health Public Health UHM Public health Program Description: The public health profession is a diverse and multidisciplinary field dedicated to improving and protecting the health and well-being of communities and populations. Public health professionals work to prevent disease, promote health, and address health disparities on a broad scale. The primary objective of the UH Manoa Public Health program is to prepare students for future careers in a wide array of exciting career fields within public health. The Bachelor of Arts degree in Public Health is designed to educate undergraduates interested in public health and/or health profession training in the broad basic concepts in public health education, practice, and research. The primary focus of public health education is to improve health and quality of life through the population-based prevention and treatment of disease and other physical and mental health conditions, through surveillance of cases and the promotion of health behaviors. Training in the Native Hawaiian traditional healing practices will focus on hoÊ»oponopno (conflict resolution), lomilomi (massage), and lÄÊ»au lapaÊ»au (herbal medicines). An overarching goal is to work towards eliminating health disparities in Native Hawaiian, Pacific Islander, and other underserved communities by creating a collaboration between Traditional and Western Medicine. This student-centered concentration promotes the integration of underserved and underrepresented students into an academic and cultural environment that supports educational achievement and economic success.. The Associates of Science degree in Medical Assisting (MEDA) curriculum is designed to prepare students to assist physicians in private medical offices and clinics and hospital outpatient clinics. They assist with patient care as well as with routine office laboratory and diagnostic tests (clinical medical assisting). In addition, students are prepared to perform administrative medical office and business practices and procedures (administrative medical assisting). subcontent.text: UH West Oâahu Health Sciences Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Health Sciences Program Home Health Services Public Health Health Sciences Program Description: The Health Sciences concentration features courses that educate students on clinical healthcare, factors related to human health and disease, the human body, and cultural knowledge. These courses supplement the solid science background (biology, chemistry, physics) of the Bachelor of Science in Natural Science core. The capstone is designed to accommodate the large amount of clinical hours required for students to apply to health profession graduate schools. Upon completion of the BSNS with a Health Sciences concentration, students will be able to demonstrate appropriate laboratory techniques, triage methods based on CPR/AED/ First Aid, and correct handling of bloodborne pathogens (via OSHA certification). The concentration also has a clinical cognate that provides students the opportunity to develop the necessary skills to complete and direct patient care related to medical procedures and privacy protocol as outlined by HIPAA requirements. Utilizing problem-based learning techniques, students will develop the skills necessary for professional communication and behavior, effective teamwork, community and cultural well-being, and critical inquiry. Successful completion of the Health Sciences concentration prepares students for graduate studies in health professions or healthcare career options including health education, hospital management, health administration, health and wellness, and school health programs. subcontent.text: Chaminade University Community and Public Health Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Community and Public Health Program Home Health Services Public Health Community and Public Health Program Description: When people consider the health care system in the US, they often think of hospitals, clinics and doctorâs offices. But a rapidly growing segment of patient care is now delivered in communities. Health educators, nonprofit administrators, community advocates, data analysts and others are contributing to a holistic continuum of care aimed at helping patients live longer, more active and healthier lives. Chaminadeâs Bachelor of Science in Community and Public Health is designed to prepare you for a significant role in this network of care at a time of double-digit growth in the sector as well as to take the Certified Health Education Specialist (CHESÂ®) examination. Careers in community and public health put you at the cutting edge of preventative care, health education and health coaching, working directly with patientsâand their communitiesâto make a positive difference. Importantly, our degree also includes a foundation of knowledge in epidemiology and public health. Students are prepared for careers in everything from infectious disease outbreaks to care for vulnerable communities, to work in schools to promote health in children and families. Given the wide range of professional pathways available to community and public health students, Chaminadeâs program stresses flexibility, allowing you to choose from one of four specializations so you can individualize your learning based on your academic and future career goals. Tracks Community Health Worker Specialization: Excellent preparation for a career in health education, health coaching, epidemiology, public health and policy. Environment and Health Specialization: Explore the linkages between environment and health, especially in the area of preventative health, policy and public health. Non-profit administration Specialization: Develop your expertise in healthcare administration in the non-profit sector with a deep dive into the economics, finances and operations of community healthcare organizations. Data Analytics Specialization: Harness the power of âbig dataâ to improve healthcare, model and predict diseases and inform decision-making and policy, developing an in-demand skill set in a fast-growing area of healthcare. Apply Now Contact Program (808) 735-4813 admissions@chaminade.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to Chaminade University Competition of pre-program courses Cost and time commitment: Starting in Fall 2023, Chaminade Universityâs HawaiÊ»i Guarantee provides local high school graduates entering as freshmen the same tuition rate as University of Hawaiâi at Manoaâs annual resident undergraduate tuition AND an achievable pathway to graduate in four years. subcontent.text: Hawaiâi Pacific University Social Work Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Social Work Program Home Health Services Public Health Social Work Program Description: For some, "making the world a better place" is not an idealistic slogan, but a goal and a passion. If you are such a person and want to learn methods of solving problems effectively with people, you should consider a degree in social work. Some ways to help others are direct, one-to-one counseling with individual clients and families; and others are indirect, such as developing organizations and communities. Social work is a broad profession that tries to understand how individuals, groups, and communities are affected by social problems such as poverty, mental and physical illness, family difficulties, and social injustice. Social workers are employed in a variety of settings such as hospitals, schools, the legislature, and social welfare agencies that address the needs of children, adults, and elders. Wherever they find themselves, social workers use their skills to empower others to help themselves and change unresponsive social systems. The HawaiÊ»i Pacific UniversityÊ»s Bachelor of Social Work program helps students to develop the necessary knowledge, values and skills to help "make the world a better place." Apply Now BSW Program Director Vince Okada, PHD Assistant Professor (808) 236-5845 vokada@hpu.edu Program Prerequisites: All students interested in HPUÊ»s BSW program must apply to HPU Admissions and The School of Social Work separately: Submit HPU Student Application to HPU Admissions Once accepted to HPU, students must reach âjuniorâ status (60 credits) by the term you would be admitted if accepted to the Social Work program. You must have received a "C" or higher in the prerequisites (Introduction to Sociology, Introduction to Psychology, Introduction to Social Work courses, and a Writing course) and you must have an overall GPA of 2.75 or higher Once âjuniorâ status has been reached and you have completed the program prerequisites, you then complete the BSW Application and submit by the due date posted Cost and time commitment: Total Credits for graduation: 120 For Tuition and Fee information Please visit the HPUÊ»s Website Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. subcontent.title: Public Health Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Public Health Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Public Health ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi There are several benefits to obtaining entry-level training programs or certifications to further your journey to a career in health services. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. Here are a few reasons why obtaining one or more of theses certifications would help you on your path to working in the health field: Enhanced Knowledge and Skills: Entry-level certifications provide you with foundational knowledge and skills related to healthcare and patient care. This can give you a head start in understanding basic concepts and procedures, making it easier to grasp more advanced nursing concepts during your studies. Competitive Advantage: Health programs can be competitive, with limited spots available. Having entry-level certifications can set you apart from other applicants by demonstrating your commitment to the healthcare field and your readiness to contribute to patient care. It shows that you have taken the initiative to acquire relevant skills and experience, making you a more attractive candidate. Practical Experience: Entry-level certifications can provide you with exposure to real healthcare settings, allowing you to become familiar with the clinical environment, patient interactions, and healthcare team dynamics. Networking Opportunities: Obtaining entry-level certifications can help you build connections with healthcare professionals, instructors, and potential employers. Networking within the healthcare field will allow you to have a greater understanding of careers in healthcare through these connections. Improved Employability: Possessing entry-level certification can make you more competitive in the job market and increase your chances of finding employment as a healthcare professional. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for Human Performance Therapeutic Services-related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for nursing-related careers: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for healthcare professionals, including nurses. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Community Health Worker: Community Health Worker (CHW), also known as a Community Health Advocate, is a frontline public health worker who acts as a bridge between healthcare and social services and the communities they serve. Community Health Workers are essential in addressing health disparities, improving access to healthcare, and promoting health equity, especially in underserved and marginalized communities. Their work is crucial in bridging gaps in healthcare delivery and helping individuals and communities achieve better health outcomes. The specific roles and responsibilities of CHWs may vary depending on the community's needs and the healthcare system they work within. Range of program duration: 6 months to 1 year Medical Assistant: Medical assisting is a healthcare profession that combines administrative and clinical duties to support the efficient operation of medical offices, clinics, and healthcare facilities. Medical assistants work closely with physicians, nurses, and other healthcare professionals to ensure the smooth delivery of patient care.  Medical assistants typically complete a post-secondary education program, which can lead to a diploma, certificate, or associate's degree in medical assisting.  The specific program you choose may depend on your career goals, educational background, and the time you can commit to training. Range of program duration: 70-800 hours Medical Reimbursement Specialist: This is a healthcare professional responsible for ensuring that medical services provided to patients are accurately coded, billed, and reimbursed by insurance companies or other third-party payers. Their role is crucial for healthcare providers and facilities to receive proper compensation for the services they offer. Range of program duration: 80-85 hours Medical Receptionist and Patient Services: The Medical Receptionist and Patient Services program provides participants with a foundational understanding of the healthcare delivery system, the role of the PSR, and the tools needed to be a front-line customer-service agent in a medical office or hospital setting. Responsibilities include (but are not limited to): written and verbal correspondence with patients, scheduling, collecting co-payments, maintaining patient charts, verifying insurance coverage, and ensuring overall patient satisfaction. This course consists of five modules tailored to those with little or no experience, looking to begin a career in healthcare. Range of program duration: 80-85 hours Mental Health Technician: Mental health is just as important as physical health when it comes to a person's overall well-being. Mental health technicians care for patients with mental or emotional conditions or disabilities. Acting under a health practitioner's order, technicians monitor a patient's physical and emotional health; observe and sometimes interact, teach, counsel, or support the patient; restrain patients when needed; and assist patients with their daily tasks such as bathing and cleaning. Range of program duration: 1 to 2 semesters Registered Behavior Technician: Registered Behavior Technician (RBT) training prepares participants to meet all criteria to be eligible to become a nationally recognized RBT, a paraprofessional certified in behavior analysis. RBTs assist in delivering behavior-analytic services and practice under the direction and close supervision of an RBT Supervisor and/or an RBT Requirements Coordinator, who are responsible for all work RBTs perform. RBT certification was originally designed for settings in which a BCBA or BCaBA is already providing behavior-analytic services. Thus, applying to become an RBT is most likely to occur after the applicant has been employed by the organization in which they will continue their work assisting qualified BCBAs and/or BCaBAs in their service-delivery activities. This course includes a job shadowing experience during the last two weeks. Range of program duration: 5 weeks Theses training programs can lead to the following Jobs: Community Health Worker Medical Assistant Home Aide Skills trainer Patient Service Representative Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Public Health Admission Requirements Home Pathways & Programs Admission Requirements Some post-secondary (college) health care programs in HawaiÊ»i have what is called Selected Admission: Selected admissions programs are competitive programs that only admit a limited number of students. These programs have a rigorous application process, and only highly qualified candidates are accepted. Applying to these programs happens AFTER you are admitted to the college or university of your choice and have completed the basic prerequisites for that campus program. The basic admissions requirements are: Course prerequisites: Selected admissions programs have specific prerequisite coursework that must be completed before applying. These prerequisites can include biology, chemistry, anatomy, and physiology courses and may vary campus. GPA and Testing requirements: Some programs have minimum GPA or testing requirements that applicants must meet with all prerequisite courses. These requirements can vary per campus. Application process: All applicants who meet eligibility requirements will be reviewed and ranked according to the criteria outlined by each campus. All available seats will be offered to applicants with the highest-ranking scores. Internship or work experience: Some selected admissions programs also prioritize applicants with relevant internships or work experience in a health care setting. For specific prerequisite courses, test scores and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to later apply for the program you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs in Public Health: Kapiâolani Community College Leeward Community College UH Maui College Honolulu Community College * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map *Chaminade University of Honolulu: Cumulative high school GPA of 2.50 or higher High school students in dual enrollment or running start programs will need to submit official college transcripts Provide a written statement describing your interest in pursuing your degree at Chaminade University of Honolulu, and any related extracurricular activities that have prepared you for your educational goals. This statement must be a minimum of 250 words. Test Scores (Optional) See specific Nursing program requirements *HawaiÊ»i Pacific University: HPU understands that each student has a unique academic history and individual talents. This is why HPU takes a holistic approach to reviewing applications, and considers all the information provided on your application to make an admissions decision. For more admissions information, please visit the HPU Admissions website . What is CONSIDERED: Grade Point Average - GPA SAT and/or ACT scores (or English Proficiency if educated outside of the US) Extracurricular activities Personal statement (essay) and/or resume Academic area of interest Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: UH West Oâahu Public Administration - Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Public Administration - Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management Home Health Services EMS PUBA-Disaster Preparedness Program Description: The University of HawaiÊ»iâWest OÊ»ahu Bachelor of Arts in Public Administration degree prepares students for supervisory and management roles in the public sector. Students receive a solid foundation in public sector practices and processes as well as a fundamental understanding of, and appreciation for, public sector management practices and administrative procedures. Students may also go on to pursue graduate degrees in varied programs, such as Public Administration, Criminal Justice, Health Care Administration, and Urban and Regional Planning, Management Science. The Public Administration program offers concentrations in: Community Health Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management Health Care Administration General Public Administration Justice Administration Long-Term Care Certificates in Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management, Health Care Administration, and Long-Term Care are also available. All students majoring in Public Administration are required to take core courses and complete a capstone course (e.g., Senior Project or Administrative Practicum). The study of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management provides students with a broad range of administrative skills and knowledge that are ideally suited to meet the critical needs of emergency management administrators. At UH West Oâahu, students may pursue a Bachelor of Arts in Public Administration with a concentration in disaster preparedness & emergency management or a certificate in Disaster Preparedness & Emergency Management. All courses meet the national standards as established by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Higher Education Project. Courses for the bachelorâs degree and certificate are offered through in-class and distance learning instruction. The disaster preparedness and emergency management concentration is the only upper division disaster management program in the State of HawaiÊ»i. The curriculum includes courses in natural sciences, social sciences, and liberal arts, as well as application-based coursework in healthcare. Within Health Professions students have the opportunity to participate in health-related student organizations, gain real-world experience through undergraduate practicums and internships, and conduct undergraduate research with UH West Oâahu and UH System Faculty and Scholars. Students can choose to specialize in one of several plans of study including: Pre-nursing (General Health Sciences plan) Pre-physicians assistant Pre-physical therapy General Public Administration Pre-occupational therapy Pre-pharmacy Pre-medical The Pre-Nursing or General Health Sciences plan is designed to prepare pre-nursing students for nursing academic pathway agreement with UH ManoaÊ»s Bachelors of Science degree in Nursing (See UH Manoa Nursing page for details). Other specializations, or tracks, allow the student to follow a clear career path and fulfill potential prerequisites necessary for graduate and/or professional school in medicine and health sciences. Students interested in graduate and/or professional school in medicine, physical therapy, occupational therapy, and physician assistant studies may opt to follow a pre-health focus, which includes courses required for entrance into graduate school. Graduates are prepared for entry-level career opportunities in healthcare and health-related services or for entry into graduate and professional programs. Students who successfully complete the program will be certified in CPR/AED and First Aid, trained in Bloodborne pathogen safety, and may be eligible to apply to take the Certified Health Education Specialist (CHES) examination. text: Public Health | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Diagnostic services Home Pathways and Programs Health Services Diagnostic Services Diagnostic Services Pathway Map to Employment Careers in diagnostic services focus on using medical tests, imaging techniques, and other diagnostic methods to identify, analyze, and diagnose medical conditions and diseases. These professionals play a critical role in helping healthcare providers make accurate treatment decisions and provide appropriate care for patients by helping healthcare providers identify health issues early, monitor disease progression, and make informed decisions about appropriate interventions. Students in the diagnostic services program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into healthcare with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in a diagnostic services program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore healthcare through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in diagnostic services will require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training is required, you are able to attain entry level certifications that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview: The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey: If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement: As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow.
