subcontent.title: Diagnostic Services Entry Level Jobs - Traing Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Diagnostic Services Entry Level Jobs - Traing Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us DS Entry Level Jobs/ Training Programs Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi There are several benefits to obtaining entry-level training programs or certifications to further your journey to a career in health services. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. Here are a few reasons why obtaining one or more of theses certifications would help you on your path to working in the health field: Enhanced Knowledge and Skills: Entry-level certifications provide you with foundational knowledge and skills related to healthcare and patient care. This can give you a head start in understanding basic concepts and procedures, making it easier to grasp more advanced nursing concepts during your studies. Competitive Advantage: Health programs can be competitive, with limited spots available. Having entry-level certifications can set you apart from other applicants by demonstrating your commitment to the healthcare field and your readiness to contribute to patient care. It shows that you have taken the initiative to acquire relevant skills and experience, making you a more attractive candidate. Practical Experience: Entry-level certifications can provide you with exposure to real healthcare settings, allowing you to become familiar with the clinical environment, patient interactions, and healthcare team dynamics. Networking Opportunities: Obtaining entry-level certifications can help you build connections with healthcare professionals, instructors, and potential employers. Networking within the healthcare field will allow you to have a greater understanding of careers in healthcare through these connections. Improved Employability: Possessing entry-level certification can make you more competitive in the job market and increase your chances of finding employment as a healthcare professional. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for diagnostic services-related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for nursing-related careers: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for healthcare professionals, including nurses. Length of training program: 2-4 hours Phlebotomy certification: Involves the collection of blood samples for laboratory testing or medical purposes. By successfully completing a phlebotomy training program from an accredited institution, which includes classroom instruction on topics like anatomy and physiology, venipuncture techniques, infection control, medical terminology, and legal and ethical considerations, students can obtain certification by a recognized certifying agency. Length of training program: Theses training programs can lead to the following Jobs: Phlebotmist Caregivers Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.title: Kapiâolani Community College Radiologic Technician Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Kapiâolani Community College Radiologic Technician Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Radiologic Technician Program Home Health Radiologic Technician Program Description: Kapiâolani Community College offers the only two-year Associate in Science degree in Radiologic Technology for the State of Hawaiâi. The Radiologic Technology (RAD) Program curriculum includes classroom studies, hands-on exercises in well-equipped laboratories, and intensive supervised clinical practice in affiliated hospitals. This combination of subject matter and clinical experience is designed to prepare program graduates for safe operation of x-ray equipment in diagnostic imaging settings under the supervision of a radiologist. Radiologic technologists are medical personnel who perform diagnostic imaging examinations or administer radiation therapy treatments. They are educated in anatomy, patient positioning, examination techniques, equipment protocols, radiation safety, and basic patient care. Radiologic technologists may practice general radiography, or specialize in a specific imaging technique such as bone densitometry, cardiovascular-interventional radiology, computed tomography, mammography, magnetic resonance imaging, nuclear medicine, or sonography. Technologists specializing in radiation therapy or medical dosimetry are involved in the treatment of cancer with high doses of radiation. Radiologic technologists work closely with radiologists, specialist physicians who interpret medical images to diagnose or treat diseases and injuries. Technologists may work in hospitals, clinics, or in private physician offices. Their duties may also include record-keeping, ordering and/or stocking supplies, and performing quality control activities to assure proper imaging equipment function. Satisfactory completion of this A.S. degree program qualifies graduates to take the credentialing examination of the American Registry of Radiologic Technologists (ARRT), which is accepted by the Hawaiâi Board of Radiologic Technology for state licensure. Apply Now Health Career Program Counselors Program Counselors (808) 734-9224 hlthsci@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: KapaiÊ»olani Community Collegeâs RAD program has select admissions , meaning you must complete the following before you apply to enter the RAD program: Apply to KapiÊ»olani Community College Attend at Health Careers Information Sessions Meet with the Health Program counselors to let them know that you want to be in the RAD program. They will advise you on what you need to complete in order to apply for RAD. Register for courses on the program prerequisite course list. Pass each class with a âCâ or better, âC-â is not accepted! Complete all of the prerequisite courses with a minimum GPA of 2.5. Complete the A2 Assessment ( A2 Info Sheet ) The A2 test must be taken within the current application period. Students must receive 75% or higher on all test sections. Meet with the counselors again to make sure you have completed all the necessary prerequisites to apply for the Radiologic Technician programÊ»s Associates of Science degree!! These courses meet degree pre-program requirements for the KapiÊ»olani Community College RAD program. subcontent.text: Maui College Dental Hygiene Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Dental Hygiene Program Home Health Services Dental Hygiene Program Description: The Dental Hygiene program is a four semester and one summer session program within a cohort that prepares individuals to work in general and specialty dental offices, and public health agencies. Emphasis is placed on the correlations among prevention, education, and the clinical phases of dental hygiene practice as well as basic and social sciences. The curriculum is organized in accordance with requirements of the American Dental Association Commission on Dental Accreditation for a Dental Hygiene program and with consultation from the Maui County Dental Association. The Dental Hygiene program is accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation, a specialized accrediting body recognized by the Council of Postsecondary Accreditation and the United States Department of Education. You will earn an Associate in Science (AS) Degree in Dental Hygiene upon completion of the program. Apply Now Program Counselors Wayne Aguiran Program Counselor (808) 984-3306 uhmc.advising@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: University of HawaiÊ»i Maui Collegeâs Dental Hygiene program has select admissions , meaning you must complete the following before you apply to enter the Dental program: Apply to UH Maui College Meet with the UH Maui College counselors to let them know that you want to be in the Dental program (uhmc.advising@hawaii.edu). They will advise you on what you need to complete in order to apply for the program. Declaring a Major. You will need to declare a major while you are working on your pre-dental courses, declaring Liberal Arts as your major will allow you to still receive financial aid if you apply and quality. You will not declare your major as Dental UNTIL you are accepted into the Dental Hygiene program. Register for courses on the Dental program prerequisite course list. Pass each class with a âCâ or better, âC-â is not accepted! Complete all of the prerequisite courses with a minimum GPA of 2.5. Make sure you have completed all the necessary prerequisites to apply for the Dental programÊ»s Associates of Science in Dental degree, then submit your application to the UH Maui College Dental program! subcontent.text: UH at MÄnoa Medical Technology Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us UH MÄnoa Medical Technology Home Health Diagnostic Svcs Medical Technology Program Description: The UH MÄnoa Medical Technology program is a career-pathway structure where students progress from associate degree Medical Lab Technician ( See KapiÊ»olani Community College MLT program ) to bachelorâs degree Medical Lab Scientist (MLS). Medical Laboratory Science (MLS) is a vital field within the healthcare sector that involves the analysis of various biological specimens to aid in the diagnosis, treatment, and monitoring of diseases. Medical laboratory professionals, often referred to as medical laboratory scientists or clinical laboratory scientists, play a crucial role in providing accurate and timely laboratory test results to healthcare providers. MLS is a crucial aspect of modern healthcare, playing a pivotal role in disease diagnosis, treatment monitoring, and research. Medical laboratory scientists contribute behind the scenes to ensure that patients receive accurate diagnoses and appropriate care. The MLS program at UH MÄnoa has 2 pathways to degree: 2 + 2 model:  Students successfully complete KapiÊ»olani Community CollegeÊ»s MLT Associate of Science degree with a GPA of 2.5 or higher, then apply UH MÄnoaÊ»s MLS program for an additional 2 years. Second Degree Seekers:  Students who have successfully completed a bachelors of science degree and wish to change their career journey. Apply Now Contact Program Director Violet Nxedhlana Program Director (808) 956-8632 violetnx@hawaii.edu Qualities of a Medical Laboratory Scientist: Passion for science Have a technical aptitude Good problem-solving skills Adaptability Good communication skills Team Player Compassion Are detail-oriented Program Prerequisites: University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa MLS Program has varying admissions requirements based on which paths you want to take. Please visit the program website for details on how to apply for each path. https://medtech.jabsom.hawaii.edu/admission/ Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Additional program fees: ~$250 per semester Total number of credits: ~60 Approximate total program tuition costs: ~$29,260 Estimated program length: (based on full time traditional student status) MLS Program: 2 years (length of time will vary per MLS path) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree pre-program requirements for the KapiÊ»olani Community College MLT program which serves as a career pathway to the UH MÄnoa MLS program: General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite - Placement into ENG 100 MATH 103: College Algebra *Prerequisite - âCâ or better in MATH 75X or 82X, OR placement into MATH 100 HWST 107: Hawaiian Piko *Prerequisite - Placement into ENG 100S PSY 100: *Prerequisite - None *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Career Pathway 2 X 2 Model:  MLT - MLS Students who complete the KapiÊ»olani Community College Associates of Science Degree in Medical Lab Technician (MLT) can qualify to apply for the Bachelors of Science in Medical Technologies at the University of HawaiÊ»i at MÄnoa (MLS) . It offers the educational preparation required of dental hygienists to provide oral health care and education to the people of Hawaii, the continental U.S., and the Pacific-Asia region. Students majoring in dental hygiene can become licensed professionals who offer preventive, education, and therapeutic services for the control of oral diseases and the promotion of optimum oral health. The UH Manoa Bachelor of Science in Dental Hygiene has two different pathways depending you each students education background and circumstances: High School Direct Entry in Dental Hygiene For High School Graduates from the Class of 2023 Fall (August) admission only. This full-time cohort program admits high school graduates who will complete their Bachelor of Science in dental hygiene degree in four years. With direct entry into our program, a studentâs academic path is secure. Bachelor of Science in Dental Hygiene For Current UH Manoa, Transfer & Veteran Students. Fall (August) admission. This full-time program admits current UH Manoa, transfer and veteran students to the Bachelor of Science degree program following completion of prerequisite and the majority of general education courses. Students will learn to operate and maintain laboratory equipment. Graduates of this program will be eligible to challenge the national certification examination for Medical Laboratory Technician (MLT) given by the American Society for Clinical Pathology (ASCP). When certified, the MLT graduate will meet the requirements for state licensure and meet minimum qualifications to work in the State of HawaiÊ»i as a Medical Laboratory Technician. subcontent.text: UH West Oâahu Public Administration - Healthcare Administration Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Public Administration - Healthcare Administration Home Health Services PUBA-Healthcare Program Description: The University of HawaiÊ»iâWest OÊ»ahu Bachelor of Arts in Public Administration degree prepares students for supervisory and management roles in the public sector. Students receive a solid foundation in public sector practices and processes as well as a fundamental understanding of, and appreciation for, public sector management practices and administrative procedures. Students may also go on to pursue graduate degrees in varied programs, such as Public Administration, Criminal Justice, Health Care Administration, and Urban and Regional Planning, Management Science. The Public Administration program offers concentrations in: Community Health Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management Health Care Administration General Public Administration Justice Administration Long-Term Care Certificates in Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management, Health Care Administration, and Long-Term Care are also available. All students majoring in Public Administration are required to take core courses and complete a capstone course (e.g., Senior Project or Administrative Practicum). The Health Care Administration concentration of the bachelors in Public Administration degree is designed to further a studentâs understanding of central concepts of health care systems as well as analyze and provide solutions to health care challenges. The program provides students with the essential skills and knowledge to work as health care administrators in hospitals, ambulatory care centers, and long-term care facilities. This concentration will also assist those who are already employed in the health care field to fully develop management, legal, and behavioral skills for more effective job performance. UH West Oâahu offers a Bachelorâs Degree in Public Administration with a concentration in Health Care Administration, as well as a Health Care Administration certificate program. The Health Care Administration program is the only undergraduate degree of its kind in the state and is offered in-class and through distance learning. Apply Now Program Contact Dr. Kristina Lu, Professor Program Contact (808) 689-2361 kguo@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to University of HawaiÊ»i West OÊ»ahu *See Articulation Agreement below for UH Maui College Dental Hygiene transfer student requirements Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $306 Additional fees: Up to $130 per semester Total number of credits: 120 Approximate total UH West OÊ»ahu PUBA program tuition costs: ~$37,760 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status) PUBA program courses and prerequisite courses: 4 year Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the UH West OÊ»ahu PUBA program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree pre-program requirements for the UH West OÊ»ahu PUBA program. PUBA program Prerequisite Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100 MATH 115: Intro to Statistics *Prerequisite: âCâ or better in MATH 82, OR placement into MATH 100 PSY 100: Survey of Psychology *Prerequisite: None SP 151: Personal and Public Speech *Prerequisite: Placement into ENG 100 PUBA 101: Introduction to Health Care Administration *Prerequisite: None *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. subcontent.title: Diagnostic Services Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Diagnostic Services Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Diagnostic Services Admission Requirements Home Pathways & Programs Admission Requirements Some post-secondary (college) healthcare programs in HawaiÊ»i have what is called Selected Admission: These are competitive programs that only admit a limited number of students. These programs have a rigorous application process, and only highly qualified candidates are accepted. Applying to these programs happens AFTER you are admitted to the college or university of your choice and have completed the basic prerequisites for that campus nursing program. The basic admissions requirements are: Course prerequisites: Selected admissions programs have specific prerequisite coursework that must be completed before applying. These prerequisites usually include biology, chemistry, anatomy, and physiology courses and may vary campus (see campus program page for more details).. GPA requirements: Some programs have minimum GPA requirements that applicants must meet with all prerequisite courses. These requirements can vary per campus. Application process: All applicants who meet eligibility requirements will be reviewed and ranked according to the criteria outlined by each campus. All available seats will be offered to applicants with the highest-ranking scores. Internship or work experience: Some selected admissions programs also prioritize applicants with relevant internships or work experience in a health care setting. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to later apply for the a healthcare program with selected admission, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs in Diagnostic services: Kapiolani Community College UH Maui College * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. text: Emergency Medical Services | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Emergency Medical Services Home Pathways and Programs Health Services EMS Emergency Medical Services Pathway Map to Employment Careers in Emergency Medical Services (EMS) involve providing immediate medical care, transport, and assistance to individuals experiencing medical emergencies, trauma, or urgent health situations. EMS professionals play a vital role in saving lives, stabilizing patients, and ensuring their safe transport to medical facilities. Careers in EMS require strong communication skills, quick decision-making, adaptability, and a dedication to helping those in need. Professionals in this field provide critical care in high-stress and time-sensitive situations, making their work invaluable to the health and safety of communities. Students in the emergency medical services program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into healthcare with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the emergency medical services program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore healthcare through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in emergency medical services will require additional training and education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training is required, you are able to attain entry level certifications that will allow you to work in the healthcare field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview: The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey: If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement: As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text:
Emergency Medical Services Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES
			    ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi There are several benefits to obtaining entry-level training programs or certifications to further your journey to a career in health services. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. Here are a few reasons why obtaining one or more of theses certifications would help you on your path to working in the health field: Enhanced Knowledge and Skills: Entry-level certifications provide you with foundational knowledge and skills related to healthcare and patient care. This can give you a head start in understanding basic concepts and procedures, making it easier to grasp more advanced nursing concepts during your studies. Competitive Advantage: Health programs can be competitive, with limited spots available. Having entry-level certifications can set you apart from other applicants by demonstrating your commitment to the healthcare field and your readiness to contribute to patient care. It shows that you have taken the initiative to acquire relevant skills and experience, making you a more attractive candidate. Practical Experience: Entry-level certifications can provide you with exposure to real healthcare settings, allowing you to become familiar with the clinical environment, patient interactions, and healthcare team dynamics. Networking Opportunities: Obtaining entry-level certifications can help you build connections with healthcare professionals, instructors, and potential employers. Networking within the healthcare field will allow you to have a greater understanding of careers in healthcare through these connections. Improved Employability: Possessing entry-level certification can make you more competitive in the job market and increase your chances of finding employment as a healthcare professional. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for emergency medical services-related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for nursing-related careers: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for healthcare professionals, including nurses.
Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Phlebotomy certification: Involves the collection of blood samples for laboratory testing or medical purposes. By successfully completing a phlebotomy training program from an accredited institution, which includes classroom instruction on topics like anatomy and physiology, venipuncture techniques, infection control, medical terminology, and legal and ethical considerations, students can obtain certification by a recognized certifying agency. Range of program duration: 100-150 hours Theses training programs can lead to the following Jobs: Phlebotmist Caregivers Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. Hawaii Career Pathways builds bridges between schools and industries so students can get training and education for high-skill, high-wage professions. subcontent.title: Kapiâolani Community College Mobile Intensive Care Technician Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Kapiâolani Community College Mobile Intensive Care Technician Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Mobile Intensive Care Technician Program Home Health Mobile Intensive Care Technician Program Description: The Mobile Intensive Care Technician (MICT) which is also known as the Paramedic (EMT-P). Certification as an EMT is a prerequisite to the MICT program. The MICT is prepared to perform advanced life support functions in the pre-hospital emergency setting under the direction of a medical doctor. In addition to all functions performed by an EMT, a MICT performs advanced functions such as administering intravenous fluids; administering medication; performing endotracheal intubation; recording and reading electrocardiograms; using the cardiac monitor defibrillator. GMICTuates are qualified to take the National Registry Examination for certification as an EMT-P and can apply for work with an ambulance service. Apply Now Health Career Program Counselors Shepherd Maingano Health Career Program Counselors (808) 734-9224 hlthsci@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: KapaiÊ»olani Community Collegeâs MICT program has select admissions, meaning you must complete the following before you apply to enter the MICT program: Apply to KapiÊ»olani Community College Attend at Health Careers Information Sessions Meet with the Health Program counselors to let them know that you want to be in the MICT program. They will advise you on what you need to complete in order to apply for MICT. Register for courses on the program prerequisite course list. Pass each class with a âCâ or better, âC-â is not accepted! Complete all of the prerequisite courses with a minimum GPA of 2.5. Meet with the counselors again to make sure you have completed all the necessary prerequisites to apply for the MICT programÊ»s Associates of Science degree!! Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Additional MICT program costs: Up to $5000 Total number of credits: 73 Approximate total program tuition costs: $14,620 Estimated program length: (based on full time student status) Program Prerequisite courses: 1 year MICT Program: 1.5 - 2 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students who are interested in the KapiÊ»olani Community College MICT program and can be completed through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree pre-program requirements for the KapiÊ»olani Community College MICT program. KapiÊ»olani Community College MICT program prerequisite courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite - Placement into ENG 100 MATH 103: College Algebra *Prerequisite - âCâ or better in MATH 82, OR placement into MATH 103 HLTH 125: Survey of Medical Terminology (1 credit) *Prerequisite - None HDFS 230: Human Development *Prerequisite - None *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: Students who complete the KapiÊ»olani Community CollegeÊ»s Mobile Intensive Care Technician Associate's degree program can apply via a transfer agreement with the 4-year university programs listed below. subcontent.text: Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Emergency Medical Services Admission Requirements Home Pathways & Programs Admission Requirements Some post-secondary (college) healthcare programs in HawaiÊ»i have what is called Selected Admission: These are competitive programs that only admit a limited number of students. These programs have a rigorous application process, and only highly qualified candidates are accepted. Applying to these programs happens AFTER you are admitted to the college or university of your choice and have completed the basic prerequisites for that campus nursing program. The basic admissions requirements are: Course prerequisites: Selected admissions programs have specific prerequisite coursework that must be completed before applying. These prerequisites usually include biology, chemistry, anatomy, and physiology courses and may vary campus (see campus program page for more details). GPA requirements: Some programs have minimum GPA requirements that applicants must meet with all prerequisite courses. These requirements can vary per campus. Application process: All applicants who meet eligibility requirements will be reviewed and ranked according to the criteria outlined by each campus. All available seats will be offered to applicants with the highest-ranking scores. Internship or work experience: Some selected admissions programs also prioritize applicants with relevant internships or work experience in a health care setting. For specific prerequisite courses, test scores and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to later apply for the a healthcare program with selected admission, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs in Emergency Medical services: Kapiâolani Community College * University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. Students receive a solid foundation in public sector practices and processes as well as a fundamental understanding of, and appreciation for, public sector management practices and administrative procedures. Students may also go on to pursue graduate degrees in varied programs, such as Public Administration, Criminal Justice, Health Care Administration, and Urban and Regional Planning, Management Science. The Public Administration program offers concentrations in: Community Health Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management Health Care Administration General Public Administration Justice Administration Long-Term Care Certificates in Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management, Health Care Administration, and Long-Term Care are also available. All students majoring in Public Administration are required to take core courses and complete a capstone course (e.g., Senior Project or Administrative Practicum). Students receive a solid foundation in public sector practices and processes as well as a fundamental understanding of, and appreciation for, public sector management practices and administrative procedures. Students may also go on to pursue graduate degrees in varied programs, such as Public Administration, Criminal Justice, Health Care Administration, and Urban and Regional Planning, Management Science. The Public Administration program offers concentrations in: Community Health Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management Health Care Administration General Public Administration Justice Administration Long-Term Care Certificates in Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management, Health Care Administration, and Long-Term Care are also available. All students majoring in Public Administration are required to take core courses and complete a capstone course (e.g., Senior Project or Administrative Practicum). The study of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management provides students with a broad range of administrative skills and knowledge that are ideally suited to meet the critical needs of emergency management administrators. At UH West Oâahu, students may pursue a Bachelor of Arts in Public Administration with a concentration in disaster preparedness & emergency management or a certificate in Disaster Preparedness & Emergency Management. All courses meet the national standards as established by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Higher Education Project. Courses for the bachelorâs degree and certificate are offered through in-class and distance learning instruction. The disaster preparedness and emergency management concentration is the only upper division disaster management program in the State of HawaiÊ»i. subcontent.text: Recommended Health Early College Courses | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Recommended Health Early College Courses Home Pathways & Programs Health Early College Below are the recommended college courses that high school students can complete as participants in HawaiÊ»iâs Dual Credit Program , which includes Early College (EC) and Running Start (RS) programs. The following identified course will meet degree requirements for each track (2-year associate degree or 4-year bachelor degree) and may reduce a student's time to degree completion. These courses can be taken in partnership with any University of HawaiÊ»i Community College (UHCC) Campus and aligns generally with all of the HIDOE IT Pathway Programs of Study. For UHCC campus and program of study specific EC courses, please see college campus pages. It is highly recommended that students reach out to their high school counselor and/or a postsecondary counselor/advisor at the UH campus prior to enrolling in any early postsecondary opportunities (including EC and RS) . text: Human Performance Therapeutic Services | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Human Performance Therapeutic Services Home Pathways and Programs Health Services HPTS Human Performance Therapeutic Services Pathway Map to Employment Careers in human performance therapeutic services (HTPS) revolve around improving individuals' physical, mental, and emotional well-being to enhance their overall performance, quality of life, and functional abilities. These professionals work with clients to prevent and manage injuries, optimize physical capabilities, and promote overall health. Careers in HTPS require a strong understanding of anatomy, physiology, and movement mechanics, as well as excellent communication and interpersonal skills. These professionals contribute to the overall health, well-being, and improved quality of life for their clients. Students in the human performance therapeutic services program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into healthcare with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the human performance therapeutic services program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore healthcare through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in human performance therapeutic services will require additional training and education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training is required, you are able to attain entry level certifications that will allow you to work in the healthcare field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview: The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey: If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement: As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Human Performance Therapeutic Services Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Human Performance Therapeutic Services ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi There are several benefits to obtaining entry-level training programs or certifications to further your journey to a career in health services. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation, like the Good Jobs JawaiÊ»i training programs. Here are a few reasons why obtaining one or more of theses certifications would help you on your path to working in the health field: Enhanced Knowledge and Skills: Entry-level certifications provide you with foundational knowledge and skills related to healthcare and patient care. This can give you a head start in understanding basic concepts and procedures, making it easier to grasp more advanced nursing concepts during your studies. Competitive Advantage: Health programs can be competitive, with limited spots available. Having entry-level certifications can set you apart from other applicants by demonstrating your commitment to the healthcare field and your readiness to contribute to patient care. It shows that you have taken the initiative to acquire relevant skills and experience, making you a more attractive candidate. Practical Experience: Entry-level certifications can provide you with exposure to real healthcare settings, allowing you to become familiar with the clinical environment, patient interactions, and healthcare team dynamics. Networking Opportunities: Obtaining entry-level certifications can help you build connections with healthcare professionals, instructors, and potential employers. Networking within the healthcare field will allow you to have a greater understanding of careers in healthcare through these connections. Improved Employability: Possessing entry-level certification can make you more competitive in the job market and increase your chances of finding employment as a healthcare professional. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for Human Performance Therapeutic Services-related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for nursing-related careers: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for healthcare professionals, including nurses. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Personal Trainer Certification: Personal trainer certification is a critical step for individuals pursuing a career in the fitness industry. It ensures that trainers have the necessary knowledge and skills to guide clients toward their fitness goals and promote a healthy lifestyle. The specific requirements and certification processes may vary among certifying organizations, so individuals should research and choose the one that best aligns with their career goals and interests. Range of program duration: 4 to 6 weeks Licensed Massage Therapist: Massage therapists use a variety of techniques to apply pressure, knead, rub, or otherwise manipulate the muscles and soft tissues of the body. These techniques can include Swedish massage (gentle, long strokes), deep tissue massage (firm pressure targeting deep muscles), sports massage (focused on athletes and sports-related issues), hot stone massage (heated stones placed on the body), and many others. Range of program duration: 500-600 hours Certified Pharmacy Technician: A pharmacy technician is a healthcare professional who works alongside pharmacists to assist in various pharmacy-related tasks. Their primary responsibilities revolve around supporting the pharmacy's operations, ensuring the safe and efficient dispensing of prescription medications, and providing excellent customer service.  Students will develop skills in calculation, drug classification, processing, inventory, and billing in retail and hospital settings. Range of program duration: 100-150 hours Theses training programs can lead to the following Jobs: Personal Trainer Massage Therapist Pharmancy Techician Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Kapiâolani Community College Physical Therapy Assistant Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Physical Therapy Assistant Program Home Health Physical Therapy Assistant Program Description: The Physical Therapist Assistant (PTA) works with patients under the direction of a licensed physical therapist and implements therapeutic programs which could include the application of physical agents (such as heat, cold, water, and electricity) as well as massage, exercise, and functional activities. The PTA also observes the patients during treatment and reports progress to the physical therapist. Physical therapy patients are those who have not developed or have lost the ability to carry out everyday life skills due to disability, accident, injury, or illness. The goal of physical therapy is to assist patients in learning and improving life skills such as walking and moving about with braces, artificial limbs, and other assistive devices. The purpose of this curriculum is to prepare students for licensure and employment as a Physical Therapist Assistant (PTA) in HawaiÊ»i and the United States with the knowledge and abilities to provide care in a variety of settings requiring the rehabilitation of patients who were born with a disability or are disabled as a result of illness, injury, or accident. The Physical Therapist Assistant works under the direction and supervision of Licensed Physical Therapists (PTs). PTAs implement the plan of care developed by the PT following the standards in the American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) Guide to Physical Therapist Practice, APTA Core Values, individual state practice acts, and the APTA policies. The PTA program is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation in Physical Therapy Education (CAPTE). They will advise you on what you need to complete in order to apply for PTA. Register for courses on the program prerequisite course list. Pass each class with a âCâ or better, âC-â is not accepted! Complete all of the prerequisite courses with a minimum GPA of 2.5. Meet with the counselors again to make sure you have completed all the necessary prerequisites to apply for the Physical Therapy Assistant programÊ»s Associates of Science degree! subcontent.text: UH West Oâahu Respiratory Care | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Respiratory Care Program Home Health Services Respiratory Care Program Description: Respiratory Care involves the treatment of those with asthma, cystic fibrosis, bronchiolitis, lung injury, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and other respiratory-related ailments. Those trained in the field evaluate, treat, monitor and aid in the prevention of many breathing disorders. Kapiâolani Community College is one of many accredited two-year Respiratory Therapy programs across the nation and the only program in the state. Through programs like these, students learn the technical training needed to work in the field and are well-prepared to earn the credentials of a Certified and Registered Respiratory Therapist. UH West Oâahuâs Bachelor of Applied Science degree, with a concentration in Respiratory Care , is designed to supplement the technical training that a student receives in an accredited associate degree Respiratory Therapy program. Students develop job skills that are needed to excel in the industry, such as critical thinking and communication skills. The program also exposes students to the historical, cultural, and social context of the profession. In addition, courses in research and contemporary health care issues expand the depth in the studentsâ applied health sciences knowledge base. UH West Oâahu courses are delivered both in-class and through distance learning instruction. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: The UH West OÊ»ahu BAS: Concentration in respiratory care (RESP) offers working professionals who have earned the Associate in Science (A.S.) degree in respiratory care at Kapiâolani Community College (KCC) the opportunity to earn a baccalaureate degree and to continue for advanced education in respiratory care. The additional requirements in the liberal arts and sciences will contribute to increasing academic skills development, advancing knowledge, attaining career goals, and meeting the needs of the health care community in the areas of leadership, clinical practice, research and education. This program area has been structured to enable the student to design an academic curriculum that reflects their individual interests in this program. Career paths within this area of study include, but are not limited to: athletic training exercise physiology sports nutrition physical therapy sports psychology/rehabilitation counseling coaching/personal training Additionally, this degree program has been designed to fulfill the requirements for entry into graduate programs in the area of health sciences (e.g. Athletic Training, Physical Therapy, Occupational Therapy, Physicians Assistant, Physician, Nurse, Nurse Practitioner). subcontent.text: Kapiâolani Community College Respiratory Care Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial (R & C) Construction Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Respiratory Care Program Home Health Respiratory Care Program Description: In the Respiratory Care (RESP) program, you will learn to care for patients with cardiovascular and pulmonary system disorders. Specifically, you will learn to perform routine therapy such as oxygen, lung inflation, and secretion management, as well as, critical care modalities such as ventilator management, arterial puncture and analysis, neonatal and pediatric care, home care, sleep technology, hemodynamics, and ECG. You will receive laboratory training followed by hands-on experience in hospitals, labs, and home care sites. The Associate in Science degree in Respiratory Care is a fully accredited program that requires completed credits in liberal arts prior to entering the six semesters of professional training and additional credits of arts electives to receive the Associate in Science degree in Respiratory Care (ASRC) and registry eligibility to sit for national credentialing exams. The Respiratory Care program prepares students to care for patients with cardiovascular and pulmonary system disorders. Specifically, students will learn to perform routine therapy such as oxygen, lung inflation, and secretion management, as well as, critical care modalities such as ventilator management, arterial puncture and analysis, neonatal and pediatric care, sleep technology, hemodynamics, and ECG. Students also will receive laboratory training followed by hands-on experience in hospitals, labs, and home care sites. Apply Now Program Director Jung Eun Kim Program Director (808) 734-9243 jungeun@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: KapiÊ»olani Community Collegeâs RESP program has select admissions , meaning you must complete the following before you apply to enter the RESP program: Apply to KapiÊ»olani Community College Attend at Health Careers Information Sessions Meet with the Health Program counselors to let them know that you want to be in the RESP program. They will advise you on what you need to complete in order to apply for RESP. Register for courses on the program prerequisite course list. Pass each class with a âCâ or better, âC-â is not accepted! Complete all of the prerequisite courses with a minimum GPA of 2.5. Meet with the counselors again to make sure you have completed all the necessary prerequisites to apply for the Respiratory Care Practitioner programÊ»s Associates of Science degree! Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Additional RESP program costs: Up to $500 per semester Total number of credits: 95-96 Approximate total program tuition costs: ~$16,000 - $19.000 Estimated program length: Prerequisites courses: 1 year REPS program courses: 2.5 3 years Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree pre-program requirements for the KapiÊ»olani Community College RESP program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100: Composition I *Prerequisite - âCâ or better in ENG 22 OR Placement into ENG 100 MATH 103: College Algebra *Prerequisite - âCâ or better in MATH 82, OR placement into MATH 103 HWST 107: Hawaiian Piko *Prerequisite - None PSY 100: *Prerequisite - Placement into ENG 100 AND MATH 82 HLTH 125: Survey of Medical Terminology *Prerequisite - None MICRO 130: General Microbiology *Prerequisite - None *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration. Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: The UH West OÊ»ahu BAS: Concentration in respiratory care (RESP) offers working professionals who have earned the Associate in Science (A.S.) degree in respiratory care at Kapiâolani Community College (KCC) the opportunity to earn a baccalaureate degree and to continue for advanced education in respiratory care. The additional requirements in the liberal arts and sciences will contribute to increasing academic skills development, advancing knowledge, attaining career goals, and meeting the needs of the health care community in the areas of leadership, clinical practice, research and education. Performance Therapeutic Services Admission Requirements Home Pathways & Programs Admission Requirements Some post-secondary (college) healthcare programs in HawaiÊ»i have what is called Selected Admission : These are competitive programs that only admit a limited number of students. These programs have a rigorous application process, and only highly qualified candidates are accepted. Applying to these programs happens AFTER you are admitted to the college or university of your choice and have completed the basic prerequisites for that campus nursing program. The basic admissions requirements are: Course prerequisites: Selected admissions programs have specific prerequisite coursework that must be completed before applying. These prerequisites usually include biology, chemistry, anatomy, and physiology courses and may vary campus (see campus program page for more details). GPA requirements: Some programs have minimum GPA requirements that applicants must meet with all prerequisite courses. These requirements can vary per campus. Application process: All applicants who meet eligibility requirements will be reviewed and ranked according to the criteria outlined by each campus. All available seats will be offered to applicants with the highest-ranking scores. Internship or work experience: Some selected admissions programs also prioritize applicants with relevant internships or work experience in a health care setting. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to later apply for the a healthcare program with selected admission, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs in Human Performance Therapeutic services: Kapiolani Community College * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i Hilo * University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow.
