subcontent.title: Kapiâolani Community College Information Technology Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Kapiâolani Community College Information Technology Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Information Technology Program Home Networking Information Technology Program Description: The Information Technology program is career-laddered and competency-based. The program focuses on strong programming fundamentals, network connectivity, hands-on type projects, front-end graphical user interface (GUI) programming with strong connectivity to databases such as Microsoft ACCESS, Microsoft SQL Server, and Oracle in a stand alone as well as web environment. It provides training in the use and support of business-related computer systems, data communication networks (including local area networks), World Wide Web and its importance to businesses, and the development of business information technology systems programs using procedural and object-oriented programming techniques. The program includes a combination of business, computer, and information technology courses. Campus-based computer and networking projects, faculty-supervised laboratories, and workplace internships provide hands-on experience designed to prepare students for positions in computer support, programming, network hardware set up and configuration, or systems development in a business information technology system. The program focuses on computers, the Internet and the World Wide Web, and information technology as tools to solve business problems. The program trains students in the management of storage and the use of client-server environments in the accessing, processing, storing, and networking of information on computer-based business systems. Todayâs modern computing environment is a network of interrelated computer systems with connections via a local area network, wide area network, and the Internet. These computer-systems provide access to a variety of information to facilitate the operation of a business. The Information Technology program atKapiÊ»olani Community Collegeâs ensures student currency in these areas through courses in information technology. Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator David Stevens Program Coordinator (808) 734-9843 dsteven3@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Placement into English 100 Placement into Math 103 Industry Related Credentials: Certain IT courses also help to prepare you to take the following industry certification exams: CompTIA A+ CompTIA Network+ CompTIA Security+ Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits 60-62 Approximate total program tuition costs: $7,869-$8,646 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the Kapiolani Community College IT  program. General Academic Courses: ENG 100 Composition I *Prerequisite - âCâ or better in ENG 22, OR placement into ENG 100 Math 103 College Algebra *Prerequisite - âCâ or better in MATH 82, OR placement into ENG 103 Program Specific Courses: ICS 101: Digital tools for the informational world *Prerequisite - Placement into ENG 100, AND Placement into MATH 103 ICS 111 Introduction to Computer Science *Prerequisite - Placement into MATH 135 or higher *Prerequisites are courses or other background that must be completed PRIOR to enrollment. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration.  Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. National Center for Academic Excellence in Cybersecurity (NCAE-C): Designation: CAE - Cyber Defense Education Sponsored by the National Security Agency (NSA), CAE-C designations are awarded to institutions that commit to producing cybersecurity professionals that will reduce vulnerabilities in our national infrastructure. KapiÊ»olani Community College was named a National Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense (CAE-CD) by the National Security Agency (NSA) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). The CAE-CD designation is awarded to regionally accredited academic institutions that offer high-quality cybersecurity-related degrees and certificates. The CAE-CD designation is based on a combination of elements related to the institution, focused on outputs for determining academic achievement. As a recognized institution, KapiÊ»olani CC has demonstrated that it engages in significant community involvement, embeds cybersecurity awareness in classes throughout the campus, encourages faculty professional development, integrates cybersecurity practices within the institution and prepares students to meet the growing need for professionals with cybersecurity skills. âThrough the guidance of the NSA and DHS to become a CAE-CD institution, our cybersecurity learning pathway incorporates real-life scenarios, critical-thinking and problem-solving exercises, hands-on labs, industry certificate preparation and cooperative decision-making activities, resulting in fully prepared cybersecurity professionals,â said KapiÊ»olani CC IT Director Dale Nakasone. âThe CAE designation will benefit graduates from KapiÊ»olani CC who will have the potential to become highly sought after as candidates for high-paying industry careers.â Transfer Agreements (Articulation)*: Students who complete the Associate of Science degree in IT may apply to transfer to the following programs via a transfer agreement with the 4-year university programs listed below. UH West Oahu - Bachelors of Applied Science in Information Technology ( Articulation Agreement - Fall 2019 ) Transfer agreements (also known as Articulation Agreements) are individual agreements between programs that facilitate a smooth transition from 2-year associate degree programs to 4-year bachelor degree programs. Interface Design course topics include graphic design, web design, front-end interface programming, typography, graphic symbolism, digital multimedia, and motion graphic design. Additional courses include digital imaging, design history and portfolio development. The program is intended to serve students preparing for a career in interface design and professionals updating and refining their job skills. The program integrates classroom instruction with hands-on production skills in a learning environment that encourages the full design process for interface design as dictated by the industry and utilized in the field. The Associate in Science degree, New Media Arts with a specialization in Interface Design, will introduce students to the theory, technology, aesthetics, business, and production process of interface design. Upon completion of the ABIT program, many students apply for graduate programs, launch an entrepreneurial start-up, or accept employment in a small to large-sized company. The program can be completed in 4 years* (8 full-time semesters). Students who have completed an associate degree can transfer to the upper division program and complete the ABIT BAS in 4 semesters and 60 credits, using a traditional 16-week semester format. Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Dr. Debasis Bhattacharya Program Coordinator (808) 984-3619 debasisb@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete an associates degree in IT/ICS from an aligned community college (see articulation agreements below). Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration.  Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus National Center for Academic Excellence in Cybersecurity (NCAE-C): Designation: CAE - Cyber Defense Research Sponsored by the National Security Agency (NSA), CAE-C designations are awarded to institutions that commit to producing cybersecurity professionals that will reduce vulnerabilities in our national infrastructure. The University of Hawaii Maui College (UHMC) has been designated as a National Center of Academic Excellence (CAE) in Cyber Defense Education (CDE) through the academic year 2024 for the Bachelor of Applied Science (BAS) in Applied Business and Information Technology (ABIT) Degree . The Center for Cybersecurity Education and Research (CCER) was established at the University of Hawaii Maui College in 2015, to provide the local community and students with cybersecurity education, training and guidance. The mission of CCER is to provide cybersecurity guidance, training and workforce development activities to the local community, K-12 students and teachers, as well as students enrolled at UHMC. The program recognizes evolving technology drives content creation and emerging media platforms. The Creative Media degree offers concentrations in General Creative Media, Communications and New Media Technologies, Design and Media (Includes Web Design) and Game Design and Development. You may find this degree of interest if you want to pursue software development as a career path or go to graduate school in computer science. In addition to the general track, the ICS Department also offers two specialized BS CS tracks: Data Science and Security Science. Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Kenny Kaâaiakamanu-Quibilan Program Coordinator (808) 956-5428 kennydq@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to UH MÄnoa Competition of General Education courses Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $471 Total number of credits 120 Approximate total program tuition costs: $48,744 Estimated program length: 4 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. Prerequisites are REQUIRED for registration.  Please contact program coordinator or advisor for information on placement into courses as there are multiple methods of placement per campus. National Center for Academic Excellence in Cybersecurity (NCAE-C): Designation: CAE - Cyber Defense Research Sponsored by the National Security Agency (NSA), CAE-C designations are awarded to institutions that commit to producing cybersecurity professionals that will reduce vulnerabilities in our national infrastructure. The research of cybersecurity faculty at the University of HawaiÊ»i - Manoa (UHM) covers many critical issues, including cryptography, cloud security, loT security, information assurance, machine learning security, mobile/wireless security, network security, smart grid security, software/hardware security, supported by AFOSR, AFRL, EPSRC, NASA, NSA, NSF, NRL, ONR, ODNI, and industrial partners. UHM faculty have published 300+ papers in prestigious peer-reviewed journals and conferences, mentored security-focused graduate students, served as journal editors and reviewers, led research conferences, and given keynotes/invited talks at research conferences. These research successes earned UHM a CAE-R designation in May 2015. The designation provided many opportunities for Hawaiian communities including the establishment of the NSF CyberCorpsÂ® SFS program in 2016. UHM has enhanced computer science BA/BS degrees with a Security Science Concentration and a management MS degree with Information Security. UHM collaborated with local government, education institutions, and industry communities and founded CyberHawaiâi in 2016, which broadens our outreach with high schools, community colleges, Hawaiâi DOD, Hawaiâi DOE, etc. Jobs Hawaiâi Career Explorer Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text: Chaminade University Computer Science | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us BS Computer Science and Data Science, Analytics, & Visualization Home Networking Computer Science Program Description: We donât have to tell you how important computers are to everyday life. We use computers for communication, for learning, to have fun and to work. We use them for getting around town, getting around the country and for national security. Computers help us run airports, schools, hospitalsâeven our government. Itâs hard to imagine a world without themâand easy to see why computer science skills are in very high demand across just about every sector and just about everywhere. To prepare you for this ever-changing field, our Computer Science program is focused on hands-on learning so you can turn theory into practice and embrace critical thinking. We also believe in the power of social responsibility and so seek to inspire you to find ways to make a positive difference. Our innovative courses explore everything from software engineering to operating systems to computer architecture. And across our offerings, youâll have a strong network of support, including experienced faculty mentors and advisors who will help you map out your own academic path. The Data Science, Analytics and Visualization program is about preparing graduates for the data revolution that is occurring in every sector of the economy. Data Science is a fastest growing sector in computer science with millions of emerging jobs. Thatâs why we developed Hawaiiâs first B.S. Data Science Analytics and Visualization degree. An exceptional technical foundation is paired with an emphasis on data ethics and communication. Tailored programs allow you to specialize in business analytics, healthcare informatics, environmental analytics or S&T analytics. A graduate will be indispensable to a wide variety of employer organizations who need to leverage data to advance their missions. Your pre-graduation internships and real-world projects with big business, small business, agencies and community organizations will connect you to your future employers. Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Dr. Rylan Chong Program Coordinator (808) 739-7445 rylan.chong@chaminade.edu Program Prerequisites: Admission to Chaminade University Competition of pre-program courses Cost and time commitment: Starting in Fall 2023, Chaminade Universityâs HawaiÊ»i Guarantee provides local high school graduates entering as freshmen the same tuition rate as University of Hawaiâi at Manoaâs annual resident undergraduate tuition AND an achievable pathway to graduate in four years. The program includes a combination of business, computer, and information technology courses. Campus-based computer and networking projects, faculty supervised laboratories, and workplace internships provide hands-on experience designed to prepare students for positions in computer support, programming, network administration, or systems development in a business information technology system. The program focuses on computers and information technology as tools to solve business problems. subcontent.text: Admission Requirements | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Admission Requirements Home Pathways & Programs Admission Requirements The  minimum admission requirements for the various colleges and universities in Hawaiâi are detailed below. You must meet the minimum admission requirement for each college or university to participate in any of their degree programs.  Additional prerequisite program requirements can be found on each programâs page on this site. * Universities have a selective admissions process and consider a number of factors in addition to the minimum admission requirements for acceptance. See links to each Universityâs admission page for more information. UH Community Colleges Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i Hilo * University of HawaiÊ»i West Oahu Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form * Chaminade University of Honolulu Cumulative high school GPA of 2.50 or higher High school students in dual enrollment or running start programs will need to submit official college transcripts Provide a written statement describing your interest in pursuing your degree at Chaminade University of Honolulu, and any related extracurricular activities that have prepared you for your educational goals.  This statement must be a minimum of 250 words. Test Scores (Optional) For Nursing program requirements GO HERE * HawaiÊ»i Pacific University HPU understands that each student has a unique academic history and individual talents. text: Transportation Services | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (HOST) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Transportation Home Pathways and Programs Transportation Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) The Automotive Collision Repair program equips students with the skills to perform non-structural auto repairs, including bodywork, surface preparation, and painting. Students will learn to assess collision damage, estimate repair costs, and apply customer service skills when working with vehicle owners. Automotive Maintenance & Light Repair (MLR) The Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair program prepares students with the technical skills for bumper-to-bumper maintenance and light repairs, covering engine systems, transmissions, drive trains, suspension, brakes, electrical systems, and heating/air conditioning. Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) The Aviation Maintenance Technology program trains students in servicing, troubleshooting, and repairing aircraft, with a focus on electrical systems, airframe applications, and ethics. Graduates will be prepared for FAA airframe and powerplant certification exams with advanced training. Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) The Marine Maintenance Technology program equips students with skills to service, diagnose, and repair marine engines, as well as install equipment and rigging. Training includes two- and four-stroke outboards, inboard engines, fuel injection systems, outdrives, and transmissions. text: Automotive Maintenance & Light Repair | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (HOST) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Automotive Collision Repair Home Pathways and Programs Transportation Automotive Maintenance Repair Automotive Maintenance & Light Repair Pathway Map to Employment Careers in automotive maintenance and light repair focus on diagnosing and repairing basic vehicle issues to ensure safe and efficient operation. Professionals in this field perform tasks like routine maintenance (oil changes, tire rotations, and brake inspections), minor repairs on engine systems, electrical components, and heating/cooling systems, and troubleshooting mechanical problems. Entry-level positions, such as automotive technician or service specialist , often serve as a stepping stone to more advanced roles, including master technician or shop supervisor . With growing vehicle complexity, knowledge of computerized diagnostics and hybrid systems is increasingly valuable. These careers offer opportunities in dealerships, repair shops, fleet services, and more, combining hands-on technical work with problem-solving skills. Students in the automotive maintenance & light repair program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into this field with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities to help them understand the current landscape of this industry. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the Automotive Maintenance & Light Repair program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore the industry through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in Automotive Maintenance & Light Repair may require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training might be required, you may also be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview: The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement: As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. subcontent.text:
automotive maintenance & light repair Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us automotive maintenance & light repair
			    ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Transportation Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi For entry-level positions in the automotive maintenance & light repair industry, several industry-related credentials can enhance your qualifications and demonstrate foundational knowledge and skills. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. The following are some NON-CREDIT (not related to college) programs you can take that will help you in your career journey. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for automotive maintenance & light repair related careers: OSHA 10 General - If youâre an entry-level worker, our OSHA 10-Hour Outreach General & Healthcare Industry course is your orientation to occupational safety and health. As part of OSHA's Outreach Training program to raise awareness about the safety measures under OSHA 29 CFR 1910, this course will help teach you how to improve workplace safety. Youâll learn OSHA's best practices for reducing accidents and injuries, including fall protection, emergency evacuation plans, and the use of personal protective equipment. You'll also learn about the major hazards you might encounter in general industry work and solutions for recognizing, controlling, and protecting against them. This includes flammable and combustible substances, chemical and electrical hazards, and fire prevention. Additionally, you should know what your employer's responsibility is for your safety, as well as the rights OSHA grants you as a worker. Thatâs why you'll learn how to file a complaint if your workplace isn't living up to its safety obligations. Range of training duration: 10 hours Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for construction professionals. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Commercial Drivers License Training (CDL): A Commercial Driverâs License (CDL) is essential in the construction industry for operating heavy vehicles such as dump trucks, cement mixers, and tractor-trailers. Workers with a CDL play a critical role in transporting materials, equipment, and machinery to and from construction sites. Obtaining a CDL involves meeting specific requirements, including passing written and skills tests tailored to the type of vehicle being driven. CDL certification ensures that drivers are trained in safety protocols, vehicle operation, and compliance with transportation regulations, making it a valuable credential for construction professionals. Range of program duration: 4-8 Weeks Scissor Lift Certification: Aerial and scissor lifts play an important role in construction and many other industries. These versatile lifts come in several types with various applications and operating hazards. This course will teach you how to maximize worksite safety while working on or around aerial and scissor lifts. Only trained persons may operate aerial lifts and scissor lifts. This awareness-level certificate course complies with training requirements for aerial lifts and related scaffolding equipment found in OSHA standard 1926.454. It does not provide an OSHA-accepted certification or certification card. Range of program duration: 1-2 Hours These training programs can lead to the following entry level Jobs: Laborer Forklift operator Truck Driver Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. subcontent.text: UH MÄnoa Mechanical Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (HOST) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Mechanical Engineering (BS) Program Home Transportation Mechanical Engineering Program Description: The Department of Mechanical Engineering offers a Bachelor of Science degree in Mechanical Engineering (BS ME) . This degree requires completion of at least 121 credit hours of coursework. The curriculum consists of a group of required courses chosen to provide the students with the basic tools for the professional practice of mechanical engineering and to assist students in developing a sense of responsibility as professionals. The objectives of the lower division curriculum are to build a foundation in the basic sciences and mathematics, provide an introduction to engineering design and professional ethics, develop communications and computer programming skills, and acquire an appreciation for the humanities and social sciences. The objectives of the upper division program are to provide a sound foundation in the engineering sciences; build on that foundation for applications in the areas of energy conversion, mechanical systems and control, experimentation, and manufacturing; and encourage creativity culminating in a capstone design experience. To provide sufficient flexibility, technical elective courses enable students to acquire additional competence in areas compatible with their career objectives. All electives are subject to the approval of an adviser. Apply Now Program Prerequisites: Admission to UH MÄnoa Competition of General Education courses Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $441 Total number of credits 121 Approximate total program tuition costs: $53,361 Estimated program length: 4 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the UH Manoa BS in Mechanical Engineering program. The program is designed to provide students with knowledge of heavy duty truck engines and chassis components and to develop student proficiency in the repair and maintenance of heavy duty truck equipment. The Diesel program is currently certified in the Master Status from Automotive Service Excellence Education Foundation (ASEEF). ASEEF is a non-profit organization that evaluates and accredits entry-level automotive technology education programs against standards developed by the automotive service industry. It also develops career-readiness education for students which fuse local partnerships, rigorous standard-based education, workplace experience, and mentorship together. Admission is every other Fall semester. Program Offerings: Associates of Applied Science (AAS), DISL, 67 Credits Certificate of Achievement (CA), DISL, 27 Credits Apply Now Contact Program Coordinator Bobby Salvatierra Program Coordinator (808) 842-2541 bs33@hawaii.edu Contact Program Counselor Scott Parry Program Counselor (808) 845-9172 sparry@hawaii.edu Program Prerequisites: Complete the application process for Honolulu Community College Placement into ENG 100; MATH 50 or placement into MATH 150 or higher Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $131 Total number of credits: 80-83 Approximate total program tuition costs: $8,777 Estimated program length: 2 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the Honolulu Community College DISL program. Do you enjoy seeing how things work or taking mechanical items apart? Do you love carsâtheir engines, their complexity, their freedom? Turn your love of cars into a high-paying career! Youâll gain the skills and competencies necessary for a successful career as an automotive technician. Youâll understand and achieve the work habits and attitudes necessary to work in a highly competitive field, and how to keep ahead of the latest technological changes in the automotive field. The program offers hands-on shop training by certified instructors (Automotive Service Excellence) with years of real-world experience in the industry. It is a unique two-year work-study experience designed to develop entry-level service technicians for Ford and Lincoln/Mercury dealerships proficient in the latest automotive service technologies and methods. The ASSET program leads to an AAS degree. The program also enables graduates to make advancements in their career paths. The cost of tools and supplies is approximately $1,120. Students interested in enrolling in ASSET should see the AMT ASSET Instructor. An open-exit option allows the students to identify their career objectives and participate in program exploration. The Automotive Technology (AMT) program at Honolulu CC is a comprehensive fivesemester program that prepares students for employment as automotive technicians. Students completing the program may earn a Certificate of Achievement after one year or an Associate in Applied Science degree upon program completion. This program is currently master certified by the Automotive Service Excellence Education Foundation (ASEEF) in all eight certification areas: engine repair, automotive transmission and transaxle, manual drivetrain and axles, suspension and steering, brakes, electrical/electronics systems, heating and air conditioning, and engine performance. ASEEF is a non-profit organization that evaluates and accredits entry-level automotive technology education programs against standards developed by the automotive service industry. Electrical Engineering is a profession concerned with the design of electrical, electronic, and electro-magnetic systems. Sub-disciplines within this profession include biomedical engineering. bioengineering, electronic circuits, computers, lasers and optics, networks, signal and image processing, solid-state devices, and telecommunications. Electrical engineers design and build fiber-optic communication, memory chips, solar cells, compact disk players, television, cell phones, laptop computers, Internet routers, stereo components, robots, radio, modern aircraft control, electrical power plants, flat panel displays, electric and hybrid cars, biomedical equipment, portable media players, and air traffic control radar. Much of "high technology" is designed and built by electrical engineers. subcontent.text: Hawaiâi Pacific University Electrical Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (HOST) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Electrical Engineering Program Home Transportation Electrical Engineering Program Description: The Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering degree at HPU involves the application of engineering principles to electrical systems and devices for purposes of diagnostics, maintenance, innovation or design, development, testing and commissioning with core expertise in electrical circuits, signals and systems, control and microcontroller systems, electronics, digital hardware, communications technology, embedded systems, and power. Students apply fundamentals in topics of electricity, electromagnetism, and electronics to proceed toward specialization in advanced topics, such as computer architecture, network engineering, renewable energy, robotics and automation, intelligent control, image and audio processing, and modeling of engineering process-based systems. The program offers students a concentration in Engineering Sustainability. Additionally, students have an option to undertake a Thesis and one extra semester of study to attain a Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering with Honors. Graduates can find employment in a wide variety of industries such as heavy industry and manufacturing, government roles, consultancy firms in engineering and business, instrumentation, aviation, robotics, building and construction, healthcare, hospitality, military, and many other areas.Communications while providing students the flexibility to tailor their degree to fit their career interests. subcontent.title: Human Performance Therapeutic Services Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text: Human Performance Therapeutic Services Entry Level Jobs - Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Human Performance Therapeutic Services ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi There are several benefits to obtaining entry-level training programs or certifications to further your journey to a career in health services. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation, like the Good Jobs JawaiÊ»i training programs. Here are a few reasons why obtaining one or more of theses certifications would help you on your path to working in the health field: Enhanced Knowledge and Skills: Entry-level certifications provide you with foundational knowledge and skills related to healthcare and patient care. This can give you a head start in understanding basic concepts and procedures, making it easier to grasp more advanced nursing concepts during your studies. Competitive Advantage: Health programs can be competitive, with limited spots available. Having entry-level certifications can set you apart from other applicants by demonstrating your commitment to the healthcare field and your readiness to contribute to patient care. It shows that you have taken the initiative to acquire relevant skills and experience, making you a more attractive candidate. Practical Experience: Entry-level certifications can provide you with exposure to real healthcare settings, allowing you to become familiar with the clinical environment, patient interactions, and healthcare team dynamics. Networking Opportunities: Obtaining entry-level certifications can help you build connections with healthcare professionals, instructors, and potential employers. Networking within the healthcare field will allow you to have a greater understanding of careers in healthcare through these connections. Improved Employability: Possessing entry-level certification can make you more competitive in the job market and increase your chances of finding employment as a healthcare professional. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for Human Performance Therapeutic Services-related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for nursing-related careers: Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for healthcare professionals, including nurses. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Personal Trainer Certification: Personal trainer certification is a critical step for individuals pursuing a career in the fitness industry. It ensures that trainers have the necessary knowledge and skills to guide clients toward their fitness goals and promote a healthy lifestyle. The specific requirements and certification processes may vary among certifying organizations, so individuals should research and choose the one that best aligns with their career goals and interests. Range of program duration: 4 to 6 weeks Licensed Massage Therapist: Massage therapists use a variety of techniques to apply pressure, knead, rub, or otherwise manipulate the muscles and soft tissues of the body. These techniques can include Swedish massage (gentle, long strokes), deep tissue massage (firm pressure targeting deep muscles), sports massage (focused on athletes and sports-related issues), hot stone massage (heated stones placed on the body), and many others. Range of program duration: 500-600 hours Certified Pharmacy Technician: A pharmacy technician is a healthcare professional who works alongside pharmacists to assist in various pharmacy-related tasks. Their primary responsibilities revolve around supporting the pharmacy's operations, ensuring the safe and efficient dispensing of prescription medications, and providing excellent customer service.  Students will develop skills in calculation, drug classification, processing, inventory, and billing in retail and hospital settings. Range of program duration: 100-150 hours Theses training programs can lead to the following Jobs: Personal Trainer Massage Therapist Pharmancy Techician Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. Hawaii Career Pathways builds bridges between schools and industries so students can get training and education for high-skill, high-wage professions. text: Automotive Collision Repair | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (HOST) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Automotive Collision Repair Home Pathways and Programs Transportation Automotive Collision Repair Automotive Collision Repair Pathway Map to Employment Careers in automotive collision repair focus on restoring vehicles damaged by accidents to their original condition. Professionals in this field perform tasks such as assessing collision damage, replacing or repairing body panels, straightening frames, and refinishing surfaces through painting and detailing. They also work with vehicle owners and insurance companies to estimate repair costs and ensure quality service. Entry-level roles include collision repair technician , auto body specialist , and refinishing technician , with opportunities to advance to positions like shop foreman or collision estimator . These careers require technical skills, precision, and attention to detail and offer employment opportunities in auto repair shops, dealerships, and insurance-related fields. Students in the automotive collision program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into this field with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities to help them understand the current landscape of this industry. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the automotive collision program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore the industry through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in automotive collision may require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training might be required, you may also be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview: The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey: If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement: As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.text:
Automotive Collision Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Resources Contact Us Automotive Collision
			    ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Transportation Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi For entry-level positions in the automotive collision, several industry-related credentials can enhance your qualifications and demonstrate foundational knowledge and skills. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. The following are some NON-CREDIT (not related to college) programs you can take that will help you in your career journey. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for automotive collision related careers: OSHA 10 General - If youâre an entry-level worker, our OSHA 10-Hour Outreach General & Healthcare Industry course is your orientation to occupational safety and health. As part of OSHA's Outreach Training program to raise awareness about the safety measures under OSHA 29 CFR 1910, this course will help teach you how to improve workplace safety. Youâll learn OSHA's best practices for reducing accidents and injuries, including fall protection, emergency evacuation plans, and the use of personal protective equipment. You'll also learn about the major hazards you might encounter in general industry work and solutions for recognizing, controlling, and protecting against them. This includes flammable and combustible substances, chemical and electrical hazards, and fire prevention. Additionally, you should know what your employer's responsibility is for your safety, as well as the rights OSHA grants you as a worker. Thatâs why you'll learn how to file a complaint if your workplace isn't living up to its safety obligations. Range of training duration: 10 hours Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for construction professionals. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Commercial Drivers License Training (CDL): A Commercial Driverâs License (CDL) is essential in the construction industry for operating heavy vehicles such as dump trucks, cement mixers, and tractor-trailers. Workers with a CDL play a critical role in transporting materials, equipment, and machinery to and from construction sites. Obtaining a CDL involves meeting specific requirements, including passing written and skills tests tailored to the type of vehicle being driven. CDL certification ensures that drivers are trained in safety protocols, vehicle operation, and compliance with transportation regulations, making it a valuable credential for construction professionals. Range of program duration: 4-8 Weeks Scissor Lift Certification: Aerial and scissor lifts play an important role in construction and many other industries. These versatile lifts come in several types with various applications and operating hazards. This course will teach you how to maximize worksite safety while working on or around aerial and scissor lifts.  Only trained persons may operate aerial lifts and scissor lifts. This awareness-level certificate course complies with training requirements for aerial lifts and related scaffolding equipment found in OSHA standard 1926.454. It does not provide an OSHA-accepted certification or certification card. Range of program duration: 1-2 Hours These training programs can lead to the following entry level Jobs: Laborer Forklift operator Truck Driver Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. Take Relevant High School Courses: Transportation pathway courses Gain Hands-On Experiences: Internship, shadowing or volunteering Earn Entry Level Certifications: OSHA 10 Dual Credit Opportunities: Take Early College courses Explore your Social Capital: Talk to your family and friends who are working or have worked in the transportation industry. For specific prerequisite courses, and admissions requirements, select the campus via our career maps. UH Community Colleges To apply for admission to a UH Community College with the intent to select an education program, you must: Be 18 years of age or older, or Have earned a U.S. high school diploma, GED, or equivalency certificate *Please see individual community college websites for course placement information The following UH Community College campuses have associates degree programs associated with RCC: Leeward Community College Honolulu Community College KauaÊ»i Community College HawaiÊ»i Community College UH Maui College * University of HawaiÊ»i at Manoa * University of HawaiÊ»i Hilo For general admission to these UH university campuses with the intent to later apply for their programs, you must: Know and provide your current high school GPA Have taken the following high school course requirements: 4 units of English (*journalism and/or newswriting do not count as English credits) 3 units of Math (including Algebra I, Algebra II, and Geometry) 3 units of Science (laboratory courses recommended) 3 units of Social Studies 4 units of other college-prep courses at UHM/UHWO or 7 units of other college-prep courses at UH Hilo College-prep courses can include a 4th unit of math, science, or social science. High school foreign language courses count toward other college-prep courses, but is not required . Certain programs (e.g., nursing, social work, education, etc.) may have additional requirements. Please check with the appropriate department for more information. 5 units of electives (Examples of elective courses: Art, Dance, Band, Physical Education, AVID, Computer Science, etc.) If available, SAT or ACT scores (optional) Other supplemental documents (might be required for individual programs) Letter(s) of Recommendation Personal Statement & List of Achievements form For campus specific requirements, please see individual campus pages via our career map *HawaiÊ»i Pacific University: HPU understands that each student has a unique academic history and individual talents. This is why HPU takes a holistic approach to reviewing applications, and considers all the information provided on your application to make an admissions decision. For more admissions information, please visit the HPU Admissions website . subcontent.text: UH MÄnoa Mechanical Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (HOST) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Mechanical Engineering (BS) Program Home Transportation Mechanical Engineering Program Description: The Department of Mechanical Engineering offers a Bachelor of Science degree in Mechanical Engineering (BS ME) . This degree requires completion of at least 121 credit hours of coursework. The curriculum consists of a group of required courses chosen to provide the students with the basic tools for the professional practice of mechanical engineering and to assist students in developing a sense of responsibility as professionals. The objectives of the lower division curriculum are to build a foundation in the basic sciences and mathematics, provide an introduction to engineering design and professional ethics, develop communications and computer programming skills, and acquire an appreciation for the humanities and social sciences. The objectives of the upper division program are to provide a sound foundation in the engineering sciences; build on that foundation for applications in the areas of energy conversion, mechanical systems and control, experimentation, and manufacturing; and encourage creativity culminating in a capstone design experience. To provide sufficient flexibility, technical elective courses enable students to acquire additional competence in areas compatible with their career objectives. All electives are subject to the approval of an adviser. Apply Now Program Prerequisites: Admission to UH MÄnoa Competition of General Education courses Cost and time commitment: Cost per credit: $441 Total number of credits 121 Approximate total program tuition costs: $53,361 Estimated program length: 4 years (based on 15-18 credits per semester) Financial Aid Resources Recommended College Courses during High School: The courses listed below are recommended for high school students to complete through a dual credit program such as Early College when in high school. These courses meet degree requirements for the UH Manoa BS in Mechanical Engineering program. Classroom and hands-on live lab training is provided that represents the current and new technological trends in the industry. The training will also help students progress from entry level work to higher skill levels in the trade. This program also seeks to serve the community by providing job upgrading opportunities for professionals in the field. Graduates have found that completion of the Auto Body Repair and Painting program enables them to get better paying jobs and to advance faster once employed, than others who do not have the benefit of training. Note: This program requires a valid driver's license. Electrical Engineering is a profession concerned with the design of electrical, electronic, and electro-magnetic systems. Sub-disciplines within this profession include biomedical engineering. bioengineering, electronic circuits, computers, lasers and optics, networks, signal and image processing, solid-state devices, and telecommunications. Electrical engineers design and build fiber-optic communication, memory chips, solar cells, compact disk players, television, cell phones, laptop computers, Internet routers, stereo components, robots, radio, modern aircraft control, electrical power plants, flat panel displays, electric and hybrid cars, biomedical equipment, portable media players, and air traffic control radar. Much of "high technology" is designed and built by electrical engineers. subcontent.text: Hawaiâi Pacific University Electrical Engineering Program | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (HOST) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Electrical Engineering Program Home Transportation Electrical Engineering Program Description: The Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering degree at HPU involves the application of engineering principles to electrical systems and devices for purposes of diagnostics, maintenance, innovation or design, development, testing and commissioning with core expertise in electrical circuits, signals and systems, control and microcontroller systems, electronics, digital hardware, communications technology, embedded systems, and power. Students apply fundamentals in topics of electricity, electromagnetism, and electronics to proceed toward specialization in advanced topics, such as computer architecture, network engineering, renewable energy, robotics and automation, intelligent control, image and audio processing, and modeling of engineering process-based systems. The program offers students a concentration in Engineering Sustainability. Additionally, students have an option to undertake a Thesis and one extra semester of study to attain a Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering with Honors. Graduates can find employment in a wide variety of industries such as heavy industry and manufacturing, government roles, consultancy firms in engineering and business, instrumentation, aviation, robotics, building and construction, healthcare, hospitality, military, and many other areas.Communications while providing students the flexibility to tailor their degree to fit their career interests. title: Aviation Maintenance Technology | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
text: Aviation Maintenance Technology | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Production (FMP) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (HOST) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Aviation Maintenance Technology Home Pathways and Programs Transportation Automotive Maintenance Repair Aviation Maintenance Technology Pathway Map to Employment Careers in aviation maintenance technology focus on ensuring the safety, reliability, and performance of aircraft. Professionals in this field inspect, troubleshoot, repair, and maintain various aircraft systems, including engines, electrical components, hydraulics, and airframes. They follow strict regulations set by the FAA (Federal Aviation Administration) to ensure compliance with safety standards. Entry-level roles, such as aviation maintenance technician or aircraft mechanic , often lead to advanced positions like lead mechanic , maintenance supervisor , or inspection specialist . With additional certifications (e.g., FAA airframe and powerplant certifications), these professionals can work for airlines, private aviation companies, government agencies, or aerospace manufacturers, contributing to the essential operation of the aviation industry. Students in the aviation maintenance technology program of study in high school will have the opportunity to lay the foundation for their journey into this field with a clear understanding of the role and responsibilities as well as work based learning opportunities to help them understand the current landscape of this industry. The map below shows various education and training pathway opportunities available in HawaiÊ»i, starting high school and leading you to a job here in HawaiÊ»i. The Breakdown of the Map Starting in the aviation maintenance technology program of study in high school you will be introduced to key concepts, overall understanding of the field and the opportunity to explore the industry through work based learning to ensure this career path is the right fit for you. A career in aviation maintenance technology may require additional education depending on the path you want to pursue. While more training might be required, you may also be able to attain entry level certifications/courses that will allow you to work in the field right after high school. Community College Track (2+ Years) University Track (4+ Years) Training Programs (< 1-Year) How to use the map. Map Overview: The large map shows all the possible educational and training pathways available in Hawaii. You can click on any of the bubbles to obtain more information. Start Your Journey: If you prefer a guided approach, you can click on âStart Your Journeyâ in the upper left corner of the map. This will take you through various screens and include enlargements of the selected areas of the map overview. Admissions Requirement: As you navigate the map, be sure to read the admission requirements for the Community College and University Track Programs. You must meet admissions requirements to enroll in these programs. Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow. subcontent.title: Aviation Maintenance Technology Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways
subcontent.text:
Aviation Maintenance Technology Entry Level Jobs and Training Programs | Hawaiâi Career Pathways Home Pathways & Programs Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Animal Systems (AS) Food Systems (FS) Agriculture and Food Production (AFP) Business Natural Resources Management (NRM) Architectural Design and Engineering Technology Architectural Design (AD) Engineering Building and Construction Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) Systems Residential and Commercial Construction (RCC) Cultural Arts, Media, and Entertainment Digital Design (DD) Fashion and Artisan Design (FAD) Film and Media Entertainment (FME) Education Learning Support Professional (LSP) Teaching As a Profession (TAP) Health Services Public Health Services (PHS) Diagnostic Services (DS) Emergency Medical Services (EMS/EMT) Human Performance Therapeutic Services (HPTS) Nursing Services (NS) Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Culinary Arts (CA) Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management (SHTM) Information Technology and Digital Transformation Artificial Intelligence (AI) Programming Networking Cybersecurity (Cyber) Web Design and Development (WDD) Transportation Services Automotive Maintenance and Light Repair (MLR) Automotive Collision Repair (ACR) Aviation Maintenance Technology (AMT) Marine Maintenance Technology (MMT) Resources Contact Us Aviation Maintenance Technology
			    ENTRY LEVEL JOBS/ TRAINING PROGRAMS Home Pathways & Programs Transportation Entry Level Jobs-Training Programs See a current list of FREE post high school training programs currently available through the University of Hawaiâi Community Colleges. Take a look at Good Jobs Hawaiâi For entry-level positions in the aviation maintenance technology industry, several industry-related credentials can enhance your qualifications and demonstrate foundational knowledge and skills. Some of those certifications can be done while you are in high school or shortly after graduation. The following are some NON-CREDIT (not related to college) programs you can take that will help you in your career journey. Entry Level Training Programs: Entry-level training for related careers can vary depending on the specific role and level of education required. Here are some common entry-level training options for aviation maintenance technology related careers: OSHA 10 General - If youâre an entry-level worker, our OSHA 10-Hour Outreach General & Healthcare Industry course is your orientation to occupational safety and health. As part of OSHA's Outreach Training program to raise awareness about the safety measures under OSHA 29 CFR 1910, this course will help teach you how to improve workplace safety. Youâll learn OSHA's best practices for reducing accidents and injuries, including fall protection, emergency evacuation plans, and the use of personal protective equipment. You'll also learn about the major hazards you might encounter in general industry work and solutions for recognizing, controlling, and protecting against them. This includes flammable and combustible substances, chemical and electrical hazards, and fire prevention. Additionally, you should know what your employer's responsibility is for your safety, as well as the rights OSHA grants you as a worker. Thatâs why you'll learn how to file a complaint if your workplace isn't living up to its safety obligations. Range of training duration: 10 hours Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: High school students can pursue BLS certification, which teaches cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) skills. BLS certification is often required for construction professionals. Range of program duration: 2 - 4 hours Commercial Drivers License Training (CDL): A Commercial Driverâs License (CDL) is essential in the construction industry for operating heavy vehicles such as dump trucks, cement mixers, and tractor-trailers. Workers with a CDL play a critical role in transporting materials, equipment, and machinery to and from construction sites. Obtaining a CDL involves meeting specific requirements, including passing written and skills tests tailored to the type of vehicle being driven. CDL certification ensures that drivers are trained in safety protocols, vehicle operation, and compliance with transportation regulations, making it a valuable credential for construction professionals. Range of program duration: 4-8 Weeks Scissor Lift Certification: Aerial and scissor lifts play an important role in construction and many other industries. These versatile lifts come in several types with various applications and operating hazards. This course will teach you how to maximize worksite safety while working on or around aerial and scissor lifts. Only trained persons may operate aerial lifts and scissor lifts. This awareness-level certificate course complies with training requirements for aerial lifts and related scaffolding equipment found in OSHA standard 1926.454. It does not provide an OSHA-accepted certification or certification card. Range of program duration: 1-2 Hours These training programs can lead to the following entry level Jobs: Laborer Forklift operator Truck Driver Bridging the Gap Students need to learn the right skills today to succeed in the jobs of tomorrow.
